('73', 0, 5, 9, 338) 2. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('73', 0, 6, 10, 366) February 23, 1938 I have read the Governor Generals statement 3 with the respect and attention it deserves.
('73', 0, 6, 11, 474) I had hoped that it would give some satis faction, as was given at least to me and, if I may say so, a large number of Congressmen when he made a pronouncement upon the Congress demand for certain assurances as a condition precedent to the accep tance of ministerial responsibility by Congress members of the pro vincial Legislatures.
('73', 0, 6, 12, 809) It reads like a special pleading unworthy of a personage possessing unheard of powers.
('73', 0, 6, 13, 896) No one has questioned the propriety of examining the cases of prisoners to be discharged; but what I have questioned, and the Con gress most emphatically questions, is the propriety of such exami nation by provincial Governors in provinces said to be enjoying com plete provincial autonomy.
('73', 0, 6, 14, 1187) That duty and the right of examination belong solely to responsible Ministers as I understand the Government of India Act and the convention in responsibly governed Colonies.
('73', 0, 6, 15, 1362) The Governors duty and right are to advise their Ministers on the question of broad policy and warn them of danger in their exercise of certain powers, but having done so to leave their Ministers free to exercise their unfettered judgment.
('73', 0, 6, 16, 1602) If such were not the case, the responsibility would become a perfectly meaningless term, and the Ministers responsible to their electors would have as their share
('73', 0, 7, 17, 1765) 1 The addressee had consulted Gandhiji in connection with his stay at Nainital and his relations with his father.
('73', 0, 7, 18, 1879) 2 This appeared under the title How Crisis Can Be Avoided.
('73', 0, 7, 19, 1938) 3 Dated February 22
('73', 1, 0, 1, 1958) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 1, 1, 2, 1998) nothing but odium and disgrace, if their responsibility had to be shared with Governors in the daily administration of affairs by law entrusted to them.
('73', 1, 1, 3, 2151) It is hardly graceful for His Excellency to quote against the poor Ministers their non exercise of their undoubted powers to prevent Governors from examining individual cases.
('73', 1, 1, 4, 2327) The Congress Resolution 1 describes their forbearance as exemplary patience.
('73', 1, 1, 5, 2404) I would venture to add that probably it was also the inexperi ence of the Ministers who were totally new to their task.
('73', 1, 1, 6, 2524) I am afraid, therefore, that unless this crucial question is decided in favour of the Ministers, it will be difficult for them to shoulder the grave responsi bility that the Congress has permitted them to take over.
('73', 1, 1, 7, 2740) I am glad that His Excellency has drawn public attention to the method I adopted in Bengal.
('73', 1, 1, 8, 2832) He might have noted also the difference between Bengal on the one hand and the U.P. and Bihar on the other.
('73', 1, 1, 9, 2940) In Bengal I was dealing with a Government which was not bound by the Congress manifesto in any shape or form.
('73', 1, 1, 10, 3050) The Ministers there rightly or wrongly would not listen to a wholesale discharge of convi cted prisoners.
('73', 1, 1, 11, 3156) I was treading upon very delicate ground in pursuance of my promise to the prisoners.
('73', 1, 1, 12, 3242) My motive was purely humanitarian, and the only weapon that I had at my disposal was an appeal to the human in the Bengal Ministers.
('73', 1, 1, 13, 3375) And I am glad to be able to testify that I was not speaking to hearts of stone.
('73', 1, 1, 14, 3455) The situation in the U. P. and Bihar is totally different.
('73', 1, 1, 15, 3514) The Ministers there are bound by the manifesto which gave them victory at the polls.
('73', 1, 1, 16, 3599) They had not only examined the cases of all prisoners whose release they were seeking but, being fully aware of their responsibility for the due preservation of peace in their provinces, had personally secured assurances from the prisoners in question that they no longer believed in the cult of violence.
('73', 1, 1, 17, 3905) One thing in His Excellencys statement gives me hope that the impending crisis might be prevented.
('73', 1, 1, 18, 4004) He has still left the door open for negotiations between the Governors and the Ministers.
('73', 1, 1, 19, 4094) I recognize that the notices were sudden, because in the nature of things they had to be so.
('73', 1, 1, 20, 4187) 2 All the parties have now had ample time for considering the
('73', 1, 2, 21, 4249) 1 Vide Resolution on Ministerial Resignations, 18 2 1938
('73', 1, 3, 22, 4306) 2 The Viceregal statement read: In the case of Bihar the demand was received by the Governor at 1 p.
('73', 1, 3, 23, 4407) and cabled for action by the Chief Secretary by 4 p.
('73', 1, 3, 24, 4460) the same day.
('73', 1, 3, 25, 4474) In the case of the United Provinces the time limit set for compliance was also brief to a degree.

('73', 2, 1, 2, 4620) situation.
('73', 2, 1, 3, 4631) In my opinion the crisis can be avoided if the Governors are left free to give an assurance that their examination of cases was not intended to be usurpation of the powers of the Ministers, and that since they had armed themselves with assurances from prisoners they were free to release them on their own responsibility.
('73', 2, 1, 4, 4953) And I hope that the Working Committee will leave the Ministers free, if they are sum moned by the Governors; to judge for themselves whether they are satisfied by the assurances they may receive.
('73', 2, 1, 5, 5149) One thing I must say in connection with the exercise by His Excellency of his powers under Section 126 (5) in the light of his argument justifying the use of sub section 5 of Section 126. I have read the whole of it.
('73', 2, 1, 6, 5366) It is entitled Control of the Federation over Provinces in Certain Cases.
('73', 2, 1, 7, 5440) Unless the sub sections have no conne ction with one another and they are to be read independently of one another, my reading is that in the present case the exercise of powers under sub section 5 of Section 126 is a manifest misapplication.
('73', 2, 1, 8, 5682) But here I am treading on dangerous ground.
('73', 2, 1, 9, 5726) Let lawyers decide the point.
('73', 2, 1, 10, 5756) My purpose in making this long statement is to assist a peaceful solution of the crisis that has suddenly appeared.
('73', 2, 2, 11, 5872) Harijan, 26 2 1938, and The Hindu, 24 2 1938

('73', 3, 3, 4, 6582) 4. LETTER TO N. S. HARDIKAR
('73', 3, 4, 5, 6610) WARDHA, SEGAON, February 24, 1938
('73', 3, 5, 6, 6644) DEAR DR.
('73', 3, 5, 7, 6653) HARDIKAR, I retain the same view that I held in 1920 as to volunteers.
('73', 3, 5, 8, 6724) You know that at Ahmedabad the Congress had passed a resolution 1
('73', 3, 6, 9, 6790) embodying a pledge for volunteers and certain instructions to be followed by them.
('73', 3, 6, 10, 6873) Experience has proved for me the correctness of the position I then took.
('73', 3, 6, 11, 6947) It is true that there has not been the response that I wanted.
('73', 3, 6, 12, 7010) The causes of the inadequacy of response I need not go into at the present moment.
('73', 3, 6, 13, 7093) Our volunteers for me are, and should be, our non violent army, irresistible and invincible.
('73', 3, 6, 14, 7186) Therefore I would expect every adult person to undergo a practical volunteer training for at least three months.
('73', 3, 6, 15, 7299) I would expect them to give at least one month every year to practical service.
('73', 3, 6, 16, 7379) Now that in seven provinces the Congress runs the Government the thing should be easy.
('73', 3, 6, 17, 7466) The first thing, therefore, is to prepare a textbook, giving in minute detail the course of instructions to be imparted to candidate volunteers and then begin the work of instruction not in cities but in villages.
('73', 3, 6, 18, 7680) I would concentrate all effort on villiages.
('73', 3, 6, 19, 7725) Whilst I note the marvellous mass awakening that has taken place, I am painfully conscious of the fact that a far greater and a far more solid awakening has to take place before we can confidently say that swaraj is ours for the asking.
('73', 3, 6, 20, 7962) Any extraneous event may put power into our hands.
('73', 3, 6, 21, 8013) I would not call that swaraj of the people.
('73', 3, 6, 22, 8057) If what I have said appeals to your head and to your heart, you should show this letter to Jawaharlal and if he approves, and only if he approves, you should take the next step.
('73', 3, 6, 23, 8235) I say this with deliberation.
('73', 3, 6, 24, 8265) I do not want to take a new step in life of a political nature unless I can secure his approval and co operation.
('73', 3, 6, 25, 8379) Secondly, there is not that meeting of our hearts which is necessary for me to give guidance.
('73', 3, 7, 26, 8473) 1 Vide Speech at Congress Session, Ahmedaad I, 28 12 1921
('73', 4, 0, 1, 8531) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 5
('73', 4, 1, 2, 8579) know the reason why.
('73', 4, 1, 3, 8600) I know that there is no such barrier between you and Jawaharlal.
('73', 4, 1, 4, 8665) Therefore even though I may say something which appeals to your head and heart, in my opinion I should have Jawaharlals hearty endorsement before you take any step on the strength of what I say.
('73', 4, 1, 5, 8860) I hope you are now keeping perfect health.
('73', 4, 1, 6, 8903) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('73', 4, 2, 7, 8933) From a facsimile: Mahatma, Vol. IV, between pp.

('73', 4, 3, 9, 8993) 5. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('73', 4, 4, 10, 9019) SEGAON, WARDHA, February 24, 1938
('73', 4, 5, 11, 9053) DEAR MR. JINNAH, I thank you for your letter.
('73', 4, 5, 12, 9099) I have read your letter to Jawaharlal also.
('73', 4, 5, 13, 9143) I observe that both the letters invite, not written replies but a personal discussion.
('73', 4, 5, 14, 9230) I do not know whether it will take place in the first instance between you and Jawaharlal or, now that Subhas Bose succeeds him, between you and the latter.
('73', 4, 5, 15, 9387) If you desire that before this there should be a talk between you and me, I would be delighted to see you in Segaon any time which is convenient to you before the 10th of March after which, if health permits, I might have to go to Bengal.
('73', 4, 5, 16, 9626) So far as I am concerned, just as on the Hindu Muslim question I was guided by Dr. Ansari, now that he is no more in our midst, I have accepted Maulana Abul Kalam Azad as my guide.
('73', 4, 5, 17, 9807) My suggestion, therefore, to you is that conversation should be opened in the first instance as between you and Maulana Saheb.
('73', 4, 5, 18, 9934) But in every case regard me as at your disposal.
('73', 4, 6, 19, 9983) Yours sincerely,
('73', 4, 7, 20, 10000) M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 16 6 1938

('73', 6, 4, 6, 11788) 9. INTERVIEW TO REPRESENTATIVES OF SCINDIA STEAM NAVIGATION COMPANY 3
('73', 6, 5, 7, 11858) [March 4, 1938] 4
('73', 6, 6, 8, 11876) Three representatives of the Scindia Steam Navigation Company had an interview with Gandhiji at Segaon....
('73', 6, 6, 9, 11983) They seemed to be worried by the following among a number of things:
('73', 6, 7, 10, 12052) (1) The discrimination clauses.
('73', 6, 7, 11, 12084) 5 They cited from Gandhijis article in Young India entitled The Giant and the Dwarf 6 the following statements:
('73', 6, 8, 12, 12196) To talk of no discrimination between Indian interests and English or European is to perpetuate Indian helotage.
('73', 6, 8, 13, 12308) What is equality of rights between a giant and a dwarf?
('73', 6, 8, 14, 12364) . And again: In almost every walk of life the Englishman by reason of his belonging to the ruling class occupies a privileged position....
('73', 6, 8, 15, 12503) The cottage industries of India had to perish in order that Lancashire might flourish.
('73', 6, 8, 16, 12590) The Indian shipping had to perish, so that British shipping might flourish.
('73', 6, 9, 17, 12666) Is the shipping not to revive and rise to its full height in a free India?
('73', 6, 10, 18, 12741) (2) What are Indian or swadeshi companies?
('73', 6, 10, 19, 12784) It has become a fashion nowadays to bamboozle the unwary public by adding (India) Limited to full blooded British concerns.
('73', 6, 10, 20, 12908) Lever Brothers (India) Limited have their factories here now.
('73', 6, 10, 21, 12970) They claim to produce swadeshi soap, and have already ruined several large and small soap factories in Bengal.
('73', 6, 10, 22, 13081) Then there is the Imperial Chemicals (India) Ltd.
('73', 6, 10, 23, 13131) which has received valuable concessions.
('73', 6, 10, 24, 13172) This is dumping foreign industries instead of foreign
('73', 6, 11, 25, 13226) 1 The report is date lined New Delhi, March 4, 1938. 2 Vide Telegram to Secretary, Prisoners Relief Society, Lahore, 11 1 1938 Statement to the Press, 14 1 1938, and letter to the addressee, Leter to Sham Lal, 20 2 1938 3 This is reproduced from Mahadev Desais article Swadeshi Industries and Discrimination.
('73', 6, 11, 26, 13535) 4 According to Gandhi19151948: A Detailed Chronology, Shantikumar Morarjee and Gaganvihari Mehta met Gandhiji at Segaon on this date.
('73', 6, 11, 27, 13669) 5 In the new constitution under the Government of India Act of 1935 6 Vide The Giant and the Dwarf
('73', 7, 0, 1, 13768) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 7, 1, 2, 13808) goods on us!
('73', 7, 2, 3, 13821) (3) Then there are companies with Indian Directorate with British Managing Agents who direct the Directorate.
('73', 7, 2, 4, 13931) Would you call a company with a large percentage of Indian capital and a large number of Indian Directors on the Board, but with a non Indian Managing Director or non lndian firm as Managing Agents, a swadeshi concern?
('73', 7, 3, 5, 14150) Gandhiji dealt with these points fairly exhaustively in his reply which may be summarized below in his own words: (1) On this point I am glad you have reminded me of my article written in 1931. I still hold the same views, and have no doubt that a free India will have the right to discriminateif that word must be usedagainst foreign interests, wherever Indian interests need it.
('73', 7, 3, 6, 14531) (2) As regards the definition of a swadeshi company I would say that only those concerns can be regarded as swadeshi whose control, direction and management either by a Managing Director or by Managing Agents are in Indian hands.
('73', 7, 3, 7, 14761) I should have no objection to the use of foreign capital, or to the employment of foreign talent, when such are not available in India, or when we need them, but only on condition that such capital and such talents are exclusively under the control, direction and management of Indians and are used in the interests of India.
('73', 7, 3, 8, 15087) But the use of foreign capital or talent is one thing, and the dumping of foreign industrial concerns is totally another thing.
('73', 7, 3, 9, 15215) The concerns you have named cannot in the remotest sense of the term be called swadeshi.
('73', 7, 3, 10, 15304) Rather than countenance these ventures, I would prefer the development of the industries in question to be delayed by a few years in order to permit national capital and enterprise to grow up and build such industries in future under the actual control, direc tion and management of Indians themselves.
('73', 7, 3, 11, 15607) (3) Answer to this is contained in my answer on the second point.
('73', 7, 4, 12, 15673) Harijan, 26 3 1938
('73', 8, 0, 1, 15692) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 9
('73', 8, 1, 2, 15740) 10. TALK WITH A FRIEND 1
('73', 8, 2, 3, 15765) [Before March 5, 1938] [GANDHIJI:] The States resolution 2 is a call to the States people not to go to sleep but to start work in right earnest.
('73', 8, 2, 4, 15910) The Congress is deeply concerned about the welfare of Indian States, as the Congress resolution 3 on the Federation should clearly show.
('73', 8, 2, 5, 16047) We want the States people to carry on ceaseless work in the States, but not in the name of the Congress.
('73', 8, 2, 6, 16152) The use of the name of the Congress may expose the Congress to insult.
('73', 8, 2, 7, 16223) If insult could result in good to the States people, I would court it.
('73', 8, 2, 8, 16294) But it is far from being so.
('73', 8, 2, 9, 16323) The Congress cannot in the nature of things step into each and every Indian State and protect those who agitate there.
('73', 8, 2, 10, 16442) It is better able to protect them by not allow ing them to use its name.
('73', 8, 2, 11, 16515) If the States people have begun to understand and respect the Congress it is a good thing, but then let them work with the moral support of the Congress but avoid the Congress name.
('73', 8, 2, 12, 16697) Whenever the Congress can effectively help the States people it would do so not by actively meddling with their affairs but by acting as an intermediary.
('73', 8, 2, 13, 16851) Co operation from within the States is an impossible proposition, and therefore I have been deliberately advising the States people to refrain from having Congress Committees within the States.
('73', 8, 2, 14, 17045) Some say: We would end the States. Now this cry does neither these friends nor the Indian States any harm.
('73', 8, 2, 15, 17152) But it would harm them if they were actively interesting them selves in States affairs and trying to work there in the Congress name.
('73', 8, 2, 16, 17286) The prestige of the Congress would suffer and not gain by the use of the Congress name.
('73', 8, 2, 17, 17374) Mysore is a case in point.
('73', 8, 2, 18, 17401) It had a bona fide Congress organization but it could not prevent the Congress flag from being insulted.
('73', 8, 3, 19, 17506) But, said the friend from the States, all these things have happened in British India?
('73', 8, 4, 20, 17593) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desais Notes 2 Passed at the Congress session at Haripura 3 Which inter alia read: The Indian States participating in the Federation should approximate to the Provinces in the establishment of representative institutions and responsible government, civil liberties and method of election to the Federal Houses.
('73', 8, 4, 21, 17930) Otherwise the Federation as it is now contemplated will, instead of building up Indian unity, encourage separatist tendencies and involve the States in internal and external conflicts.
('73', 9, 0, 1, 18115) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 9, 1, 2, 18156) They have, and the Congress has always stood up to the insult.
('73', 9, 1, 3, 18219) That is because in British India we can adopt civil disobedience for any good cause, but in the States it is impossible.
('73', 9, 1, 4, 18340) The Congress Committees will have always to be at the mercy of the States and would be in no better case than, for instance, a Committee in Afgha nistan, which would entirely exist on the mercy of the Government of Afghanistan.
('73', 9, 1, 5, 18568) But of course this is my personal view and interpretation.
('73', 9, 1, 6, 18627) When I came to India, I had an offer from three Indian States to settle and carry on my work from there.
('73', 9, 1, 7, 18732) I had to decline the offer.
('73', 9, 2, 8, 18760) But we do not ask for active help from the Congress.
('73', 9, 2, 9, 18813) We want to organize under the aegis of the Congress.
('73', 9, 2, 10, 18866) The onus of helping us would be upon the Congress, but we do not ask for the help.
('73', 9, 2, 11, 18949) There it is, whether you ask for it or not, the onus would be upon the Congress, and it is not able to discharge it.
('73', 9, 2, 12, 19066) Without being able to render any active support, the aegis of the Congress would be a superfluous affair.
('73', 9, 2, 13, 19172) A big organization like the Congress cannot allow itself to be stultified.
('73', 9, 2, 14, 19247) This is all as plain as a pikestaff to me.
('73', 9, 2, 15, 19290) I do not know how the States people fail to understand this.
('73', 9, 2, 16, 19351) The best help that the Congress can render today is to destroy the delusion that it can actively help the Indian States.
('73', 9, 2, 17, 19472) That will automatically mean that the States people must learn to rely on themselves for all internal reforms.
('73', 9, 3, 18, 19583) I understand this very well.
('73', 9, 3, 19, 19612) But look at the resolution as finally passed.
('73', 9, 3, 20, 19658) The new rider that has been added is absurd.
('73', 9, 3, 21, 19703) We are allowed to have Committees in States but they will be allowed to do nothing.
('73', 9, 3, 22, 19787) The position is anomalous.
('73', 9, 3, 23, 19814) It is, I am afraid.
('73', 9, 3, 24, 19834) It was a concession to the States people, but a useless concession in terms of my interpretation.
('73', 9, 4, 25, 19932) Then, what shall be our position?
('73', 9, 4, 26, 19966) Shall we stop enrolling Congress members and begin to organize a separate national organization which will join the Congress under the present restrictions?
('73', 9, 4, 27, 20123) The real job is to build up your own organization.
('73', 9, 4, 28, 20174) But you may continue to be members of the Congress, attend it and keep in touch with it.
('73', 9, 4, 29, 20263) But your real work will lie in the States.
('73', 9, 4, 30, 20306) The resolution is permissive.
('73', 9, 4, 31, 20336) You need not set up a Congress Committee in the States.
('73', 9, 4, 32, 20392) But my advice is of no value.
('73', 9, 4, 33, 20422) You must seek authoritative instructions from the Working Committee
('73', 9, 5, 34, 20490) Harijan, 5 3 1938

('73', 10, 1, 2, 20557) 11. TELEGRAM TO MRS.
('73', 10, 1, 3, 20578) GEORGE JOSEPH
('73', 10, 2, 4, 20592) [On or after March 5, 1938] 1
('73', 10, 3, 5, 20622) STAGGERING NEWS.
('73', 10, 3, 6, 20639) WANT YOU TO BE BRAVE AND TRUST GODS LOVE IN EVERYTHING.

('73', 10, 5, 11, 20785) 12. DISCUSSION WITH SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE
('73', 10, 6, 12, 20825) March 6, [1938] 2
('73', 10, 7, 13, 20843) SUBHAS BOSE: Bapu, may I ask you a question?
('73', 10, 7, 14, 20888) What is the future programme of the Board?
('73', 10, 8, 15, 20931) [GANDHIJI:] The most immediate piece of work before the Board is the preparation of textbooks for teachers.
('73', 10, 8, 16, 21039) Next, the Board must approach the different Congress ministers and chalk out the plan of work for each province, with due consi deration for the present limitations and capacity of work.
('73', 10, 8, 17, 21226) Thirdly, the Board must itself conduct an experimental centre to test the syllabus it has drawn up, and must revise its own recommen dations at every step in the light of the experience thus gained.
('73', 10, 8, 18, 21425) Fourthly, the Board must organize and conduct as many train ing schools as possible.
('73', 10, 8, 19, 21510) Every training school serves a double pur pose.
('73', 10, 8, 20, 21558) It may not only train future teachers, but every training school also means a demonstration school of basic education.
('73', 10, 9, 21, 21677) SUBHAS BOSE: What about the expenses of the Board?
('73', 10, 9, 22, 21728) [G.] We shall have to beg for it.
('73', 10, 9, 23, 21762) I do not think it right to expect any financial contributions from the Congress governments, because that would provide an opportunity for the criticisms of the opposition party.
('73', 10, 10, 24, 21941) SUBHAS BOSE: Bapu, this is as regards the problem of rural basic education.
('73', 10, 10, 25, 22017) What is your suggestion as regards the problem of basic education in urban areas?
('73', 10, 11, 26, 22099) 1 The addressees telegram to Mahadev Desai, to which this telegram is a reply, is dated March 5, 1938. It read ,Joseph sinking.
('73', 10, 11, 27, 22227) Inform Bapu. 2 The source has these notes placed along with the letters of 1938. 3 All India Education Board
('73', 11, 0, 1, 22336) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 11, 1, 2, 22377) Some municipalities, e.
('73', 11, 1, 3, 22401) g., the municipalities of Calcutta and Bombay, are doing some work in this direction and would like to extend their work in progressive primary education.
('73', 11, 1, 4, 22556) What is your suggestion as regards the problem of primary education in cities?
('73', 11, 1, 5, 22635) [G.] According to my educational philosophy, there is no fundamental difference between the basic education in a rural and an urban area.
('73', 11, 1, 6, 22773) The aim in both is the samethe development of the intelligence through a vocation.
('73', 11, 1, 7, 22856) The system of training that is evolved for rural areas will also be applicable to urban areas.
('73', 11, 1, 8, 22951) I know from personal experience that the products of primary education in urban areas are good for nothing, but, for the present, I do not wish to divide the energies of the Board.
('73', 11, 1, 9, 23132) If it succeeds in solving the problem of rural education, the other problem will also be solved.
('73', 11, 1, 10, 23229) If ten years of work are devoted to rural education, you may consider that the whole problem of primary education whether rural or urban has been grappled with.
('73', 11, 2, 11, 23390) Subhas Bose next asked whether a representative of a city municipality with some experience of municipal education could not be a member of the Board, so that he could attempt, if he liked, to adapt the findings of the A. I. E. B. for the purpose of urban basic education.
('73', 11, 2, 12, 23663) [G.] Certainly.
('73', 11, 2, 13, 23679) The Board will be a representative body.
('73', 11, 2, 14, 23720) All the members of the Board are representatives of the city.
('73', 11, 2, 15, 23782) Where shall I find real villagers as members?

('73', 14, 11, 17, 27965) 19. TALK WITH A PACIFIST 1
('73', 14, 12, 18, 27992) [Before March 12, 1938] [GANDHIJI:] For non violence to permeate as we should have a living faith in God.
('73', 14, 12, 19, 28098) Non violence comes to us through doing good continually without the slightest expectation of return.
('73', 14, 12, 20, 28199) It simply spends itself and it is its own reward, and done in that spirit it is done not merely for friends but certainly for adversaries.
('73', 14, 12, 21, 28338) That is the indispensable lesson in non violence.
('73', 14, 12, 22, 28388) It was thrown my way by God in South Africa in an atmosphere which was as adverse as it well could be.
('73', 14, 12, 23, 28491) I was in a country where I knew no European or Indian.
('73', 14, 12, 24, 28546) I had gone there to make a career as a lawyer.
('73', 14, 12, 25, 28593) But I succeeded in learning the eternal law of suffering as the only remedy for undoing wrong and injustice.
('73', 14, 12, 26, 28702) It means positively the law of non violence.
('73', 14, 12, 27, 28747) You have to be prepared to suffer cheerfully at the hands of all and sundry, and you will wish ill to no one, not even to those who may have wronged you.
('73', 14, 12, 28, 28901) Just now a good many people are talking of world peace,
('73', 14, 13, 29, 28957) 1 This is reproduced from Mabadev Desais Notes.
('73', 15, 0, 1, 29005) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 15, 1, 2, 29046) promoting peace societies and passing resolutions.
('73', 15, 1, 3, 29097) This is good as far as it goes.
('73', 15, 1, 4, 29129) But it may not be non violence.
('73', 15, 1, 5, 29161) An army of non violence exposes itself to all the risks that an army of violence does.
('73', 15, 1, 6, 29248) Only the latter expects to retaliate even when it is not the aggressor.
('73', 15, 1, 7, 29320) An army of non violence runs risks without the wish to retaliate.
('73', 15, 2, 8, 29386) [THE PACIFIST:] But the war spirit is creeping slowly over us.
('73', 15, 2, 9, 29449) How are we to combat it?
('73', 15, 2, 10, 29474) I know how difficult it is for you to combat it in England.
('73', 15, 2, 11, 29534) You have to approach the problem with faith and determination even though you may be very few.
('73', 15, 2, 12, 29629) I would recommend the study of Richard Greggs book 1 on the practice of non violence.
('73', 15, 2, 13, 29715) A true pacifist refuses to use the fruit of armspeace and order.
('73', 15, 2, 14, 29780) So long as we eat a single grain of wheat grown under the protection of arms we participate in violence.
('73', 15, 2, 15, 29885) When one realizes this one has to be an exile in ones own country and a rebel.
('73', 15, 2, 16, 29964) But everything has to be done accor ding to the measure of ones strength.
('73', 15, 2, 17, 30038) A few people with the courage of their convictions can become perfect nuisances to the whole State.
('73', 15, 2, 18, 30138) How far it is possible to reduce the whole thing to practice is for each individual to judge.
('73', 15, 3, 19, 30232) Our English movement for peace is growing.
('73', 15, 3, 20, 30275) But shall we simply go on enrolling more and more members?
('73', 15, 3, 21, 30334) I am not enamoured of numbers.
('73', 15, 3, 22, 30365) A peace army does not rely upon numbers unless they understand the implications of non vio lence.
('73', 15, 3, 23, 30463) I would, therefore, concentrate on a few becoming saturated with the spirit of non violence and disciplining themselves for the utmost suffering.
('73', 15, 3, 24, 30609) How exactly to act in particular situations is a matter of waiting on God.
('73', 15, 3, 25, 30684) The answer comes straight in response to prayer from the heart.
('73', 15, 3, 26, 30748) Such prayer carries with it the anguish of the soul.
('73', 15, 4, 27, 30801) Harijan, 12 3 1938

('73', 19, 1, 2, 34478) 26. A DISCUSSION 1
('73', 19, 2, 3, 34497) [On or before March 15, 1938] 2
('73', 19, 3, 4, 34529) Gandhiji was discussing with a friend and co worker his reactions to the Haripura Congress.
('73', 19, 3, 5, 34621) He said he would make these views known as early as possible for the information and benefit of those who would be responsible for the session in Mahakoshal.
('73', 19, 3, 6, 34779) The Congress is a striking testimony to the great organizing ability of the Sardar and his lieutenants as also his ability to command financial help from moneyed friends.
('73', 19, 3, 7, 34950) But the scale cannot be, must not be, repeated.
('73', 19, 3, 8, 34998) It is wrong to make lavish use of money even when it is plentiful.
('73', 19, 3, 9, 35065) I am partly responsible for the use of electricity and motors and motor lorries.
('73', 19, 3, 10, 35146) For Dev and Dastanes 3 importunity had weakened me at Faizpur.
('73', 19, 3, 11, 35209) Sardars thoroughness showed me the glaring absurdity of the use of these things for a village Congress.
('73', 19, 3, 12, 35313) They made the Congress camp look like a bit of Bombay instead of the multiplied village it should have looked and was intended to look like.
('73', 19, 3, 13, 35454) Classes were retained at Faizpur.
('73', 19, 3, 14, 35488) At Haripura the classification was intensified.
('73', 19, 3, 15, 35536) There were the leaders, ministers, delegates visitors and the villagers.
('73', 19, 3, 16, 35609) The division was not horizontal but vertical.
('73', 19, 3, 17, 35655) The Congress is our political Mecca.
('73', 19, 3, 18, 35692) The annual function is not a tamasha or a fair, but a Haj, a pilgrimage, at which all distinctions as between rich and poor, learned and illiterate, city dweller and villager disap pear.
('73', 19, 3, 19, 35879) Why should Working Committee members have more conveni ences than others?
('73', 19, 3, 20, 35953) Why should they have food other than the villa gers?
('73', 19, 3, 21, 36006) Should a villager eat different food and be differently housed when he becomes a member of the Working Committee?
('73', 19, 3, 22, 36120) Or why should a delegate who happens to be a Minister have a much multi plied hut?
('73', 19, 3, 23, 36203) It is a wholly different thing when one is ill or is used to special food.
('73', 19, 3, 24, 36278) Such persons should make their own arrangements or have them made by the Reception Committee by previous appoint ment.
('73', 19, 3, 25, 36397) Indeed those who have frail bodies should abstainfrom atten dance, unless their presence is urgently required in the interest of the
('73', 19, 4, 26, 36530) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desais Haripura Notes V, 19 3 1938. Appa rently this discussion took place before Gandhiji left Segaon for Calcutta on March 15. 2 Ibid
('73', 19, 5, 27, 36692) 3 Vitthal V. Dastane
('73', 20, 0, 1, 36713) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 21
('73', 20, 1, 2, 36762) Congress.
('73', 20, 1, 3, 36772) Vertical division of the camps into different classes sets a pernicious example to the vast number of villagers who attend the Con gress.
('73', 20, 1, 4, 36910) The Congress management has to go out of its way to show the villagers that before it there is no prince and no pauper and that all are equal.
('73', 20, 1, 5, 37053) If these artificial differences disappear next year, much expense will be saved.
('73', 20, 1, 6, 37134) Electric lights are in no way necessary.
('73', 20, 1, 7, 37175) Visitors should be ex pected to bring their own lanterns.
('73', 20, 1, 8, 37233) The Reception Committee will confine itself to the lighting that may be required for the despatch of Congress work and for the safety of the camp.
('73', 20, 1, 9, 37380) Much work must not be expected to be done after dark.
('73', 20, 1, 10, 37434) Motors and motor lorries are a nuisance, bad education for the villagers, disturbing of peace, a hindrance to the proper despatch of work, and conducive to the raising of dust.
('73', 20, 1, 11, 37611) The distance of ten miles or less from a railway station must be negotiated on foot or in bullock carts.
('73', 20, 1, 12, 37716) None but pedestrian traffic should be permitted inside the camp.
('73', 20, 1, 13, 37781) The site selected for the Congress should be a solid square block as far as possible.
('73', 20, 1, 14, 37867) This will ensure a compact camp avoiding long distance between one end of the camp and the other.
('73', 20, 1, 15, 37965) The layout can be round the quadrangle where the open session is to take place.
('73', 20, 1, 16, 38045) There should be one common kitchen from where food should be served at stated prices per course, not to be eaten on the spot but to be taken to the place of residence of the diner.

('73', 24, 1, 2, 44260) attempt to secure peace, we should be able to produce hundreds.
('73', 24, 1, 3, 44324) And a non violent army acts unlike armed men, as well in times of peace as of disturbances.

('73', 30, 1, 2, 54193) the strength to speak to you at any great length.
('73', 30, 1, 3, 54243) You know that in the whole of our country the land of Orissa is the dearest to me.
('73', 30, 1, 4, 54326) As soon as I returned to India I began to hear of Orissas poverty and famine.
('73', 30, 1, 5, 54404) We raised an amount and sent over Thakkar Bapa in the capacity of a servant of this afflicted province and organized famine relief.
('73', 30, 1, 6, 54536) I also realized that if I could serve Orissa somewhat I would by so doing serve India.
('73', 30, 1, 7, 54623) Thus Orissa became for me a place of pilgrimagenot because the temple of Lord Jagannath was therefor it was not open to me, as it was not open to the Harijansbut because I thought of a novel way of touring the country for the sacred mission of the abolition of untouchability.
('73', 30, 1, 8, 54900) I had heard that the so called sanatanists were enraged at my mission of removing untouchability and would even try to frustrate it with violence.
('73', 30, 1, 9, 55047) If they were really so minded, I said to myself, I should make their work easy by discarding the rail way train and motor car and trekking through the country.
('73', 30, 1, 10, 55207) Moreover, people dont go on a pilgrimage in cars and trains.
('73', 30, 1, 11, 55268) They walk to the sacred place, with the name of God on their lips.
('73', 30, 1, 12, 55335) Meditating on Him; they proceed along their way, forgetful of the fitful fever of the world, and mindful only of offering their homage to the Lord the homage of service.
('73', 30, 1, 13, 55505) At least for me it is not possible to be so engrossed in meditation while on a rail journey.
('73', 30, 1, 14, 55598) And if there was trouble in Puri because of the anger of the sanatanists, we could not flee from their wrath.
('73', 30, 1, 15, 55708) It does not behove a satyagrahi to run away.
('73', 30, 1, 16, 55753) We must face it.
('73', 30, 1, 17, 55770) I could not do all this in a car or a railway train, and so I decided to perform the rest of the Harijan pilgrimage on foot.
('73', 30, 1, 18, 55895) 1 The temple of Lord Jagannath has the reputation of being the most famous in India, for there all human distinctions are supposed to vanish, and all sorts of people, Brahmin and pariah, brush shoulders with one another vying for the darshan of the Lord and even eat His prasad out of one anothers hands.
('73', 30, 1, 19, 56200) But evidently it had outlived that reputation and the description had become a fiction, for the priests would not admit Harijans, but throw them out of the doors of the Lord of the World.
('73', 30, 1, 20, 56388) I said to myself that so long as these distinctions of high and low endured before the very eyes of the Lord of the World, that Lord was not my Lord, that He was the Lord of the Brahmins and the Kshatriyas who exploited his name and kept Harijans out, but certainly not the Lord of the World.
('73', 30, 1, 21, 56681) My ambition of restoring its old reputation to the temple is yet unfulfilled, and you have to help me in fulfilling it.
('73', 30, 2, 22, 56801) 1 In May 1934; vide Statement to the Press, 8 5 1934
('73', 31, 0, 1, 56854) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 31, 1, 2, 56895) long as the doors of the Jagannath temple are closed to the Harijans, they are closed to me as well.

('73', 61, 1, 2, 129519) 50. SPEECH AT GANDHI SEVA SANGH MEETING
('73', 61, 2, 3, 129559) DELANG, March 28, 1938 Having heard the discussion we have had now and Kishorelals brief report of the discussion in the afternoonhaving heard it all I have come to the conclusion that this proposal should not be put before you.
('73', 61, 2, 4, 129788) You should not conclude that this is a result of the argument advanced by a few friends.
('73', 61, 2, 5, 129877) The discussion I heard here has also left the same impression on me.
('73', 61, 2, 6, 129946) This does not mean that those who have faith in this may not act upon it.
('73', 61, 2, 7, 130020) It only means that in this matter I do not wish to force anyone.
('73', 61, 2, 8, 130085) But I certainly insist upon the principle underlying this proposal.
('73', 61, 2, 9, 130153) It is not something unnatural.
('73', 61, 2, 10, 130184) If you have understood my point it will gain weight when you act upon it and carry it out according to your capacity.
('73', 61, 2, 11, 130302) [Passing] a resolution will not by itself suffice.
('73', 61, 2, 12, 130353) Take [for instance] Jamnalaljis suggestion.
('73', 61, 2, 13, 130397) He says that so long as Muslims do not become members of our Gandhi Seva Sangh, it will be futile to make efforts in this direction.
('73', 61, 2, 14, 130530) What he says is true but we shall find the correct remedy after we have served them and our action has borne fruit in the form of a closer contact with the Muslims.
('73', 61, 2, 15, 130695) Of what good will it be if one or two persons become members reluctantly?
('73', 61, 2, 16, 130769) We shall achieve something only when our relationship with the Muslims becomes that of the servant and those whom he serves.
('73', 61, 2, 17, 130894) So far the Congress has been doing what Jamnalalji suggests.
('73', 61, 2, 18, 130955) What it did was good, no doubt.
('73', 61, 2, 19, 130987) They got many Muslims enrolled as members.
('73', 61, 2, 20, 131030) But they had to be coaxed into becoming members.
('73', 61, 2, 21, 131079) This is a kind of flattery, or you may call it a politically motivated policy.
('73', 61, 2, 22, 131158) What I have said today is not for political reasons, although it may well have a welcome political outcome.
('73', 61, 2, 23, 131266) Today I place it before you solely from the standpoint of non vio lence.
('73', 61, 2, 24, 131339) If we are really experimenting with the non violence of the strong, we ought to make an effort to bring about friendship between Hindus and Muslims.
('73', 61, 2, 25, 131488) So far there has been no friendship.
('73', 61, 2, 26, 131525) It was only an attempt to win them over through flattery.
('73', 61, 2, 27, 131583) There was a policy behind all that.
('73', 61, 2, 28, 131619) We maintained friendly relations merely from a practical point of view; it was like a businessmans practical policy.
('73', 61, 2, 29, 131736) So far we have not put our non violence to the test in regard to this issue.
('73', 61, 2, 30, 131813) If today we can take this test in non violence and pass it, we shall move a thousand steps forward on the path of winning freedom

('73', 62, 1, 2, 131992) through non violent means.
('73', 62, 1, 3, 132019) If you really believe that swaraj cannot be won without non violence, you will also have to admit that our non violent means will not be effective without Hindu Muslim unity.
('73', 62, 1, 4, 132194) As I delve deeper into this question many things come up before me.
('73', 62, 1, 5, 132262) After all I am being guided by my intellect, am I not?

('73', 62, 1, 7, 132364) But mere intellect makes one insane or unmanly.
('73', 62, 1, 8, 132412) That is its function.
('73', 62, 1, 9, 132434) In such a situation Rama is the strength of the weak.
('73', 62, 1, 10, 132488) My innermost urge is for pure non violence.
('73', 62, 1, 11, 132532) My weakness is that I do not know how to make it work.
('73', 62, 1, 12, 132587) I use my intellect to overcome that weakness.
('73', 62, 1, 13, 132633) If this intellectual cleverness loses the support of truth, it will blur my vision of non violence, for is not non violence the same as truth?
('73', 62, 1, 14, 132776) Mere practical sense is but a covering for truth.

('73', 62, 1, 31, 133727) But then I cannot say right now how far it can be purified through our service.
('73', 62, 1, 32, 133807) You must not reduce your service to a bargain.
('73', 62, 1, 33, 133854) Non violence cannot work in this way.

('73', 62, 1, 36, 134046) We announced a proposal.
('73', 62, 1, 37, 134071) Millions responded to our call.
('73', 62, 1, 38, 134103) Tell me how this could have happened.

('73', 67, 8, 17, 145265) 53. SPEECH AT GANDHI SEVA SANGH MEETING
('73', 67, 9, 18, 145305) DELANG, March 30, 1938 This is the last day of the present session.
('73', 67, 9, 19, 145373) I myself was not aware that I was going to speak today.
('73', 67, 9, 20, 145429) Kishorelal told me that I was expected to speak.
('73', 67, 9, 21, 145478) Later I also felt like it.
('73', 67, 9, 22, 145505) Before I say what I wish to, I shall answer a question.
('73', 67, 9, 23, 145561) It has been asked whether every member of the Working Committee is not expected to put in 1500 hours of work in the Gandhi Seva Sangh every year.
('73', 67, 9, 24, 145707) The question has been posed by Jethalal.
('73', 67, 9, 25, 145748) Although the idea is very good it cannot be put into practice.
('73', 67, 9, 26, 145811) Today, we must give up our insistence on this.
('73', 67, 9, 27, 145858) Everyone should put in as much physical labournot mental or intellectualas possible.
('73', 67, 10, 28, 145943) 1 Vide letter to the addressee, Letter to Mirabehn, 28 3 1938
('73', 68, 0, 1, 146005) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 69
('73', 68, 1, 2, 146054) However, we cannot go so far as to expect daily four or five hours work from the members.
('73', 68, 1, 3, 146144) This is not an association of labourers.
('73', 68, 1, 4, 146185) If it can become one, well and good.
('73', 68, 1, 5, 146222) But today it is an association of educated people.

('73', 68, 1, 16, 146941) The various items of constructive activity that you are doing are only outward expressions of truth and ahimsa.
('73', 68, 1, 17, 147053) They only reveal how far they can carry you on the road of ahimsa and truth, and ultimately to freedom.
('73', 68, 1, 18, 147157) The removal of untouchability is one of the highest expre ssions of ahimsa.
('73', 68, 1, 19, 147233) It is my daily prayer, as it should be the prayer of you all, that if untouchability does not perish it were far better that Hinduism perished.
('73', 68, 1, 20, 147377) This prayer found its most poignant expre ssion during my Harijan tour of which the principal objective was the opening of the temples to Harijans.
('73', 68, 1, 21, 147525) They tell me that the untouchables do not wish to enter the temples.
('73', 68, 1, 22, 147594) Even if this is true, the reason behind this is that we have made such monsters of them that they no longer have any need for temples.
('73', 68, 1, 23, 147729) Even if they do not care to go into the temples it should be our concern to permit their entry.
('73', 68, 1, 24, 147825) And I have declared day in and day out that whoever believed in the removal of untouchability should shun temples which were not open to Harijans.
('73', 68, 1, 25, 147972) Now, how could I bear the thought of my wife or my daughters having gone to such temples?
('73', 68, 1, 26, 148062) I would plead with them, would go on bended knees to dissuade them from going to these temples, and might have to deny myself personal ties with them if my entreaties failed.
('73', 68, 1, 27, 148237) I have tried to live up to this principle all these years, and I felt humbled and humiliated when I knew that my wife and two ashram inmates 1 whom I regard as my daughters had gone into the Puri temple.
('73', 68, 1, 28, 148441) The agony was enough to precipitate a collapse.
('73', 68, 1, 29, 148489) The machine recorded an alarmingly high blood pressure, but I knew better than
('73', 68, 2, 30, 148568) 1 Durga and Velanbehn; vide Letter to Mahadev Desai, 31 3 1938

('73', 69, 1, 28, 150336) I sent them to Puri not to go into the temple, but to stand just where the Harijans were allowed to go and refuse in protest to go beyond that limit.
('73', 69, 1, 29, 150486) That would have been the right kind of propaganda, and they would that way have done Harijan service.
('73', 69, 1, 30, 150588) To do scavenging work or to eat with Harijans or to feed them is not enough, if we do not deny ourselves the going to temples and the like so long as our kith and kin, the Harijans, are denied their use.

('73', 70, 1, 27, 153123) This is neither religious tolerance nor is it non violence.

('73', 71, 5, 11, 154270) 55. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('73', 71, 6, 12, 154297) DELANG, [On or before March 31, 1938] 3
('73', 71, 7, 13, 154337) Gandhiji was asked in Delang what the Ministers attitude should be over the appointment of Acting Governors in the Provinces.
('73', 71, 7, 14, 154463) He said that acting appointments should not be made from among the services in the Provinces.
('73', 71, 7, 15, 154557) Ministers will not relish the idea of a subordinate official suddenly becoming Governor to whom they have often to refer for guidance and who may even preside over their deliberations.
('73', 71, 7, 16, 154742) Such a Governor cannot act with detachment nor can he command the res pect and confidence of the Ministers.
('73', 71, 7, 17, 154850) I should think that the Viceroy or the Secretary of State would think twice before making such appointments.
('73', 71, 7, 18, 154959) Ministers would be right, indeed it might be their duty, to protest against such an appointment.
('73', 71, 7, 19, 155056) I do not know that such an appointment might not be, casus belli.
('73', 71, 7, 20, 155122) In the Colonies generally I have known the practice of Chief Justices of Supreme Courts acting as Governors in the absence of permanent ones.
('73', 71, 8, 21, 155264) Harijan, 2 4 1938

('73', 72, 1, 2, 155619) 56. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI March 31, 1938
('73', 72, 2, 3, 155662) MAHADEV, What a gift so early in the morning!
('73', 72, 2, 4, 155708) But if even one mistake is not corrected immediately, it will lead to a succession of others.
('73', 72, 2, 5, 155802) All the same I will tolerate thousands of mistakes, but I can never part with you.
('73', 72, 2, 6, 155885) Even death at the hands of a bhakta is preferable to salvation at the hands of those who have no love for one.
('73', 72, 2, 7, 155996) There is, therefore, no question of your leaving.
('73', 72, 2, 8, 156046) Now I will list your mistakes.
('73', 72, 2, 9, 156077) I dont blame Durga or Velanbehn at all.
('73', 72, 2, 10, 156117) Ba has already made atonement; not by fasting but by confessing her lapse to me with utter simplicity.
('73', 72, 2, 11, 156220) She thus made holier yesterday our holy relationship of over fifty five years.
('73', 72, 2, 12, 156299) But what did you do?
('73', 72, 2, 13, 156320) Either your negligence or your blind love for Durga let her do a wrong thing.
('73', 72, 2, 14, 156398) And afterwards when you came to know of my pain, you started a fast without thinking.
('73', 72, 2, 15, 156484) Fasting is no remedy for thoughtlessness or wrong thinking.
('73', 72, 2, 16, 156544) The remedy lies in right thinking.
('73', 72, 2, 17, 156579) When I came to know about your fast, I tried to dis suade you, but to no avail.
('73', 72, 2, 18, 156659) I advised you to think carefully instead of fasting.
('73', 72, 2, 19, 156712) You did not do that.
('73', 72, 2, 20, 156733) You did not even try to understand my point of view.
('73', 72, 2, 21, 156786) Yesterday I asked you very tenderly whether you had understood what I said.
('73', 72, 2, 22, 156862) The reply you gave then was not proper.
('73', 72, 2, 23, 156902) Your behaviour was still worse.
('73', 72, 2, 24, 156934) Instead of attending Maulanas speech, which it was your duty to do, you went away to cry.
('73', 72, 2, 25, 157024) And as a result you threw a silly poem at me.
('73', 72, 2, 26, 157070) Last night also you should have.
('73', 72, 2, 27, 157103) given some time to Maulana, which you did not do.
('73', 72, 2, 28, 157153) You did not, thus, fully avail yourself of the opportunity of serving a Mussalman.
('73', 72, 2, 29, 157236) Had my words yesterday had their intended effect, you would have gone today to Puri with a band of workers and would have shaken up Puri.
('73', 72, 2, 30, 157374) But perhaps I myself was not sufficiently serious, otherwise I should have thought of this right in the beginning.
('73', 72, 2, 31, 157489) If your duty is as clear to you as daylight, I would even grant a days leave and also let you take along with you anybody who might be ready to go.
('73', 72, 2, 32, 157637) This may be done even today if it is possible.
('73', 72, 2, 33, 157684) You say that you interpret me, but may I ask to whom?
('73', 72, 2, 34, 157738) Is it not to Velanbehn?

('73', 77, 5, 8, 163543) 66. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('73', 77, 6, 9, 163568) CALCUTTA, April 2, 1938
('73', 77, 7, 10, 163592) MY DEAR IDIOT, I sent you a wire 1 yesterday and no reply as yet !!!
('73', 77, 7, 11, 163661) I hope it is well with you.
('73', 77, 7, 12, 163689) I do not like these frequent attacks.
('73', 77, 7, 13, 163727) I know that earth and water are the two cures.
('73', 77, 7, 14, 163774) Of course light and air are there; you have a fair dose of them.
('73', 77, 7, 15, 163839) But not of the other two.
('73', 77, 7, 16, 163865) You must take the hip, friction and sitz baths and have abdominal and local earth band ages.

('73', 78, 10, 18, 165819) 68. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('73', 78, 11, 19, 165848) April 3, 1938 My attention has been drawn to the press report purporting to give the gist of the conversations that took place between Sir Nazi muddin 2 and me on April 2. The conversations were strictly confi dential and, therefore, the report can only come from a fertile journalistic brain.
('73', 78, 11, 20, 166142) Ever since I have entered upon this self imposed mission on behalf of political prisoners and detenus, I have made
('73', 78, 12, 21, 166257) 1 Published under the title  No Assurances Given 2 Khwaja Nazimuddin, Muslim League Home Minister of Bengal
('73', 79, 0, 1, 166365) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 79, 1, 2, 166406) known the terms upon which I have intervened.
('73', 79, 1, 3, 166452) But the giving of assurances by prisoners or detenus as a price of freedom has never crossed my mind.
('73', 79, 1, 4, 166554) As a civil resister, I would not be guilty of inducing any political prisoner to give such assurances.
('73', 79, 1, 5, 166657) And I can also add that during my talks with the prisoners at Alipore and Howrah jails and the Regulation III prisoners at Hijli, they made it absolutely clear to me that they would give no assurance to anyone for the purpose of purchasing their freedom.
('73', 79, 1, 6, 166912) I wish for the sake of the cause that the news papers will not anticipate events.
('73', 79, 1, 7, 166994) Every unauthentic report adds to my difficulties which are already formidable.
('73', 79, 2, 8, 167073) Harijan, 9 4 1938

('73', 85, 1, 2, 175526) 79. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('73', 85, 2, 3, 175560) CALCUTTA, April 8, 1938
('73', 85, 3, 4, 175584) With a smiling face Mahatma Gandhi came out of the Presidency Jail at 5 p.
('73', 85, 3, 5, 175659) after having been closeted with 14 state and four women political prisoners for about three hours.
('73', 85, 3, 6, 175758) While leaving the jail gate, Mahatmaji was approached by the Associated Press.
('73', 85, 3, 7, 175837) He said he had a long talk with the prisoners, but that was all he could say at this stage.
('73', 85, 3, 8, 175929) Asked if he was going to see the prisoners again, Mahatmaji said: I may, but not this time.
('73', 85, 4, 9, 176021) Further questioned, he said he might have one or two more meetings with Sir Nazimuddin, the Home Minister, to complete his negotiations, but there is no possibility of his meeting the Governor again now.
('73', 85, 4, 10, 176225) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 4 1938
('73', 85, 5, 11, 176256) 80. THE CHOICE
('73', 85, 6, 12, 176271) My remarks arising out of the recent riots in U.P. 1 have attracted much attention.
('73', 85, 6, 13, 176355) Friends have sent me cuttings from the Press.
('73', 85, 6, 14, 176401) This is some of the criticism printed or spoken : (1) My writing betrayed hysteria.
('73', 85, 6, 15, 176485) (2) I wrote without sufficient data.
('73', 85, 6, 16, 176522) (3) I had recanted my views on non co operation and civil resistance.
('73', 85, 6, 17, 176592) (4) I had been driven to the policy of the Liberals.
('73', 85, 6, 18, 176645) (5) Congressmen had never adopted non violence as between themselves.
('73', 85, 6, 19, 176715) (6) I was expecting the impossible from human nature.
('73', 85, 6, 20, 176769) (7) If my position was accepted swaraj would never be obtained, for all India could never become non violent.
('73', 85, 6, 21, 176879) There is much more I could cull from the criticism.
('73', 85, 6, 22, 176931) I have only taken the relevant parts.
('73', 85, 6, 23, 176969) 1. If my article betrayed hysteria, the symptoms still persist, for in spite of the criticism which I have studied with the care it demanded, I see nothing to change the position I have taken up.
('73', 85, 7, 24, 177165) 1 Vide Our Failure, 22 3 1938
('73', 86, 0, 1, 177195) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 87
('73', 86, 1, 2, 177244) critics should remember that my proposition was specific and narrow.
('73', 86, 1, 3, 177313) Swaraj could not be obtained through non violent means unless our non violence was of the brave and such as to be able to deal effec tively with violence.
('73', 86, 1, 4, 177468) I have not maintained that it could not be obtained by other means.
('73', 86, 1, 5, 177536) But if it could be so obtained we were not ready to deliver the goods, for we were not ready for matching our force against the British.
('73', 86, 1, 6, 177673) 2. All the data required were that there were riots, no matter on how small a scale, that Congressmen were not able to deal with them non violently, and that the aid of the police and the military had to be summoned.
('73', 86, 1, 7, 177890) There was no dispute about these three broad facts.
('73', 86, 1, 8, 177942) They were enough to enable me to draw the conclusion I did.
('73', 86, 1, 9, 178002) In this there was no reflection on the Ministers.
('73', 86, 1, 10, 178052) I have admitted that they could not have acted otherwise.
('73', 86, 1, 11, 178110) The fact, however, remains that the Congress non violence was not able to cope with the emergency.
('73', 86, 1, 12, 178209) 3. There is nothing in my article to warrant the infe rence that I had lost my faith in non co operation and civil resistance.
('73', 86, 1, 13, 178336) All I need say is that it is brighter than ever.
('73', 86, 1, 14, 178385) The two are quite enough to bring swaraj, provided that non violence practised is of the bravest.
('73', 86, 1, 15, 178483) 4. I wish I could be drawn towards the policy of the Liberals.
('73', 86, 1, 16, 178546) I have many personal friends among them.
('73', 86, 1, 17, 178587) But they have no sanction.
('73', 86, 1, 18, 178614) I claim that I have an infallible sanction.
('73', 86, 1, 19, 178658) My article was written to show that during the riots it was not the sanction that had failed, the failure was of the organization which had accepted the sanction, namely, active, constructive non violence.
('73', 86, 1, 20, 178864) 5. I can only refer the critics to the many resolutions of the Congress which do not confine the use of non violence only towards Englishmen.
('73', 86, 1, 21, 179006) Indeed I remember having many discusions at the Working Committee meetings at which the necessity of non vio lence among ourselves was emphasized.
('73', 86, 1, 22, 179153) 6. Well, human nature has hitherto responded nobly to the call of non violence.
('73', 86, 1, 23, 179233) But I am concerned with the Congress nature.
('73', 86, 1, 24, 179278) Congressmen have to sign a pledge which commits them to non violence.
('73', 86, 1, 25, 179348) 1 My question was and ishave they non violence in them?
('73', 86, 1, 26, 179404) If they have, is it of the brave?
('73', 86, 1, 27, 179438) My thesis is that if it is of the brave, it should be enough for dealing with the riots and for delivering the goods.
('73', 86, 2, 28, 179556) 1 The practice was started in 1919 at the time of the satyagraha against the Rowlatt Act; vide Instructions to Volunteers, 26 2 1919
('73', 87, 0, 1, 179689) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 87, 1, 2, 179730) 7. This is answered in the foregoing.
('73', 87, 1, 3, 179768) But I have the fear that our non violence is not of the kind required.
('73', 87, 1, 4, 179839) Congressmen may not treat my warning lightly.
('73', 87, 1, 5, 179885) After all I am supposed to be the Congress expert, however inefficient, on non violence.
('73', 87, 1, 6, 179974) I have confidence in my readings and my remedies.
('73', 87, 1, 7, 180024) I cite Ahmedabad and Viramgam violences 1, Bombay violence during the Princes visit, 2 and Chauri Chaura 3 on the eve of Bardoli.
('73', 87, 1, 8, 180154) The results have amply justified the remedies applied at my instance, though on these occassions critics were not wanting who had expressed their strong disapproval of the suspensions.
('73', 87, 1, 9, 180339) I have no doubt about my present diagnosis [or] about the remedies.
('73', 87, 1, 10, 180407) The remedies are not beyond our ability if we have a living conviction about non violence and its nature.
('73', 87, 1, 11, 180513) Here are some of the remedies : 1. We must discover a solution for the Hindu Muslim tension.
('73', 87, 1, 12, 180606) I use that expression deliberately instead of communalfor if we find this, the other will follow as a matter of course.
('73', 87, 1, 13, 180726) 2. There must be a purging of the Congress registers so as to make them proof against bogus voters.
('73', 87, 1, 14, 180826) From all accounts I receive, our registers contain too many bogus names to be called at all accurate.
('73', 87, 1, 15, 180928) 3. Congressmen must not be afraid to find themselves in a minority.
('73', 87, 1, 16, 180996) 4. Without delay every Provincial Congress Committee should raise a proper corps of volunteers pledged to non violence in thought, word and deed.
('73', 87, 1, 17, 181142) And there should be a manual of instructions as to training, etc., prepared for universal use.
('73', 87, 1, 18, 181237) There is nothing heroic or impracticable in these suggestions.
('73', 87, 1, 19, 181300) But they are impracticable if those who lead have no living faith in non violence.
('73', 87, 1, 20, 181383) If they have not, the sooner non violence is removed from the Congress vocabulary the better it is for the Congress and the nation.
('73', 87, 1, 21, 181515) The alternative is certainly not unadulterated violence.
('73', 87, 1, 22, 181572) The Congress is the only political organization in the world which has, at my instance, adopted unadulterated non violence for the attainment of swaraj.
('73', 87, 1, 23, 181725) It is its only sanction.
('73', 87, 1, 24, 181750) I dare say that if its quality is not what it
('73', 87, 2, 25, 181796) 1 In April 1919 during demonstrations against Rowlatt Act ; vide Press Statement on Suspension of Civil Disobedience, 18 4 1919 2 On November 17, 1921; videA Deep Stain, 18 11 1921 3 In February 1922; vide The Crime of chauri Chaura
('73', 88, 0, 1, 182029) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 89
('73', 88, 1, 2, 182078) should be, it will do great harm to the nation.
('73', 88, 1, 3, 182126) In the last heat we may be found to be cowards instead of brave men and women.
('73', 88, 1, 4, 182205) And there is no disgrace greater than cowardice for fighters for freedom.
('73', 88, 1, 5, 182279) Surely there is nothing to be ashamed of in retracing our steps.
('73', 88, 1, 6, 182344) If we feel that we shall not be able to displace the British power without a violent struggle, the Congress must say so to the nation and prepare accordingly.
('73', 88, 1, 7, 182503) We must do what is being done all the world over forbear when we can, hit when we must.

('73', 89, 6, 9, 184093) 84. INTERVIEW TO P. R. THAKUR 2
('73', 89, 7, 10, 184125) CALCUTTA, April 10, 1938
('73', 89, 8, 11, 184150) Mahatmaji intimated his good wishes to Mr. Thakur and desired that he should follow in the footsteps of his noble grandfather, Sree Guru Chand Thakur, who devoted his life to the cause of the Scheduled Castes.
('73', 89, 8, 12, 184360) He further added that the Congress would try its level best to stamp out the sin of untouchability from the soil of Bengal.
('73', 89, 8, 13, 184484) He asked Mr. Thakur to visit the different Congress Provinces and study for himself the Congress work and activities for the uplift of the Scheduled Castes and make a propaganda in Bengal so that the Bengal Scheduled Castes might respond to the clarion call of the Congress for achieving Indias political end.
('73', 89, 8, 14, 184794) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 12 4 1938

('73', 93, 3, 14, 190132) 94. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 4
('73', 93, 4, 15, 190161) CALCUTTA, April 13, 1938 I regret to inform the public that the negotiations that I have been conducting with the Government of Bengal through Sir Nazim uddin have not yet been concluded.
('73', 93, 4, 16, 190349) I must confess that my arrival in Calcutta was ill timed, as the Ministers were all busy with the assembly work and as it was known that I should come back before the end of March, I felt it was unnecessary to ascertain Sir Nazimuddins wishes about the time of my arrival.
('73', 93, 4, 17, 190622) Had I taken the precaution of writing to him, I would not have found myself in Calcutta at an inauspicious moment.
('73', 93, 4, 18, 190737) I have now to write a letter 5 to Sir Nazimuddin, summarizing my suggestions which, I am assured, will be considered by the Government as speedily as possible and definite decisions takena process which, it is expected, will be completed within one month.
('73', 93, 5, 19, 190993) 1 Daughter of Lakshmidas P. Asar 2 Puratan Buch, addressees husband 3 Which describes the characteristics of a bhakta 4 This was published in the Harijan under the title Negotiations Not Concluded.
('73', 93, 5, 20, 191191) 5 Vide the following item.

('73', 94, 1, 2, 191267) hoped, however, that the decisions may be taken much earlier, and if it becomes necessary for me to return to Calcutta, I shall do so without hesitation, provided, of course, that my health permits it.
('73', 94, 1, 3, 191469) Meanwhile I must repeat that all agitation for the release of detenus and prisoners should be suspended while negotiations con tinue.
('73', 94, 1, 4, 191603) I must also state that it is not conducive to the success of the negotiations if public demonstrations are held in honour of those who may be discharged.
('73', 94, 1, 5, 191757) In my opinion, it is more dignified for Congress men to exercise restraint.
('73', 94, 1, 6, 191833) I have seen extracts of speeches and addresses as reported in the papers which do not betray any spirit of non violence.
('73', 94, 1, 7, 191954) I may add that whilst I have been seeing the convicted prisoners and discussing with them their attitude to non violence for my own guidance, the Government have made it plain to me that whatever the prisoners might state to me will not be allowed to determine their policy.
('73', 94, 1, 8, 192229) They think that it will be improper for them to base their action on such assurances as I may issue.
('73', 94, 1, 9, 192330) I fully appreciate the Government view.
('73', 94, 1, 10, 192370) My talks with political prisoners therefore are purely for my own personal satisfaction.

('73', 95, 1, 2, 193410) 95. LETTER TO KHWAJA NAZIMUDDIN
('73', 95, 2, 3, 193442) [April 13, 1938] 1
('73', 95, 3, 4, 193461) DEAR SIR NAZIMUDDIN, In accordance with the understanding of yesterday, I submit herewith my suggestions : (1) I understand that the detenus, including the Regulation III prisoners, will be discharged and all restrictions upon their liberty will be removed inside of one month from this date.
('73', 95, 3, 5, 193754) I can only hope that I shall not have to return to Calcutta in that connection.
('73', 95, 3, 6, 193834) Should my presence, however, be required, I shall gladly come whenever wanted.
('73', 95, 3, 7, 193913) (2) With regard to the convicted political prisoners I suggest that (A) the ailing prisoners should be discharged forthwith irrespective of their terms of imprisonment; (B) those who have less than 6 months to serve should be discharged forthwith; (C) those who have 18 months or less, but over 6 months to serve, should be discharged within 3 months; (D) those who have longer terms than 18 months to serve should be discharged within one year at the most.
('73', 95, 3, 8, 194371) (3) Those releases should be contingent upon a public understanding between the Government and the Opposition, that is, the Congress Party, to the effect that (A) there shall be no public demonstrations or processions in honour of those detenus or prisoners who may be discharged; (B) there should be no agitation, directly or indirectly, initiated or countenanced by the Congress Party to depart from or improve upon the settlement that may be arrived at.
('73', 95, 3, 9, 194828) In other words, so far as Bengal at any rate is concerned, the question of the release of detenus and political prisoners shall cease to be a Party question or a
('73', 95, 4, 10, 194990) 1 Although the addressee in his letter of April 17 to Gandhiji acknowledges this as of the 12th, this was obviously written after the Statement to the Press, 1341938; vide the preceding item.
('73', 96, 0, 1, 195182) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 97
('73', 96, 1, 2, 195231) matter of public controversy.
('73', 96, 1, 3, 195261) I have purposely refrained from entering into any argument in favour of the suggestions made herein.
('73', 96, 1, 4, 195362) I have discussed them threadbare with you and you have very patiently listened to me.
('73', 96, 1, 5, 195448) Whatever the fate of the negotiations and suggestions, it is agreed between us that a final decision will be taken by the Bengal Government within a few days, certainly within one month from today.
('73', 96, 1, 6, 195646) You have told me that any assurances the prisoners or detenus may give me about non violence could not or would not be allowed by the Government to influence their decision.
('73', 96, 1, 7, 195820) But, as you know, I have interested myself in their cases on the strength of their disavowal of violence for the attainment of Indias freedom.
('73', 96, 1, 8, 195963) Therefore, for my own satisfaction, I discussed the question with them and whilst they did not want to make any statement for the sake of furthering their release, they assured me that they had no faith in violence for securing Indias freedom.
('73', 96, 1, 9, 196207) I believe in their assurance and it would be a pity if such men could not be discharged.
('73', 96, 1, 10, 196296) I forgot to mention one thing during our conversations of yesterday.
('73', 96, 1, 11, 196365) The prisoners at Dum Dum asked me whether I had received the many messages they had sent me through the usual channels.
('73', 96, 1, 12, 196485) I cannot recall having received any, except the messages from the Midnapur girl prisoners.
('73', 96, 1, 13, 196576) Whatever may have happened in the past, I trust that in future you will kindly issue instructions so as to ensure the delivery of their messages to me, assuming, of course, that they are not objectionable.
('73', 96, 2, 14, 196782) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Hindustan Times, 4 10 1938; also C. W. 9919

('73', 98, 1, 2, 199317) 97. DISCUSSION WITH BENGAL CONGRESSMEN 1
('73', 98, 2, 3, 199358) CALCUTTA, [April 13, 1938] 2
('73', 98, 3, 4, 199387) The difference between your view and mine is based on the question whether the Zemindari system is to be mended or ended.
('73', 98, 3, 5, 199509) I say it should be mended, and if it cannot be mended, it would end itself.
('73', 98, 3, 6, 199585) You say that it is incapable of being mended.
('73', 98, 4, 7, 199631) In these words Gandhiji summed up the difference between the Socialist school
('73', 98, 5, 8, 199709) and what may be called the Satyagrahi school, before an informal meeting of Calcutta
('73', 98, 6, 9, 199794) Congressmen.
('73', 98, 7, 10, 199807) Q. The zemindars and mahajans are the instruments of the bureaucracy.
('73', 98, 8, 11, 199877) have always sided with it and are an obstacle to our progress and freedom.
('73', 98, 8, 12, 199952) Why should
('73', 98, 9, 13, 199963) not the obstacle be removed ?
('73', 98, 10, 14, 199993) A. They are indeed part and parcel of the bureaucracy.
('73', 98, 10, 15, 200048) But they are its helpless tools.
('73', 98, 10, 16, 200081) Must they for ever remain so?
('73', 98, 10, 17, 200111) We may do nothing to put them away from us.
('73', 98, 10, 18, 200155) If they change their mentality, their services can be utilized for the nation.
('73', 98, 10, 19, 200234) If they will not change, they will die a natural death.
('73', 98, 10, 20, 200290) If we have non violence in us, we will not frighten them.
('73', 98, 10, 21, 200348) We have to be doubly careful when the Congress has power.
('73', 98, 11, 22, 200406) Q. But cant we say the system of zemindari is an anachronism and should go, by non violent means of course?
('73', 98, 12, 23, 200514) A. Of course we can.
('73', 98, 12, 24, 200535) The question is: must we ? Why can we not say to the zemindars, These are the evils which we ask you to remove yourselves?
('73', 98, 12, 25, 200658) I admit that this presumes trust in human nature.
('73', 98, 13, 26, 200708) Q. Would you say that the Permanent Settlement 3 should remain ?
('73', 98, 14, 27, 200773) A. No, it has to go.
('73', 98, 14, 28, 200794) The way to make the kisans happy and prosperous is to educate them to know the reason of their present condition and how to mend it.
('73', 98, 14, 29, 200927) We may show them the non violent way or the violent.
('73', 98, 14, 30, 200980) The latter may look tempting, but it is the way to perdition in the long run.
('73', 98, 15, 31, 201058) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desais article Kisans and Zemindars.
('73', 98, 15, 32, 201120) Among others who attended this informal meeting were Subhas Chandra Bose and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad.
('73', 98, 15, 33, 201222) 2 From The Hindu, 1441938.
('73', 98, 16, 34, 201249) 3 Introduced by Lord Cornwallis in 1793.
('73', 99, 0, 1, 201290) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 99, 1, 2, 201332) Q. But dont you agree that the land belongs to him who tills it ?
('73', 99, 2, 3, 201398) A. I do.
('73', 99, 2, 4, 201407) But that need not mean that the zemindar should be wiped out.
('73', 99, 2, 5, 201469) The man who supplies brains and metal is as much a tiller as the one who labours with his hands.
('73', 99, 2, 6, 201566) What we aim at, or should, is to remove the present terrible inequality between them.
('73', 99, 3, 7, 201652) Q. But the mending process may be very long.
('73', 99, 4, 8, 201697) A. Seemingly the longest process is often the shortest.
('73', 99, 5, 9, 201753) Q. But why not parcel out the land among the tillers ?
('73', 99, 6, 10, 201808) A. That is a hasty thought.
('73', 99, 6, 11, 201836) The land is today in their hands.
('73', 99, 6, 12, 201870) But they know neither their rights nor how to exercise them.
('73', 99, 6, 13, 201931) Supposing they were told neither to move out of the land nor to pay the dues to the zemindars, do you think their misery would be over?
('73', 99, 6, 14, 202067) Surely much will still remain to be done.
('73', 99, 6, 15, 202109) I suggest that that should be undertaken now and the rest will follow as day follows night.
('73', 99, 7, 16, 202201) That led up to the question of the Kisan Sabhas, their relations with the Congress, their scope and their function.
('73', 99, 7, 17, 202317) My opinion is clear cut, having worked among the kisans and labour all my life.
('73', 99, 7, 18, 202397) There is nothing constitutionally wrong in the Congress allowing the Kisan Sabhas to work independently nor in allowing the office bearers of the Kisan Sabhas to be office bearers of the Congress, for they will come in the usual way.
('73', 99, 7, 19, 202631) But my study of separate kisan organizations has led me definitely to the conclusion that they are not working for the interests of the kisans but are organized only with a view to capturing the Congress organization.
('73', 99, 7, 20, 202849) They can do even this by leading the kisans along the right channels, but I am afraid they are misleading them.
('73', 99, 7, 21, 202961) If the kisans and their leaders will capture the Congress by doing nothing but authorized Congress work, there is no harm.
('73', 99, 7, 22, 203084) But if they do so by making false registers, storming meetings and so on, it would be something like Fascism.
('73', 99, 7, 23, 203194) But the main question is whether you want the Kisan Sabhas to strengthen the Congress or to weaken it, to use the kisan organization to capture the Congress or to serve the kisans, whether the Sabha is to be a rival organization working apparently in the name of the Congress or one carrying out the Congress programme and policy.
('73', 99, 7, 24, 203525) If it is really a rival organization and Congress organization only in name, its strength and energy will be utilized in resisting the Congress and those of the Congress will be utilized in resiting the Kisan Sabha,
('73', 100, 0, 1, 203741) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 101
('73', 100, 1, 2, 203791) with the result that the poor kisans will be ground between the two mill stones.
('73', 100, 2, 3, 203872) Harijan, 23 4 1938
('73', 100, 3, 4, 203891) 98. FOREWORD TO THE PERSIAN MYSTICS
('73', 100, 4, 5, 203927) April 14, 1938 Sir Jogendra Singh is to be congratulated on having given us his rendering into English of the Sayings of the Mystic by Abdullah Ansari 1. Islam has given the world mystics no less than Hinduism or Christianity.
('73', 100, 4, 6, 204154) In these days when irreligion masquerades as religion, it is well to reminds ourselves of what the best minds of all the religions of the world have thought and said.
('73', 100, 4, 7, 204321) We must not, like the frog in the well who imagines that the universe ends with the wall surrounding his well, think that our religion alone represents the whole Truth and all the others are false.
('73', 100, 4, 8, 204519) A reverent study of the other religions of the world would show that they are equally true as our own, though all are necessarily imperfect.
('73', 100, 5, 9, 204660) M. K. GANDHI The Persian Mystics
