('73', 101, 6, 16, 205842) 101. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('73', 101, 7, 17, 205873) ON THE TRAIN TO DELHI, April 14, 1938
('73', 101, 8, 18, 205911) KANTI, You have done something really excellent.
('73', 101, 8, 19, 205960) 2 Act in the same manner in future also.
('73', 101, 8, 20, 206001) And now the answers to your questions 3. 1. It has not been my experience that in daily life it is untruth and dishonesty that always triumph.
('73', 101, 8, 21, 206144) We of course come across instances of these sometimes winning, but if we look deep into the matter we shall see that the real triumph goes to truth.
('73', 101, 9, 22, 206293) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('73', 101, 10, 23, 206320) 2 The addressee had helped an old Mussalman fellow passenger on the train who had lost his ticket (Harijan, 14 5 1938).
('73', 101, 11, 24, 206440) 3 These, briefly, were: (I) Would it not have been proper for the ticketless passenger to evade the ticket examiner?
('73', 101, 11, 25, 206557) Didnt dishonesty often pay ?
('73', 101, 11, 26, 206586) (ii) How far was it proper for the addressee to advise him to be honest ?
('73', 101, 11, 27, 206660) (iii) What right had the ticket examiner to let the passenger off ?
('73', 101, 11, 28, 206728) (iv) Not himself having any money to pay, how could the addressee have appealed to other passengers to pay the ticketless passengers fare ?
('73', 101, 11, 29, 206868) (v) If the passenger could complete his journey to Madras, would it have been right for the addressee to see him out of the platform on a platform ticket ?
('73', 102, 0, 1, 207024) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 103
('73', 102, 1, 2, 207074) If, however, the victory of truth was always self evident, what would be its value, and what would be the merit of adhering to it?
('73', 102, 1, 3, 207205) Is not this the reason why the Ishopanishad, which is regarded as authoritative as the Vedas has this mantra, that the face of truth is covered with a golden lid?
('73', 102, 1, 4, 207368) We are dazzled by the splendour of that lid.
('73', 102, 1, 5, 207413) 2. Now the second question.
('73', 102, 1, 6, 207441) It may not be our lot always to suffer, but that doesnt mean that we shouldt advise other people to follow the seemingly strait and narrow path of truth.
('73', 102, 1, 7, 207595) Even if the old man had been able to hide himself and reach Madras, what would it have availed?
('73', 102, 1, 8, 207691) Where was the guarantee that he would not have got caught somewhere?
('73', 102, 1, 9, 207760) And why should we assume that he had to suffer because finally he had to get down?
('73', 102, 1, 10, 207843) We dont always know what is for our good.
('73', 102, 1, 11, 207885) We should, there fore, proceed blindly on the asump tion that the path of truth cannot but lead to our good.
('73', 102, 1, 12, 207994) 3. It was certainly within the right of the ticket examiner to let that man go.
('73', 102, 1, 13, 208074) If, however, he did not think he had such a right, he could not have neglected his duty out of false pity.
('73', 102, 1, 14, 208181) But even in that case he could have issued the man a ticket and paid for it from his own pocket or could have collected the money from other passen gers.
('73', 102, 1, 15, 208335) 4. Supposing the examiner did not let the man travel, nor issued him a ticket with his own money, and the old man had therefore to miss the train or go to jail, why should he have minded that?
('73', 102, 1, 16, 208528) If he was a lover of truth, he should have faced that cheerfully.
('73', 102, 1, 17, 208594) And we are thinking here about the duty of a lover of truth.
('73', 102, 1, 18, 208655) Even though you are not maintaining yourself with money earned by yourself, on an occasion like this, which arises only once in a while, you could have paid something yourself and collected the balance from the other passengers.
('73', 102, 1, 19, 208884) If the latter had paid anything, so far so good; but even if they hadnt, you would have done your duty.
('73', 102, 1, 20, 208988) But I didnt feel, either, that even the little you did was not enough.
('73', 102, 1, 21, 209059) 5. Had the examiner let the man travel to Madras, he could have informed the ticket collector there that he had used his discretion in letting him go.
('73', 102, 1, 22, 209210) But supposing he had refused to do that, it would not have been right for the old man to get out of the station with the help of a platform ticket.
('73', 102, 1, 23, 209358) However, the way out of that situation would have been easy.
('73', 102, 1, 24, 209419) You yourself could have explained his condition to the ticket collector and if the latter had not been con vinced he could have kept the man in custody.
('73', 102, 1, 25, 209572) These days, however,
('73', 103, 0, 1, 209593) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 103, 1, 2, 209635) they dont follow that practice since it puts the railway company to a loss; the ticket collector merely shouts angrily at such persons and lets them go.
('73', 103, 1, 3, 209788) If you have any doubts even after reading these answers to your questions, ask me again.
('73', 103, 1, 4, 209877) Blessings from
('73', 103, 3, 5, 209892) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 7334. Courtesy: Kantilal Gandhi

('73', 103, 12, 21, 210736) Q. Do you think you have succeeded in your mission regarding the release of the Bengal political prisoners ?
('73', 103, 12, 22, 210845) A. Let us hope so.
('73', 103, 13, 23, 210864) Q. Have you been invited by the Viceroy to Delhi ?

('73', 104, 5, 10, 211569) A. Let us see what these are.

('73', 106, 2, 3, 214183) ON THE TRAIN, April 16, 1938 CHI.
('73', 106, 2, 4, 214217) SUSHILA, Lately you have been figuring in my dreams.
('73', 106, 2, 5, 214270) Shall I call it attachment or love?
('73', 106, 2, 6, 214306) Be that as it may, you have become a big question mark for me.
('73', 106, 2, 7, 214369) You have already taken one; you want to take the other one too ? These words of Mother still echo in my ears.
('73', 106, 2, 8, 214479) Her concern was justified.
('73', 106, 2, 9, 214506) My duty is clear.
('73', 106, 2, 10, 214524) At least today your place is not with me.

('73', 107, 1, 2, 216051) 108. LETTER TO PYARELAL
('73', 107, 2, 3, 216075) April 16, 1938 CHI.
('73', 107, 2, 4, 216095) PYARELAL, Now you may know the reason why I feel light at heart.
('73', 107, 2, 5, 216160) If I want to act on your letter, who is there to stop me?
('73', 107, 2, 6, 216218) But you should know my decision.
('73', 107, 2, 7, 216251) Sushilas pure love has showed me the way.
('73', 107, 2, 8, 216293) For your sake she is starving herself.
('73', 107, 2, 9, 216332) I was overawed when I learnt about it.
('73', 107, 2, 10, 216371) There is no pretence, no outward show.
('73', 107, 2, 11, 216410) I was terribly perturbed.
('73', 107, 2, 12, 216436) If Sushila has to starve herself as she is doing, is my love so only in name or does it serve any purpose?
('73', 107, 2, 13, 216543) Mothers tears made me resolve that if Pyarelals life could be put on the rails then I would be qualified to keep Sushila.
('73', 107, 2, 14, 216665) If that does not happen, I would stand disqualified in my own eyes.
('73', 107, 2, 15, 216733) If my non violence is not capable of melting your heart, how would it help in winning swaraj?
('73', 107, 2, 16, 216827) You have become part of me.
('73', 107, 2, 17, 216855) If I cannot keep you, I am worthless.
('73', 107, 2, 18, 216893) Mothers words were not the words of an ignorant woman.
('73', 107, 2, 19, 216948) Her candid words emanated from her great anguish.
('73', 107, 2, 20, 216998) They went direct to my heart, and she was fully entitled to tell me all she did.
('73', 107, 2, 21, 217079) When others hear such words of truth, it will only benefit them.
('73', 107, 2, 22, 217144) Hence, at that time I lightened my heart by taking the decision that if Pyarelal cannot convince me of the justice of the step he wishes to take, he should give up his fast, whether complete or partial.
('73', 107, 2, 23, 217347) If in his innermost heart he cannot be persuaded, he can by all means abide by his decision and then I will eat when he eats and starve when he starves.
('73', 107, 2, 24, 217500) When he fasts I will fast too.
('73', 107, 2, 25, 217531) If he should leave, my fast will commence from that very moment.
('73', 107, 2, 26, 217596) This thought occurred to me after I heard about Sushila.
('73', 107, 2, 27, 217653) I made my resolve after seeing Mothers anguish.
('73', 107, 2, 28, 217701) She will tell you everything on reaching home.
('73', 107, 2, 29, 217748) God has willed otherwise.
('73', 107, 2, 30, 217774) If you go from here, you will be breaking your vow.
('73', 107, 2, 31, 217826) I cannot quietly sit at Segaon till the visit to the Frontier Province materializes.
('73', 107, 2, 32, 217911) And (at Segaon), you should start nothing until I am settled there (Segaon).
('73', 107, 2, 33, 217988) But this is making a mountain out of a mole hill.
('73', 107, 2, 34, 218038) A new phase has begun for me.
('73', 107, 2, 35, 218068) My love for you will be as much asfor swaraj.
('73', 107, 2, 36, 218114) If the spark that Sushila has kindled is enough, God will grant me the strength to quietly adhere to my resolve.
('73', 107, 2, 37, 218227) If you have become part of me, then your duty is clear.
('73', 107, 2, 38, 218283) You must do as I say.
('73', 107, 2, 39, 218305) By doing so, you will benefit yourself, me, Sushila and Mother, who is like a cow.
('73', 107, 2, 40, 218388) Then all of us will strive together for
('73', 108, 0, 1, 218428) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 109
('73', 108, 1, 2, 218478) swaraj.
('73', 108, 1, 3, 218486) The happiness and peace of many others like Mahadev, for instance depend on your peace of mind.
('73', 108, 1, 4, 218582) If you can believe it, do this much in good faith.
('73', 108, 1, 5, 218633) Nothing should be given up for fear that I may resort to fasting.
('73', 108, 1, 6, 218699) Duty should never be forgotten.
('73', 108, 1, 7, 218731) If you think that it is clearly your duty to go, who am I to stand in the way?
('73', 108, 1, 8, 218810) If there is any room for the slightest doubt, give the benefit of it to me whom you have accepted as father.

('73', 114, 1, 2, 227577) 120. SPEECH AT VIDYAMANDIR TRAINING SCHOOL, WARDHA 1
('73', 114, 2, 3, 227630) April 21, 1938 Today the students of the Vidyamandir have taken a solemn pledge.
('73', 114, 2, 4, 227711) It is a momentous pledge.
('73', 114, 2, 5, 227737) Its fulfilment would seem well nigh impossible.
('73', 114, 2, 6, 227785) This pledge binds one to serve without a break for twenty five years on a monthly salary of Rs. 15. The fact that more than five thousand applications 2 were received is proof that unemploment in our country has reached the extreme limit.
('73', 114, 2, 7, 228024) Some persons, while working for high ideals cannot get even dal and rice; many persons cannot obtain work to fill their bellies.
('73', 114, 2, 8, 228153) 3 It is also proof of the glamour that surrounds Government employment.
('73', 114, 2, 9, 228225) I know that people apply for constableships or teacherships in the hope of adding to their legal pay in illegal ways.
('73', 114, 2, 10, 228343) I hope that no one of you entertains any such hope.
('73', 114, 2, 11, 228395) I do not know that with all my patriotism I could bind myself to serve as a teacher for Rs. 15 per month.
('73', 114, 2, 12, 228501) You must dismiss from your minds the thought that there may be profits left over in your schools to be divided amongst you.
('73', 114, 2, 13, 228625) If, therefore, there is anyone among you who repents of the contract, you will ask the Minister to relieve you.
('73', 114, 2, 14, 228737) I promise to plead for you.
('73', 114, 2, 15, 228765) Having said this, I tender my congratu lations to those who hold to their contract.
('73', 114, 2, 16, 228849) I hope that God will give you strength to abide by your pledge.
('73', 114, 2, 17, 228913) Yours is a self sacrificing pledge.
('73', 114, 2, 18, 228949) If you prove true to your pledge you will set a noble example before the world.
('73', 114, 2, 19, 229029) If you do not succeed, both Ravishankar Shukla and I will be condemed by the world.
('73', 114, 2, 20, 229113) So the weaklings had better withdraw now.
('73', 114, 2, 21, 229155) This scheme is wholly Indian.
('73', 114, 2, 22, 229185) Its ideal was born in Segaon.
('73', 114, 2, 23, 229215) Real India is enshrined in the seven lakhs of villages, whose plight is even worse than Segaons.
('73', 114, 2, 24, 229312) I want you to drive away illiteracy from these villages, find out means whereby villagers can obtain food and cloth ing, and take the message of winning swaraj through truth and non violence to the villages.
('73', 114, 2, 25, 229520) This responsibility rests on you.
('73', 114, 2, 26, 229554) It is your
('73', 114, 3, 27, 229565) 1 The school, a combination of the Wardha Scheme and Ravishankar Shuklas Vidya Mandir Scheme, was to be conducted under the supervision of the Hindustani Talimi Sangh.
('73', 114, 3, 28, 229733) 2 Out of these 166 candidates were selected.
('73', 114, 3, 29, 229778) 3 The remaining part of the paragraph is from Harijan.
('73', 115, 0, 1, 229833) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 115, 1, 2, 229875) dharma to work with this ideal in view.
('73', 115, 1, 3, 229915) I have presented my scheme after mature deliberation.
('73', 115, 1, 4, 229969) If it fails, the teachers would be to blame.
('73', 115, 1, 5, 230014) It is through handicrafts that instruction in geometry, history, geography and arithmetic will be given and an attempt will be made to meet the expenses of the school through the students manual labour.
('73', 115, 2, 6, 230217) You know that the scheme of this education has been drawn up in pursuance of the Congress programme.
('73', 115, 2, 7, 230318) Now the Congress is pledged to win swaraj by non violent and truthful means.
('73', 115, 2, 8, 230395) Therefore the cultivation of these cardinal virtues is the foundation of the scheme.
('73', 115, 2, 9, 230480) And if you do not show these in your daily contact with yourpupils and a character in keeping with them, you will fail and so will your school.
('73', 115, 2, 10, 230624) You know what Hitler is doing in Germany.
('73', 115, 2, 11, 230666) His creed is violence, of which he makes no secret.
('73', 115, 2, 12, 230718) The other day we were told that the sword was their soul.
('73', 115, 2, 13, 230776) The boys and girls there are taught the science of violence from the beginning.
('73', 115, 2, 14, 230856) They are taught to hate the enemy even in their arithmetic, and you will find that the examples have been chosen with a view to inculcate the military spirit.
('73', 115, 2, 15, 231015) If we endorse their creed, we must recognize the necessity of inculcating the spirit of violence from infancy.
('73', 115, 2, 16, 231126) The same thing is happening in Italy.
('73', 115, 2, 17, 231164) We must be honest even as they are honest.
('73', 115, 2, 18, 231207) I have no doubt that if the scheme is worked with all its implications and becomes popular throughout India, a silent revolution will have taken place and swaraj will be a certainty.
('73', 115, 2, 19, 231390) Herr Hitler is achieving his goal through the sword, I through soul.
('73', 115, 2, 20, 231459) Cast off the cloak of foreign thoughts and ideals, identify yourselves with the villagers.
('73', 115, 2, 21, 231550) The Western world is giving us destru ctive knowledge; we want to impart constructive education through non violence.
('73', 115, 2, 22, 231668) May God give you the strength to reach your cherished goal and to fulfil the pledge which you have taken today.

('73', 116, 0, 1, 231885) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 117
('73', 116, 1, 2, 231935) 121. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('73', 116, 2, 3, 231963) April 22, 1938 I observe that the forthcoming interview between Shri Jinnah and myself is not only attracting very wide attention, but is also inducing high hopes in some.
('73', 116, 2, 4, 232135) Then there are friends who gravely warn me against this visit and against building any hope on the interview.
('73', 116, 2, 5, 232245) It is better, therefore, for me to take the public into my confidence and tell them why and how I am waiting upon Shri Jinnah on April 28. He has himself published my first letter 1 to him, showing my attitude on the question of communal unity, which is as dear to me as life itself.
('73', 116, 2, 6, 232529) In that letter I clearly stated that all before me was darkness and that I was praying for light.
('73', 116, 2, 7, 232627) If anything, the darkness has deepened and the prayer become more intense.
('73', 116, 2, 8, 232702) Add to this the fact that for causes some of which I know and some of which I do not, for the first time in my public and private life I seem to have lost self confidence.
('73', 116, 2, 9, 232874) I seem to have detected a flaw in me which is unworthy of a votary of truth and ahimsa.
('73', 116, 2, 10, 232962) I am going through a process of self introspection, the results of which I cannot foresee.
('73', 116, 2, 11, 233053) I find myself for the first time during the past 50 years in a Slough of Despond.
('73', 116, 2, 12, 233135) I do not consider myself fit for negotiations or any such thing for the moment.
('73', 116, 2, 13, 233215) There is no need for any speculation as to the cause of my despondency.
('73', 116, 2, 14, 233287) It is purely internal.
('73', 116, 2, 15, 233310) It comes from within.
('73', 116, 2, 16, 233332) It must be now clear that, if I regarded the forthcoming interview as between two politicians, I should not entertain it in my present depression.
('73', 116, 2, 17, 233479) But I approach it in no political spirit.

('73', 118, 2, 13, 237353) 123. MARTIAL V. MORAL
('73', 118, 3, 14, 237375) It is often forgotten that the Congress has only moral authority to back it.
('73', 118, 3, 15, 237452) The ruling power has the martial, though it often dilutes the martial with the moral.
('73', 118, 3, 16, 237538) This vital difference has come to the fore since the assumption of office by the Congress in seven provinces.
('73', 118, 3, 17, 237648) This office holding is either a step towards greater prestige or its total loss.
('73', 118, 3, 18, 237729) If it is not to be a total loss, the ministers and the legislators have to be watchful of their own personal and public conduct.
('73', 118, 3, 19, 237858) They have to be, like Caesars wife, above suspicion in everything.
('73', 118, 3, 20, 237925) They may not make private gains either for themselves or for their relatives or friends.
('73', 118, 3, 21, 238014) If the relatives or friends get any appointment, it must be only because they are the best among the candidates, and their market value is always greater than what they get under the Government.
('73', 118, 3, 22, 238209) The ministers and the legislators of the Congress ticket have to be fearless in the performance of their duty.
('73', 118, 3, 23, 238320) They must always be ready to risk the loss of their seats or offices.
('73', 118, 3, 24, 238390) Offices and seats in the legislatures have no merit outside their ability to raise the prestige and power of the Congress.
('73', 118, 3, 25, 238513) And since both depend wholly upon the possession of morals, both public and private, any moral lapse means a blow to the Congress.
('73', 118, 3, 26, 238644) This is the necessary implication of non violence.
('73', 118, 3, 27, 238695) If the Congress non violence is merely confined to abstention from causing physical hurt to the British officials and their dependants, such non violence can never bring us independence.
('73', 118, 3, 28, 238882) It is bound to be worsted
('73', 119, 0, 1, 238908) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 119, 1, 2, 238950) in the final heat.

('73', 119, 1, 4, 239076) There is considerable force in the argument of those who have conceived Congress non violence in that narrow light when they say that it is a broken reed.

The relevant part of the resolution read: In view of the different conditions prevailing in the States and the rest of India, the general policy of the Congress is often unsuited to the States and may result in preventing or hampering the natural growth of a freedom movement in a State.
('73', 123, 2, 15, 247868) Such movements are likely to develop more rapidly and to have a broader basis, if they draw their strength from the people of the State, produce self reliance in them, and are in tune with the conditions prevailing there, and do not rely on extraneous help and assistance or on the prestige of the Congress name.

('73', 125, 2, 3, 250596) WARDHA, April 24, 1938 2
('73', 125, 3, 4, 250621) We have to make of this training school a school for winning freedom and for the solution of all our ills, of which the chief one is our communal troubles.
('73', 125, 3, 5, 250777) For this purpose we shall have to concentrate on non violence.
('73', 125, 3, 6, 250840) Hitlers and Mussolinis schools accept as their fundamental principle violence.
('73', 125, 3, 7, 250919) Ours is non violence according to the Congress.
('73', 125, 3, 8, 250967) All our problems have therefore to be solved non violently.
('73', 125, 3, 9, 251027) Our arithmetic, our science, our history will have a non violent approach, and the problems in these subjects will be coloured by non violence.
('73', 125, 3, 10, 251171) When Madame Halide Edib Hanum delivered her address to the Jamia Millia Islamia on Turkey I remarked that whereas generally history is a chronicle of kings and their wars, the future history will be the history of man.
('73', 125, 3, 11, 251390) 3 That can be or is only non violent.
('73', 125, 3, 12, 251428) Then we shall have to concentrate not on city industries but on rural industries, that is to say, if we want to keep all the 700,000 of villages alive,and not only a fraction of them, we have to revive our village handicrafts.
('73', 125, 3, 13, 251655) And you may be sure that if we can impart scholastic training through those crafts we can bring about a revolution.
('73', 125, 3, 14, 251771) Our text books will have also to be prepared with the same end.
('73', 125, 3, 15, 251835) I want you to give your close consideration to what I am saying and reject what does not appeal to you.
('73', 125, 3, 16, 251939) If what I say does not appeal to our Mussalman brethren, they may reject it summarily.
('73', 125, 3, 17, 252026) The non violence I want is not non violence limited to the fight with the British but is to be applied to all our internal affairs and problemstrue active non violence from which will issue live Hindu Muslim unity and not a unity based on mutual fear like the pact, for instance, between Hitler and Mussolini.
('73', 125, 3, 18, 252336) When the New Education Scheme was launched I was full of self confidence in which I now feel I am lacking.
('73', 125, 3, 19, 252443) My words had power of which they seem to be bereft today.
('73', 125, 3, 20, 252501) This lack of confidence is due not to things without but to things within.
('73', 125, 3, 21, 252576) It is not that my senses are paralysed.
('73', 125, 3, 22, 252616) My intellect gives me good work for my age.

('73', 131, 1, 2, 260627) 142. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('73', 131, 2, 3, 260657) April 29, 1938 The appointment of Mr. Dain, a subordinate of the Orissa Government, to be the acting Governor threatens to precipitate a crisis of the first magnitude.
('73', 131, 2, 4, 260825) The matter looked small on the surface.
('73', 131, 2, 5, 260865) The fact that he is to retire after the termination of the acting appointment has been regarded as sufficient atonement for an admitted mistake.
('73', 131, 2, 6, 261010) In my opinion it is no atonement.
('73', 131, 2, 7, 261044) If he is reverted to his original permanent post, not only would there not be anything wrong but if the Ministers wanted to be churlish, they might take a secret delight in their quondam acting Governor becoming their subordinate.
('73', 131, 2, 8, 261275) The whole of the sting lies in a subordinate official becoming an acting Governor of his Province with whom the Ministers are expected to work and almost daily submit documents for his signature and have him to preside at their meetings.
('73', 131, 2, 9, 261513) It is incongruous and unbecoming and reduces autonomy to a farce.
('73', 131, 2, 10, 261579) If this autonomy is real, and is to blossom forth into full freedom, nothing should be done by superior powers after the previous style.
('73', 131, 2, 11, 261716) Every one of their acts must conform to a rule or convention.
('73', 131, 2, 12, 261778) It must not depend upon the caprice of the Governor General or even the Secretary of state for India.
('73', 131, 2, 13, 261880) Wherever the prestige of autocracy depended upon its exacting obedience, willing or unwilling, from the ruled, the prestige of the superior authority that has voluntarily divested itself of autocracy and conferred autonomy should consist in always carrying the majority party with it.
('73', 131, 2, 14, 262165) There is no other way that I can think of for the healthy growth of autonomy and the avoidance of friction.
('73', 131, 2, 15, 262273) The Viceroy and the Governors have bestowed unstinted praise upon all the Ministers of India.
('73', 131, 2, 16, 262367) They have given no cause for the exercise of the more than ample powers reserved under the Govern ment of India Act.
('73', 131, 2, 17, 262484) The prestige of the majority party depends upon never sleeping over the rights of the people, never allowing a single error on the part of the superior authority to escape their vigilant eyes.
('73', 131, 2, 18, 262677) Looked at in this light, the Congress, it seems to me, cannot allow the appointment to pass unchallenged.
('73', 131, 2, 19, 262783) I hear that the Orissa Ministry has threatened to resign as soon
('73', 131, 3, 20, 262848) 1 This was published under the title Acting Governorship of Orissa.
('73', 132, 0, 1, 262916) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 133
('73', 132, 1, 2, 262966) as Mr. Dain occupies the gubernatorial chair.
('73', 132, 1, 3, 263012) I understand too that an interim Ministry will be appointed to carry on the Government.
('73', 132, 1, 4, 263100) I suppose that as soon as the acting appointment is over and the Gover nor returns from leave, by some arrangement the present Ministry will be reinstated.
('73', 132, 1, 5, 263256) That wont be fair play.
('73', 132, 1, 6, 263280) The Congress will stultify itself to submit to any such arrangement.
('73', 132, 1, 7, 263349) The governance of a province is not like a play of children.
('73', 132, 1, 8, 263410) The Congress is discovering what a thankless task it is, how serious it is.
('73', 132, 1, 9, 263486) The real Ministers, who represent the real majority of the Orissa legislators, cannot look unconcerned on the administration of their province passing into the hands of new irresponsible persons appointed at the will of the Governor or acting Governor as the case may be.
('73', 132, 1, 10, 263758) I do hope, therefore, that the mistake will be undone before it is too late.
('73', 132, 1, 11, 263835) There are many ways of doing it gracefully.
('73', 132, 1, 12, 263879) But there must be a will before a graceful way is found.
('73', 132, 1, 13, 263936) I hope it will be.
('73', 132, 2, 14, 263955) Harijan, 7 5 1938
('73', 132, 3, 15, 263973) 143. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('73', 132, 4, 16, 264003) April 29, 1938 I enjoy the privilege of friendship with Sir Mirza Ismail.
('73', 132, 4, 17, 264077) I know that he is anxious to liberalize the administration of Mysore.
('73', 132, 4, 18, 264147) I have found him to be willing to listen to the advice and suggestions of friends.
('73', 132, 4, 19, 264230) And I know that the tragedy 3 which has been enacted in Mysore has filled him with distress.
('73', 132, 4, 20, 264323) I have read the communique issued by the Mysore Government.
('73', 132, 4, 21, 264383) It does not read convincing to me.

('73', 133, 0, 1, 265374) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 133, 1, 2, 265416) for a solution of their difficulties, it would be wrong on my part at this critical juncture to content myself merely with sending letters or even telegrams of advice.
('73', 133, 1, 3, 265584) One or two facts stand out prominently.
('73', 133, 1, 4, 265624) There has been firing upon an unarmed crowd, resulting in several deaths and many more being injured.
('73', 133, 1, 5, 265726) I will assume, though the information received by me on behalf of the public is to the contrary, that there was some provo cation.
('73', 133, 1, 6, 265857) We can never know with absolute certainty whether the firing was justified.
('73', 133, 1, 7, 265933) There is no code which can give an exact definition of justification.
('73', 133, 1, 8, 266003) It must always be a matter of opinion, and opinions always have a knack of varying.
('73', 133, 1, 9, 266087) What I, therefore, venture to suggest to the Mysore Government is that they should not be satisfied with making an inquiry, however impartial it may be.
('73', 133, 1, 10, 266240) The demonstration that is going on in Mysore about the national flag is a symptom of the time.
('73', 133, 1, 11, 266335) I must confess that I was not aware of a popular awakening in Mysore on a wide scale, as there undoubtedly is.
('73', 133, 1, 12, 266446) It gladdens me, as I hope it gladdens the Mysore authorities.
('73', 133, 1, 13, 266508) I suggest, therefore, that the best and only remedy for the Maharaja and his Adviser, Sir Mirza Ismail, is to divest the Government of its autocracy and to make popular representatives responsible for the administration of Mysore.
('73', 133, 1, 14, 266739) The responsibility must be on the broadest scale possible if it is to ensure peace in Mysore.
('73', 133, 1, 15, 266833) It has been suggested that the state being backward, responsibility can only be a plant of slow growth.
('73', 133, 1, 16, 266937) I have never subscribed to that doctrine.
('73', 133, 1, 17, 266979) It is not a compliment to the States.
('73', 133, 1, 18, 267017) One would expect them, with all the natural advantages in their favour, to show much greater progress than in unwieldy British India.
('73', 133, 1, 19, 267151) To the leaders of the people of Mysore I will say:These tragic deaths and injuries inflicted upon innocent persons would be a small price paid for the liberty of the people.
('73', 133, 1, 20, 267325) They may make an enquiry and the injured and the heirs to the deceased may receive compen sation.
('73', 133, 1, 21, 267423) But if I were a Mysorean, I would not lay stress on personal gains; I would use these sacrifices for gaining the liberty for which they had been made voluntarily or involuntarily.
('73', 133, 1, 22, 267603) They should also remember that one condition of success is the retention of a truly non violent spirit and atmosphere under every conceivable circumst ance.
('73', 133, 1, 23, 267760) I have been told that the people have been behaving with exemplary non violence and that the crowd bravely suffered the
('73', 134, 0, 1, 267880) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 135
('73', 134, 1, 2, 267930) firing.
('73', 134, 1, 3, 267938) If that is proved to be the case, I for one will rejoice over the loss of life.
('73', 134, 1, 4, 268018) It is the necessary price paid for gaining liberty.
('73', 134, 2, 5, 268070) Harijan, 7 5 1938
('73', 134, 3, 6, 268088) 144. DISCUSSION WITH VALLABHBHAI PATEL 1
('73', 134, 4, 7, 268129) April 29, 1938 Sardar Vallabhbhai raised the question of the Lancashire Delegation coming out and asked Mahatmaji as to the lines on which the Congress is likely to approve of an agreement with U.K. Mahatmaji said that he could not see under what circumstances the Congress could be a party to agreeing to take cloth from Lancashire in return for cotton from India.
('73', 134, 4, 8, 268495) He said that would be definitely against the whole creed of the Congress.
('73', 134, 5, 9, 268569) Sardar Vallabhbhai pointed out that the Advisory Committee was appointed on a recommendation of the Assembly and the report of the Advisory Committee and the recommendation of the Government of India thereon were, without division, demanded by the Assembly to be put before them.
('73', 134, 5, 10, 268849) He, therefore, inferred that the Congress party in the Assembly were committed to negotiations with Lancashire, and he said that it would not be right for the Congress to go back on it.
('73', 134, 5, 11, 269035) Mahatmaji said that he was not a party to these requests and demands, but he said that as far as the Advisory Committee were concerned, he would say to them as under :
('73', 134, 6, 12, 269203) 1. The Advisory Committee may examine the trade pact from a purely economic point of view.
('73', 134, 6, 13, 269294) 2. That if, on that examination, they could honestly recommend an agreement with U.K., including an arrangement with Lancashire, he saw no objection to their making such recommendation.
('73', 134, 6, 14, 269480) 3. Per contra, if, on such examination, the Advisory Committee felt that they could not recommend such an agreement, he would not be sorry.
('73', 134, 6, 15, 269620) 4. That any such recommendation made by the Advisory Committee, as constituted, would command his best attention, but he would advise the Advisory Committee to put in a paragraph at the end of their recommendation saying that they had examined the whole question only from an economic point of view and no other.
('73', 134, 6, 16, 269933) Other points of view, viz., political, etc., were for the Government of India to consider and the Assembly to express an opinion on.
('73', 134, 6, 17, 270066) 5. Mahatmaji, however, made it clear in unambiguous language that if the Advisory Committee felt that they could not put in any such observation out of what he calls self respect, they may not do so.
('73', 134, 6, 18, 270266) He said that, in that case, the Congress was quite capable of raising its own points.
('73', 134, 6, 19, 270352) As I was leaving, he said:
('73', 134, 7, 20, 270379) 1 As reported by Purushottamdas Thakurdas
('73', 135, 0, 1, 270421) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 135, 1, 2, 270463) Do your best acording to your lights and leave us to do our best according to the political light.
('73', 135, 2, 3, 270562) He added that both these expressions of opinion from different points of view
('73', 135, 3, 4, 270640) would be equally valuable and consistent.
('73', 135, 4, 5, 270682) From Purushottamdas Thakurdas Papers.
('73', 135, 4, 6, 270720) Courtesy:Nehru Memorial Museum
('73', 135, 5, 7, 270751) and Library.
('73', 135, 6, 8, 270764) 145. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('73', 135, 7, 9, 270796) ON THE TRAIN TO PESHAWAR, April 30, 1938
('73', 135, 8, 10, 270837) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, Here, is a copy of the brief notes I have jotted down of the 31 2 hours talks with Jinnah.
('73', 135, 8, 11, 270948) It may be that you and the other members may not like the basis.
('73', 135, 8, 12, 271013) Personally I see no escape from it.
('73', 135, 8, 13, 271049) My handi cap today is that I do not move about the country, as you do, and a still more serious handicap is the inner despondency that has overtaken me.
('73', 135, 8, 14, 271202) I am carrying on, but it is galling to me to think that I have lost the self confidence that I possessed only a month ago.
('73', 135, 8, 15, 271325) I hope that this is but a temporary phase in my life.
('73', 135, 8, 16, 271379) I have mentioned this to help you to examine the proposals on their merits.
('73', 135, 8, 17, 271455) I do not suppose the first will present any difficulty.
('73', 135, 8, 18, 271511) The second is novel, with all its implications.
('73', 135, 8, 19, 271559) You will not hesitate summarily to reject it if it does not commend itself to you.
('73', 135, 8, 20, 271642) In this matter you will have to give the lead.
('73', 135, 8, 21, 271689) I expect to return on the 11th.

('73', 136, 1, 2, 272158) 146. NOTE TO MAHADEV DESAI
('73', 136, 2, 3, 272185) [April, 1938] 1

('73', 143, 1, 8, 285185) I have been preaching the creed of non violence for 50 years.
('73', 143, 1, 9, 285247) 2 Its superior strength I came to realize in South Africa where I had to pit it against organized violence and racial prejudice.
('73', 143, 1, 10, 285376) I practised it in South Africa, where everybody, like the Pathans, is armed and the Government has introduced conscription.
('73', 143, 1, 11, 285500) 3 The people said how a handful of Indians could fight the African Government with that weapon.
('73', 143, 1, 12, 285596) I returned from South Africa with a clear conviction of the superiority of the method of non violence to that of violence.
('73', 143, 1, 13, 285719) In India also, we have used it for gaining our rights and we have achieved some measure of success.
('73', 143, 2, 14, 285819) If the method of violence takes plenty of training, the method of non violence takes even more training, and that training is much more difficult than the training for violence.

('73', 145, 4, 13, 290428) PESHAWAR, May 4, 1938
('73', 145, 5, 14, 290450) Mahatma Gandhi replied that the Socialists believing in the Congress creed
('73', 145, 6, 15, 290525) could not be excluded from the Congress on account of their socialistic ideas.
('73', 145, 7, 16, 290604) Gandhiji is reported to have pointed out that Pandit Nehru and Mr. Subhas Chandra
('73', 145, 8, 17, 290686) Bose were Socialists.
('73', 145, 8, 18, 290708) So long as the Socialists accepted the Congress creed and
('73', 145, 9, 19, 290766) carried out the Congress programme he could not see there was any objection to their
('73', 145, 10, 20, 290851) being admitted into the Congress organization.
('73', 145, 10, 21, 290898) This, however, was his interpretation
('73', 145, 11, 22, 290936) of the existing Congress practice.
('73', 145, 11, 23, 290971) Whether different courses were warranted under
('73', 145, 12, 24, 291018) particular local conditions in the Frontier Province, he was unable to say.

('73', 146, 3, 5, 291743) He took strong exception to addresses being presented in English when he could well read Urdu and, if he felt any difficulty anywhere, he could consult Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan.
('73', 146, 3, 6, 291920) Continuing, Gandhiji said: 2
('73', 146, 4, 7, 291949) Your address is one paean of praise of me.
('73', 146, 4, 8, 291992) Well, I have never found it easy to appropriate such praise, but let me tell you that there was no time in my life when I was less able to appropriate such praise than I am today.
('73', 146, 4, 9, 292172) For a curious sense of despondency has possessed me and I cannot yet get over it.
('73', 146, 4, 10, 292254) Well, I came here not to make a speech, and I was told that I need not give more than five minutes.
('73', 146, 4, 11, 292354) But a sentence in your address 3 compels me to devote a few minutes more than I had anticipated.
('73', 146, 4, 12, 292451) The sentence about non violent passive resistance at once took my memory back to Germiston in South Africa in 1907 4. A meeting of European friends was convened to hear me speak on passive resistance, as the movement was then known.
('73', 146, 4, 13, 292684) The Chairman of the meeting there expressed practically the same statement as you have made in the address, viz., that passive resistance was a weapon of the weak.
('73', 146, 4, 14, 292848) The reference jarred on me and I immediately corrected the speaker.
('73', 146, 4, 15, 292916) It is curious, if not also surprising, that you should have made the same mistake after all these years of satyagraha in India.
('73', 146, 4, 16, 293044) We may be weak and oppressed, but non violence in not a weapon of the weak.
('73', 146, 4, 17, 293120) 5 It is a wea pon of strongest and the bravest.
('73', 146, 4, 18, 293168) Non violence has greaterpower than Hitlers or Mussolinis force.

('73', 149, 1, 2, 298627) 161. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('73', 149, 2, 3, 298653) MARDAN, May 7, 1938
('73', 149, 3, 4, 298673) MY DEAR IDIOT, Sushila has been keeping you informed about me.
('73', 149, 3, 5, 298736) I have not therefore worried to write to you.
('73', 149, 3, 6, 298782) It has been an anxious time here.
('73', 149, 3, 7, 298816) Your analysis is good.
('73', 149, 3, 8, 298839) Of course the experience was due to my weakness, lack of faith.
('73', 149, 4, 9, 298903) Let us all hope that I shall come out of the well of despair stronger and purer.
('73', 149, 4, 10, 298984) There is as yet no sign of the end of the crisis.
('73', 149, 4, 11, 299034) Darkness is still there.
('73', 149, 4, 12, 299059) There is still an unaccountable dissatisfaction with myself.
('73', 149, 4, 13, 299120) Moodiness is wholly unnatural to me.
('73', 149, 4, 14, 299157) it creeps over me now and again.
('73', 149, 4, 15, 299190) I suppress it by constant work.
('73', 149, 4, 16, 299222) But the body does not respond to it as readily as I want it to.
('73', 149, 4, 17, 299286) But I have not lost faith.
('73', 149, 4, 18, 299313) There are signs that I shall get out of the slough.
('73', 149, 4, 19, 299365) I may be deceived.
('73', 149, 4, 20, 299384) I have patience.
('73', 149, 4, 21, 299401) I do not fret over the delay.
('73', 149, 4, 22, 299431) If it is to be a new birth, a regeneration all round, it must be preceded by adequate travail.
('73', 149, 4, 23, 299526) You are not to worry over my present condition.
('73', 149, 4, 24, 299574) The sexual sense is the hardest to over come in my case.
('73', 149, 4, 25, 299631) It has been an incessant struggle.
('73', 149, 4, 26, 299666) It is for me a miracle how I have survived it.
('73', 149, 4, 27, 299713) The one I am engaged in may be, ought to be, the final struggle.

('73', 151, 1, 2, 301743) I have not yet recovered from the shock of the story 1 I heard this afternoon.
('73', 151, 1, 3, 301822) The Sikhs from Mayar told me of the tragedy that happened there in broad daylight.
('73', 151, 1, 4, 301905) So far as I know the victims had done nothing to provoke the ire of the assassins.
('73', 151, 1, 5, 301988) The assassins did the deed in broad daylight and bolted away without anyone trying to apprehend them.
('73', 151, 1, 6, 302090) It is worth pondering over how such a thing could happen when we are all talking of non violence.
('73', 151, 1, 7, 302188) There were in the village Khudai Khidmatgars and others believing in the creed of non violence.
('73', 151, 1, 8, 302284) It was their duty to catch the culprits.
('73', 151, 1, 9, 302325) It is their duty to prevent the recurrence of the deed.
('73', 151, 1, 10, 302381) It is also your duty to befriend the bereaved and to assure the fear stricken of your sympathy and succour.
('73', 151, 1, 11, 302489) So long as things of this kind countinue to happen in our midst, our non violence must be in doubt.

('73', 151, 3, 13, 302607) 165. SPEECH AT KALUKHAN 2
('73', 151, 4, 14, 302633) May 7, 1938 3
('73', 151, 5, 15, 302647) Your address is made up of two partsone devoted to my praise and the other to non violence.
('73', 151, 5, 16, 302739) The first part may be ignored for I am sure that that is going to do good to nobody.
('73', 151, 5, 17, 302824) In fact I am quite sure that if someone offered to sing my praises for twenty four hours, he would get tired and I should fall fast asleep.
('73', 151, 5, 18, 302964) What God may have enabled me to do is but a repayment of debt, and he who repays a debt deserves no praise.
('73', 151, 5, 19, 303072) In fact if he fails to do so, he may be liable to prosecution.
('73', 151, 5, 20, 303135) What interests me more is what you have said about non violence.
('73', 151, 5, 21, 303200) Let me tell you that I should not have been able to sum up better the characteristics of a non violent man.
('73', 151, 5, 22, 303308) But let me tell you what you have not said in your address, and that is the implications of non violence.

('73', 153, 1, 2, 305731) 167. SPEECH AT POLITICAL CONFERENCE, PESHAWAR 1
('73', 153, 2, 3, 305779) May 8, 1938 In all your three addresses 2 you have told me that you made a triumphant and unique demonstration of non violence during the C. D. campaign, but I have to find out whether you have assimilated non violence with all its implications.
('73', 153, 2, 4, 306025) The principal purpose of my visit was to find out whether all that I had heard from the Khan Saheb about the Khudai Khidmatgars was true, and I am very sorry that I could not give all the time that was needed in order to find out the truth.
('73', 153, 2, 5, 306266) One conviction I am carrying back with me, viz., the wonderful and affectionate allegiance of the people to the Khan Saheb as their general.
('73', 153, 2, 6, 306407) Not only the Khudai Khidmatgars but I noticed wherever I went that every man, woman and child knew him and loved him.
('73', 153, 2, 7, 306525) They greeted him most familiarly.
('73', 153, 2, 8, 306559) His touch seemed to soothe them.
('73', 153, 2, 9, 306592) And Khan Saheb was most gentle to whoever approached him.
('73', 153, 2, 10, 306650) The obedience of the Khudai Khidmatgars was unquestioned.
('73', 153, 2, 11, 306708) All this has filled me with boundless joy.
('73', 153, 2, 12, 306751) A general merits such obedience.
('73', 153, 2, 13, 306784) Khan Saheb has it by right of love unlike the ordinary general who exacts obedience through fear.
('73', 153, 2, 14, 306882) The question now is what use will Khan Saheb make of the tremen dous power of which he finds himself in possession?
('73', 153, 2, 15, 306998) I cannot answer the question now.
('73', 153, 2, 16, 307032) Nor can the Khan Saheb.
('73', 153, 2, 17, 307056) Hence it is that, if God wills it, I should like to revisit this wonderful Province about October, make a prolonged stay and study in detail the working of non violence.
('73', 153, 3, 18, 307226) Harijan, 21 5 1938

('73', 154, 1, 8, 308118) You may pluck out my eyes, but that cannot kill me.
('73', 154, 1, 9, 308170) You may chop off my nose, but that will not kill me.
('73', 154, 1, 10, 308223) But blast my belief in God and I am dead.
('73', 154, 1, 11, 308265) You may call this a superstition, but I confess it is a superstition that I hug, even as I used to hug the name of Rama in my childhood when there was any cause of danger or alarm.
('73', 154, 1, 12, 308446) That was what an old nurse had taught me.
('73', 154, 2, 13, 308488) But you think that superstition was necessary for you?
('73', 154, 2, 14, 308543) Yes, necessary to sustain me.
('73', 154, 3, 15, 308573) That is all right.
('73', 154, 3, 16, 308592) May I now ask if you had anything like a prophetic vision?
('73', 154, 3, 17, 308651) I do not know what you call a vision and what you will call prophetic.
('73', 154, 3, 18, 308722) But let me give you an experience in my life.
('73', 154, 3, 19, 308768) When I announced 2 my fast of 21 days in jail I had not reasoned about it.
('73', 154, 3, 20, 308843) On retiring to bed the previous night I had no notion that I was going to announce the next morning a fast of 21 days.
('73', 154, 3, 21, 308962) But in the middle of the night a Voice woke me up and said: Go through a fast. How many? I asked.
('73', 154, 3, 22, 309060) 21 days, was the answer.
('73', 154, 3, 23, 309085) Now let me tell you that my mind was unprepared for it, disinclined for it.
('73', 154, 3, 24, 309161) But the thing came to me as clearly as anything could be.
('73', 154, 3, 25, 309219) Let me tell you one thing more and I have done.
('73', 154, 3, 26, 309267) Whatever striking things I have done in life I have not done prompted by reason but prompted by the instinct, I would say God.
('73', 154, 3, 27, 309394) Take the Dandi Salt March of 1930. I had not the ghost of a suspicion how the breach of Salt Law would work itself out.
('73', 154, 3, 28, 309514) Pandit Motilalji and other friends were fretting and did not know what I would do; and I could tell them nothing, as I myself knew nothing about it.
('73', 154, 3, 29, 309663) But like a flash it came, and as you know it was enough to shake the country from one end to the other.
('73', 154, 3, 30, 309767) One last thing.
('73', 154, 3, 31, 309783) Until the last day I knew nothing about announcing the 6th of April 1919 as a day of fasting and prayer.
('73', 154, 3, 32, 309888) But I dreamt about itthere was no Voice or Vision as in 1930and I felt it was just the thing to do.
('73', 154, 3, 33, 309988) In the morning I shared it with C.R. and announced it to the country, you know with what a wonderfully spontaneous response.
('73', 154, 4, 34, 310113) Harijan, 14 5 1938
('73', 154, 5, 35, 310132) 1 Vide An autobiography sub title  Glimpses of Religion 2 On April 30, 1933; vide  Statement on Fast, 30 4 1933 3 Vide  Speeh at Chowpatty, Bombay, 6 4 1919

('73', 155, 1, 2, 310331) 169. INTERVIEW TO A PROFESSOR 1
('73', 155, 2, 3, 310363) PESHAWAR, [Before May 9, 1938] 2
('73', 155, 3, 4, 310396) [PROFESSOR:] How is it that many of the English Pacifists are talking of defence and elaborate plans of defence?.
('73', 155, 3, 5, 310510) May it not be possible to carry pacifism too far?
('73', 155, 3, 6, 310560) Supposing Abyssinia had simply non resisted and said to Italy, Do your worst, would the Italians have been ashamed and desisted from their design?
('73', 155, 3, 7, 310707) Lansbury said they would.
('73', 155, 3, 8, 310733) [GANDHIJI:] I shall take up the Abyssinian question first.
('73', 155, 3, 9, 310792) I can answer it only in terms of active resistant non violence.
('73', 155, 3, 10, 310856) Now non violence is the activest force on earth, and it is my conviction that it never fails.
('73', 155, 3, 11, 310950) But if the Abyssinians had adopted the attitude of non violence of the strong, i.e, the non violence which breaks to pieces but never bends, Mussolini would have had no interest in Abyssinia.
('73', 155, 3, 12, 311142) Thus if they had simply said: You are welcome to reduce us to dust or ashes but you will not find one Abyssinian ready to co operate with you, what would Mussolini have done?
('73', 155, 3, 13, 311317) He did not want a desert.
('73', 155, 3, 14, 311343) Mussolini wanted submission and not defiance, and if he had met with the quiet, dignified and non violent defiance that I have described, he would certainly have been obliged to retire.
('73', 155, 3, 15, 311529) Of course it is open to anyone to say that human nature has not been known to rise to such heights.
('73', 155, 3, 16, 311629) But if we have made unexpected progress in physical sciences, why may we do less in the science of the soul?
('73', 155, 3, 17, 311738) Now about the English Pacifists.
('73', 155, 3, 18, 311771) I know there are some great and sincere men amongst them, but they are thinking in terms of pacifism as distinguished from unadulterated non violence.
('73', 155, 3, 19, 311922) I am essentially a non violent man, and I believe in war bereft of every trace of violence.
('73', 155, 3, 20, 312014) An essentially non violent man does not calculate the consequences.
('73', 155, 3, 21, 312082) The English Pacifists you are talking of calculate, and when they speak of pacifism they do so with the mental reservation that when pacifism fails, arms might be used.
('73', 155, 3, 22, 312251) With them not non violence but arms are the ultimate sanction, as was the case with Woodrow Wilsons Fourteen Points 3. No, someone has to arise in
('73', 155, 4, 23, 312398) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desais Frontier Notes III.
('73', 155, 4, 24, 312450) The Professor has not been identified in the source.
('73', 155, 4, 25, 312503) 2 Gandhiji left Peshawar on the morning of May 9. 3 Outlined by him in a speech before the U. S. Congress on January 8, 1918, they became the basis of the armistice between Germany and the Allies and the subsequent peace treaty signed at Versailles.

('73', 156, 1, 2, 312803) England with the living faith to say that England, whatever happens, shall not use arms.
('73', 156, 1, 3, 312892) They are a nation fully armed, and if they having the power deliberately refuse to use arms, theirs will be the first example of Christianity in active practice on a mass scale.
('73', 156, 1, 4, 313070) That will be a real miracle.

('73', 158, 5, 12, 316394) 174. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('73', 158, 6, 13, 316429) NEW DELHI, May 10, 1938
('73', 158, 7, 14, 316453) The Associated Press sought the opinion of Mahatma Gandhi regarding the terms of the settlement arrived at between the Mysore Government and the Mysore Congress over the flag trouble, 1 announced by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, when he arrived here this morning by the Frontier Mail on his way to Bombay.
('73', 158, 8, 15, 316755) Mahatma Gandhi said that he fully concurred with the terms of the settlement as he thought that it was the proper decision in the circumstances.
('73', 158, 8, 16, 316900) When he was told that some Socialists objected to Sardar Patels decision to allow the State flag to be hoisted by the side of the Congess flag, Mahatma Gandhi said that their objection was nevertheless not without reason; because they wanted to abolish the States, which was only possible by armed revolution to which creed he did not subscribe.
('73', 158, 9, 17, 317246) When questioned as to what should be the attitude of the general public towards the Congress flag and the Red (Socialist) flag in the case of the Congress sponsoring the labour cause in a strike, Gandhiji thought that with him the only flag that counted was the Congress flag.
('73', 158, 9, 18, 317523) A labour union which had faith in the Congress should, in all circumstances, work under the Congress flag.
('73', 158, 9, 19, 317630) If there were many flags, he feared that a clash was bound to occur.
('73', 158, 10, 20, 317699) 1 The terms of the settlement were: (1) Recognition of Mysore Congress; (2) declaration by the Mysore Government that it is open to the Reforms Committee to discuss and recommend responsible Government for Mysore State; (3) four Congress men who resigned from the Reforms Committee to be renominated with three additional Congressmen to be selected by the State Congress; (4) the satyagraha to be called off by the State Congress; (5) general amnesty to political prisoners and withdrawal of all repressive orders; and (6) the flag dispute to be settled on the lines suggested by Mahatma Gandhi, namely, that the Congress flag should be flown along with the State flag on all ceremonial occasions.
('73', 158, 10, 21, 318397) But at purely party functions of the Congress only the National flag is to be flown.
('73', 159, 0, 1, 318482) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 159, 1, 2, 318524) Regarding the release of the Delhi political prisoners, Mahatma Gandhi said that the question of their release was before him.
('73', 159, 1, 3, 318651) He would do his utmost to secure it, but at the moment he could not say as to when he would take up the matter.
('73', 159, 1, 4, 318763) The Bombay Chronicle, 11 5 1938

('73', 162, 1, 2, 322736) 181. NOTE TO D. B. KALELKAR 1
('73', 162, 2, 3, 322766) [Before May 14, 1938] 2
('73', 162, 3, 4, 322790) My silence should not in any case stand between us.
('73', 162, 3, 5, 322842) I have nothing to say about Nanavati.
('73', 162, 3, 6, 322880) I only wanted to know all that might be said about him.
('73', 162, 3, 7, 322936) I have organized myself in such a way that his or anyone elses going will not inconvenience me.
('73', 162, 3, 8, 323032) It is not necessary for Nanavati to stay here whenever I am here.
('73', 162, 3, 9, 323098) When he serves you I consider it as service to me.
('73', 162, 3, 10, 323149) Nanavati is staying here to know what village life is and to find out what part he can play in it.
('73', 162, 3, 11, 323248) He is mainly useful as a musician and when everyone leaves Segaon he would stay on and die here.
('73', 162, 3, 12, 323345) It is quite difficult to explain the usefulness of such a man.
('73', 162, 3, 13, 323408) But it is enough if, even while staying with you, he remembers that he has to pass his life in Segaon.
('73', 162, 3, 14, 323511) In this way he can retain his self respect and keep his word too.
('73', 162, 3, 15, 323577) So I think it is his dharma to go from here so long as you need him.
('73', 162, 3, 16, 323646) But if deep down in his heart he has lost interest in Segaon, he should unhesitatingly take his mind off Segaon.
('73', 162, 3, 17, 323759) His aim in life would then be to follow in your footsteps and take up Hindi.
('73', 162, 3, 18, 323836) This is the proper age for him to fix his aim.
('73', 162, 3, 19, 323883) I have very little use for him when I am in Segaon because for the most part Kanu takes up the responsibility for music.
('73', 162, 3, 20, 324004) At present his main job in Segaon is to propagate weaving and to think of and experiment on village sanitation.
('73', 162, 3, 21, 324116) These two tasks are very important.
('73', 162, 3, 22, 324152) The result may not be visible today but eventually it will grow into a big tree.
('73', 162, 3, 23, 324233) This aspect may however be ignored for the present.
('73', 162, 3, 24, 324285) It is good I am observing silence, so that you can ponder over this note.
('73', 162, 3, 25, 324359) Yet if you want to discuss something I am prepared to talk.
('73', 162, 3, 26, 324419) Todays silence leaves room for such violations.
('73', 162, 4, 27, 324467) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10786
('73', 162, 5, 28, 324512) 182. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH

('73', 166, 1, 2, 328807) 186. LETTER TO KHWAJA NAZIMUDDIN
('73', 166, 2, 3, 328840) BOMBAY, May 15, 1938
('73', 166, 3, 4, 328861) DEAR KHWAJA SAHEB, I thank you for your letter 1 of the 11th instant received yester day.
('73', 166, 3, 5, 328951) I showed it today to Subhas Babu.
('73', 166, 3, 6, 328985) I must confess that it does not satisfy my expectations.
('73', 166, 3, 7, 329042) At the same time, I fully recognize the labours given to the question by the Government.
('73', 166, 3, 8, 329131) I can also appre ciate their extreme caution.
('73', 166, 3, 9, 329177) I am not, therefore, going to come to any hasty decision.
('73', 166, 3, 10, 329235) But before I can examine the implications of the policy adumbrated in your letter, I should like to know the number of prisoners that will still remain to be dealt with after the operation of the first three clauses.
('73', 166, 3, 11, 329452) And before I can come to any conclusion, it will be absolutely necesary for me to know how the prisoners will respond to the propositions laid down by the Government.
('73', 166, 3, 12, 329619) I can well understand from your standpoint that such a pro cedure may not be countenanced.
('73', 166, 3, 13, 329710) But I am bound by a moral pro mise given to the prisoners and in pursuance thereof, if the whole programme is to work smoothly, it is necesary for me to know their mind.
('73', 166, 3, 14, 329880) It would be a breach of promise on my part if I submitted without demur to anything less than almost immediate and un conditional discharge.
('73', 166, 3, 15, 330021) I am sure you will not ask me for this purpose to travel to Calcutta.
('73', 166, 3, 16, 330091) I would, therefore, ask you kindly to grant permission either to Subhas Babu or to Sarat Babu to see the prisoners as my deputies.
('73', 166, 3, 17, 330222) Of course, your request for secrecy will be strictly respected.
('73', 166, 3, 18, 330286) Subhas Babu has not seen this letter.
('73', 166, 3, 19, 330324) He is engaged in the Working Committee meeting away from where I am staying, but if he was here, I am sure he would share the views expressed herein.
('73', 166, 4, 20, 330474) Yours sincerely,
('73', 166, 5, 21, 330491) M. K. GANDHI The Hindustan Times, 4 10 1938; also C. W. 9922

('73', 178, 3, 4, 347423) STUPID DAUGHTER, You have been proving your stupidity in every letter.
('73', 178, 3, 5, 347494) Yes, I did say that if you were tired of Segaon then I had not been entitled to receive service from you.

('73', 178, 3, 10, 347827) These two days have not passed well.
('73', 178, 3, 11, 347864) Yesterday I worked for 12 hours.
('73', 178, 3, 12, 347897) I was mentally exhausted.
('73', 178, 3, 13, 347923) I had a terrible backache.
('73', 178, 3, 14, 347950) I slept well.
('73', 178, 3, 15, 347964) I was alert again.
('73', 178, 3, 16, 347983) But the mental condition is not good.
('73', 178, 3, 17, 348021) In such a situation I do feel your absence.
('73', 178, 3, 18, 348065) But how can I send for you, how can I ask you to come so long as you do not feel drawn to this place?
('73', 178, 3, 19, 348167) Would I have been able to work so much if you had been near me?
('73', 178, 3, 20, 348231) Now do you understand what I want?
('73', 178, 3, 21, 348266) But this certainly does not mean that you should come here at once under any circumstances.
('73', 178, 3, 22, 348358) Now your second question.
('73', 178, 3, 23, 348384) I accept your version of what happ ened on the 9th night.
('73', 178, 3, 24, 348442) There is no question of your account being incorrect.
('73', 178, 3, 25, 348496) Those who see silver in a sea shell are right at all times.
('73', 178, 3, 26, 348556) But he who knows a sea shell will see it only as a sea shell, will he not?
('73', 178, 3, 27, 348631) Oh, the things that sexual impulse makes us do!
('73', 178, 3, 28, 348679) This does not even mean that I am in the right and what you thought was merely imagination.
('73', 178, 3, 29, 348771) Believe me, I admit I may have been a prey to illusion; so you can stick to your own position.
('73', 178, 3, 30, 348866) Indeed it is your duty to do so.
('73', 178, 3, 31, 348899) Ponder that verse in the Bhajanavali.
('73', 178, 3, 32, 348937) Only that is dharma which is followed by the learned and practised by the saintly and by peoplefree from attachment and hatred, and which your heart accepts as dharma.
('73', 178, 3, 33, 349105) What the learned, the saintly and people free from attachment, etc., believe can never be acceptable to us if our heart does not accept it.

('73', 179, 1, 3, 349703) That is to say, while it is necessary to exercise discretion, we must take it that if the reasons which dictate avoidance of physical contact are applicable to any other behaviour or gestures, such gestures, too must be avoided.

('73', 179, 5, 22, 350726) 204. RESOLUTION ON MYSORE SETTLEMENT 2
('73', 179, 6, 23, 350765) [May 18, 1938] 3
('73', 179, 7, 24, 350782) The Working Committee has read the popular and official versions of the recent firing that took place near Vidhuraswatham in Mysore on an unarmed crowd.
('73', 179, 7, 25, 350935) The Committee deplores the fact that the State authorities felt called upon to resort to firing.
('73', 179, 7, 26, 351032) On seeing that the Mysore government has appointed a tribunal to inquire into the causes that led to the firing, the Working Committee refrains from expressing any opinion on the tragedy.
('73', 179, 7, 27, 351220) But the Working Committee thinks that H.H. the Maharaja should establish responsible govern ment in his State so that the responsibility for law and order including firing, whenever it is deemed necessary, will be shouldered by a government answerable to the people.
('73', 179, 7, 28, 351487) The Working Committee sends its condolences to the members of the bereaved families and expresses its sympathy with those who suffered injuries.
('73', 179, 8, 29, 351632) 1 Time 2 According to The Bombay Chronicle, 19 5 1938 the resolution drafted by Gandhiji was discussed by the Working Committe on May 18 and passed the following day.
('73', 180, 0, 1, 351799) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 181
('73', 180, 1, 2, 351849) The Committee approves of the settlement effected by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and Acharya Kripalani as between the Mysore State and the Mysore State Congress.
('73', 180, 1, 3, 352008) The Working Committee notes with satisfaction that in furtherance of the settlement the Mysore Govern ment have issued a communique, 1 and congratulates H. H. the Maha raja and his advisers on the prompt manner in which they are carrying out the settlement.
('73', 180, 1, 4, 352266) The Working Committee hopes that the settlement will be strictly carried out also by the Mysore State Con gress.
('73', 180, 1, 5, 352379) On the question of hoisting the national flag the Working Committee hopes that care will be taken not to do anything that may imply any disrespect to the State flag by the State Congress or the national flag by the State authorities.
('73', 180, 1, 6, 352613) 2 The final status of the national flag will depend not upon the ability to exercise compulsion but upon the correct conduct of Congressmen and the progressive record of service that the Congress establishes in the country.
('73', 180, 1, 7, 352837) It should further be borne in mind that the national flag is the symbol of non violence and national unity to be brought about by means strictly truthful and non violent.
('73', 180, 1, 8, 353008) It should further be borne in mind that though there is a growing party among Congressmen who seeks the total abolition of States as a relic of the Middle Ages, the policy of the Congress as a whole has hitherto been and remains one of friendliness to the States in the hope that they will recognize the signs of the times and establish
('73', 180, 2, 9, 353345) 1 The communique of the Mysore Government dated May 17, stated that: (i) The Government would recognize the Mysore State Congress provided it co operated with the Government in the task of constitutional reforms and carried on its activities in a peaceful and constitutional manner.
('73', 180, 2, 10, 353628) (ii) The Government would add three new members selected by the Mysore State Congress on the committee on constitutional reforms.
('73', 180, 2, 11, 353758) (iii) On all ceremonial occasions the Mysore flag and the flag of Indian National Congress would be hoisted.
('73', 180, 2, 12, 353867) (iv) The Mysore State Congress would withdraw the civil disobedience and no tax campaigns.
('73', 180, 2, 13, 353958) (v) All the political prisoners would be released and the prohibitory orders withdrawn.
('73', 180, 3, 14, 354046) 2 The Hindu, 20 5 1938, carried the following report:  Mahatma Gandhi has instructed the Mysore State Congressmen to hoist first the Mysore State flag, that is, give precedence to the Mysore flag on all ceremonial occasions when they hoist the national flag, as a mark of their loyalty to the Ruler and in order to avoid any conflict.

('73', 182, 0, 1, 355354) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 183
('73', 182, 1, 2, 355404) 207. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('73', 182, 2, 3, 355434) BOMBAY, May 20, 1938 Sardar Prithvi Singh, who has been just taken in custody by the collector of Bombay Suburban District, is a life sentence prisoner in connection with what is known as the first Lahore Conspiracy Case of 1915. He served part of the sentence in the Andamans, and when as a result of public agitation that criminal settlement was closed, Sardar Prithvi Singh was transferred to Madras and then to Rajahmundry.
('73', 182, 2, 4, 355862) There, having grown tired of jail life, he made two attempts to abscond.
('73', 182, 2, 5, 355935) He succeeded in the second attempt in 1922, and has ever since succeeded in eluding the police.
('73', 182, 2, 6, 356031) He is a self made man.
('73', 182, 2, 7, 356054) He is a leading revolutionary and for some time has been revising his views on armed revolution, and ultimately decided in consultation with his friends to surrender himself to me and be guided by me.
('73', 182, 2, 8, 356255) After having had a full conversation with him, I decided to take charge of him, and told him that according to my view of life there could be no secrecy and voluntary surrender to authorities was in itself a service to the country.
('73', 182, 2, 9, 356487) He recognized the force of my opinion.
('73', 182, 2, 10, 356526) He came to me on the morning of the 18th, and I wrote to the District Magistrate on the 19th, informing him that Sardar Prithvi Singh had surrendered himself to me, and that I was about to put myself in communication with the Government of India with a view to securing his discharge, and that if the District Magistrate could not legally allow Sardar Prithvi Singh to remain with me, he was at liberty to take him into custody.
('73', 182, 2, 11, 356955) The District Magistrate wrote to me to say that he had no authority to leave him free.
('73', 182, 2, 12, 357042) He himself accompanied by the Superin tendent of Police arrested him today at 1 p.m.
('73', 182, 2, 13, 357127) at our residence at Juhu.
('73', 182, 3, 14, 357153) I have been given to understand that he will be treated as an A class prisoner.
('73', 182, 3, 15, 357233) I had asked Sardar Prithvi Singh to write an account of his career.
('73', 182, 3, 16, 357301) It is a thrilling romance.
('73', 182, 3, 17, 357328) So far as I can see, he has not been

('73', 185, 1, 2, 361072) 210. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('73', 185, 2, 3, 361103) SEGAON, WARDHA, May 21, 1938
('73', 185, 3, 4, 361132) DEAR FRIEND, Sardar Prithvi Singh is an old revolutionary who, belonging to a party that believed in armed revolution, was one of the odd hundred Indians, who being enraged over the treatment meted out to the passengers of the Kamagata Maru who vainly sought legal landing on the Canadian shore, took their passage to India with the avowed purpose, I believe, of causing trouble.
('73', 185, 3, 5, 361512) Sardar Prithvi Singh was tried and sentenced to 10 years imprisonment.
('73', 185, 3, 6, 361583) He was then tried in what is known as the first Lahore Conspiracy case of 1915 and was sentenced to transportation for life, and was sent to the Andamans.
('73', 185, 3, 7, 361738) When the penal settlement was broken up, he, with many other prisoners was transferred to Madras and thence to Rajahmundry.
('73', 185, 3, 8, 361862) On the way he absconded  this was in 1922and successfully evaded capture.
('73', 185, 3, 9, 361936) All these years of hiding he passed in studying the science of physical culture, and was responsible for training hundreds of youths.
('73', 185, 3, 10, 362070) But this life gave him no satisfaction.
('73', 185, 3, 11, 362110) He fell in the company of those who believe in the non violent method.
('73', 185, 3, 12, 362181) He seems to have developed faith in non violence.
('73', 185, 3, 13, 362231) On the 18th instant, he surrendered himself to me, and put himself under my guidance.
('73', 185, 3, 14, 362317) I told him that I would love to keep him with me, watch him, and engage him in constructive national activity if the Government left him free.
('73', 185, 3, 15, 362460) But I told him also that I could not keep him without informing the Government of what I was doing.
('73', 185, 3, 16, 362560) On the 19th instant, therefore, I wrote to the Collector of the Suburban District in Bombay (for I was living in Juhu) telling him that if he had no authority to let Sardar Prithvi Singh remain with me, the Sardar was ready to be arrested.
('73', 185, 3, 17, 362800) Yesterday the District Magistrate came to Juhu and arrested Sardar Prithvi Singh and lodged him in Thana Jail as an  A class prisoner.
('73', 185, 4, 18, 362935) I have given only the bare outline of Sardar Prithvi Singhs activities.
('73', 185, 4, 19, 363007) I feel that persons like Sardar Prithvi Singh should be given an opportunity of leading a useful life, instead of being kept in custody, especially when some person like me, known to the Govern ment, is willing to keep them, and hold himself responsible for their
('73', 185, 5, 20, 363271) 1 Vide Statement to the Press, 20 5 1938
('73', 186, 0, 1, 363312) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 187
('73', 186, 1, 2, 363362) peaceful conduct.
('73', 186, 1, 3, 363380) I wonder if my presentation makes any appeal to you.
('73', 186, 1, 4, 363433) If it does I would urge you to make my way smooth, and restore Sardar Prithvi Singh to me.
('73', 186, 1, 5, 363524) I may tell you that my having interested myself in the discharge of political prisoners has brought me in touch with many revolutionaries.
('73', 186, 1, 6, 363663) I entertained high hopes of their conver sion, especially if I received hearty co operation from the authorities concerned.
('73', 186, 1, 7, 363787) I do not know exactly whom or which department, or which provincial government I should properly approach.
('73', 186, 1, 8, 363894) But I felt that aswe have come to know each other, and there is a friendly contact between us, I would approach you, the fountainhead.
('73', 186, 2, 9, 364029) May I expect an early reply?
('73', 186, 2, 10, 364058) I know how busy you are, but perhaps you realize the importance of the matter and will therefore forgive me for the trouble I am giving you.
('73', 186, 2, 11, 364199) I am, Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('73', 197, 1, 2, 379479) 229. LETTER TO PYARELAL
('73', 197, 2, 3, 379503) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, May 26, 1938
('73', 197, 3, 4, 379534) PYARELAL,
('73', 197, 4, 5, 379544) There is no letter from you today.
('73', 197, 5, 6, 379579) I was perturbed by Sushilas letter of yesterday.
('73', 197, 5, 7, 379628) How can she be consoled?
('73', 197, 5, 8, 379653) She seems to be hurt all the more by my letters.
('73', 197, 5, 9, 379702) It seems that my letters, instead of healing her wounds, are keeping them raw.
('73', 197, 5, 10, 379781) Why can you not console her?
('73', 197, 5, 11, 379810) I am sure you understand my state of mind.
('73', 197, 5, 12, 379853) As for the night of the 9th I have explained that I fully agree with what Sushila says.
('73', 197, 5, 13, 379941) I have indeed said that her impression might not have been correct.
('73', 197, 5, 14, 380009) By the same token, I also believe that my impression might not have been correct either.
('73', 197, 5, 15, 380098) I am even going a step further.
('73', 197, 5, 16, 380130) Sushila is witness to her purity of mind.
('73', 197, 5, 17, 380172) I cannot even claim purity of mind.
('73', 197, 5, 18, 380208) I am willing to admit that I might have had a dirty mind.
('73', 197, 5, 19, 380266) Can it not be that my diseased mind might have aroused me and I might have seen the reflection of my own morbidity in that innocent girl and in her action?
('73', 197, 5, 20, 380422) Why should Sushila feel unhappy when all this is possible?
('73', 197, 5, 21, 380481) Why should she feel miserable on account of my morbidity, my delusion and my imperfection?
('73', 197, 5, 22, 380572) Why should Sushila go on feeling unhappy in spite of my acceptance of all these possibilities?
('73', 197, 5, 23, 380667) I am not accusing her of anything.
('73', 197, 5, 24, 380702) If you are convinced by my argument, try to pacify Sushila in your own words and in your own way.
('73', 197, 5, 25, 380800) I do not wish that she should be calm for my sake.
('73', 197, 5, 26, 380851) I can be calm only if her mind accepts that there is no reason at all to feel perturbed.
('73', 197, 5, 27, 380940) I have somehow started feeling that in all these incidents I alone have played the role of Satan and by imputing guilt to an innocent act have caused untold misery to Sushila, to Mahadev and even to you.
('73', 197, 5, 28, 381144) Thus, while on the one hand I am beginning to feel calm under the intoxication of work, on the other hand, whenever there is free time, I keep analysing the incidents of the day of the 14th of April and the night of the 9th.
('73', 197, 5, 29, 381369) I have found no clue so far.
('73', 197, 5, 30, 381398) I do not know if I shallfind it at all.
('73', 197, 5, 31, 381438) As Rajkumari says my faith in God is being tested.
('73', 197, 5, 32, 381489) If Sushila cannot be pacified at all, I can see that it will be a terrible thing for me.
('73', 197, 5, 33, 381578) But if she cannot be pacified what will you
('73', 198, 0, 1, 381622) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 199
('73', 198, 1, 2, 381672) What will poor Sushila do?
('73', 198, 1, 3, 381699) As for me, I shall reap what I have sown.
('73', 198, 2, 4, 381741) Blessings from
('73', 198, 3, 5, 381756) BAPU [PS.] You may use this if you really think it is proper.
('73', 198, 3, 6, 381818) If I cannot reduce Sushilas misery, let me at least not add to it?

('73', 199, 1, 2, 383174) 232. LETTER TO KHWAJA NAZIMUDDIN
('73', 199, 2, 3, 383207) MAGANWADI, WARDHA, May 27, 1938
('73', 199, 3, 4, 383239) DEAR KHWAJA SAHEB, I thank you for your exhaustive reply of the 24th instant.
('73', 199, 4, 5, 383317) Evidently my position has been misunderstood.
('73', 199, 4, 6, 383363) I do not wish to suggest that my judgment or that of the Congress is to be made sub servient to the opinion of the convicts, but before I could come to a final judgment, it would be necessary for me in the interest of the common cause itself to sound the prisoners mind.
('73', 199, 4, 7, 383634) If I had not, subject to confirmation after an examination of details, come to the preliminary conclusion that the solution suggested by the Bengal Government might be worthy of acceptance, I could not have thought of any interview with the prisoners.
('73', 199, 4, 8, 383886) My idea is, after deeper exami nation of the solution, to convince the prisoners of the desira bility of its acceptance.
('73', 199, 4, 9, 384007) Before, therefore, I can finally accept the solution suggested, I hold it to be necessary to take the prisoners into confi dence.
('73', 199, 4, 10, 384137) I hope that you will agree with this opinion, for the sake, as I have already said, of the common purpose, viz., to ensure peace so far as this ticklish question of prisoners release is concerned.
('73', 199, 4, 11, 384334) I take it that the question of detenus has been satisfactorily settled.
('73', 199, 4, 12, 384406) I would appreciate a line as to how the matter stands.
('73', 199, 5, 13, 384461) yours sincerely,
('73', 199, 6, 14, 384478) M. K. GANDHI The Hindustan Times, 4 10 1938; also C. W. 9925
('73', 199, 7, 15, 384539) 1 The addressee in his letter had said that Gandhijis suggestion that the proposals for release of political prisoners and detenus should first be discussed with the convicts would promote misunderstanding both among the prisoners and the public.
