('73', 201, 8, 21, 386773) 237. FOREWORD TO  BASIC NATIONAL EDUCATION
('73', 201, 9, 22, 386816) SEGAON, WARDHA, May 28, 1938 The fact that the first one thousand copies of this pamphlet have been sold out shows that what Dr. Zakir Husain and his committee have called Basic National Education is exciting fair interest in India and outside.
('73', 201, 9, 23, 387061) A more correct though much less attractive description would be Rural National Education through village handicrafts.
('73', 201, 9, 24, 387179) Rural excludes the so called higher or English education.National at present connotes truth and non violence.
('73', 201, 9, 25, 387289) And through village handicrafts means that the framers of the scheme expect the teachers to educate village children in their villages so as to draw out all their faculties through some selected village handicrafts in an atmosphere free from superimposed restrictions and interference.
('73', 201, 9, 26, 387575) Thus consi dered, the scheme is a revolution in the education of village children.
('73', 201, 9, 27, 387658) It is in no sense an importation from the West.
('73', 201, 9, 28, 387706) If the reader bears this
('73', 201, 10, 29, 387731) 1 This is written on the reverse of the preceding item.
('73', 201, 10, 30, 387787) 2 The letter is incomplete.
('73', 202, 0, 1, 387815) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 203
('73', 202, 1, 2, 387865) fact in mind he will be better able to follow the scheme to the prepa ration of which some of the best educationists have given their un divided attention.
('73', 202, 1, 3, 388021) M. K. GANDHI
('73', 202, 2, 4, 388034) Basic National Education

('73', 211, 3, 4, 403201) KRISHNACHANDRA, Your questions are very pertinent.
('73', 211, 3, 5, 403252) Our duty, as I understand it, is not to spend public funds and not to refuse the money which our relatives are willing to give us.
('73', 211, 3, 6, 403383) However, if they give unwillingly and because they cannot help it, that money should be refused.
('73', 211, 3, 7, 403480) You can judge for yourself in the present situation.
('73', 211, 3, 8, 403533) If you consider it your duty not to take anything from there, then your expenses on food, dress, some little postage, etc., should be met from here.
('73', 211, 3, 9, 403682) Now about books.
('73', 211, 3, 10, 403699) If it is a matter of a rupee or two, I do not find any harm in taking that money from here.
('73', 211, 3, 11, 403791) It would be desirable to consult me on such occasions.
('73', 211, 3, 12, 403846) I hope everything is clear now.

('73', 213, 1, 2, 405741) 258. NOTE TO ASHRAM INMATES
('73', 213, 2, 3, 405769) Not Revised June 2, 1938 I have been distressed since the 7th of April.
('73', 213, 2, 4, 405841) I had a dirty dream that night.
('73', 213, 2, 5, 405873) I did wake up before the crisis but I felt ashamed.
('73', 213, 2, 6, 405925) After the experience I hardly slept that night.
('73', 213, 2, 7, 405973) I was restless.
('73', 213, 2, 8, 405989) I walked about on the terrace and calmed myself a little.
('73', 213, 2, 9, 406047) I felt that I was not fit to accept service from Sushila and Prabhavati who slept close to my bed.
('73', 213, 2, 10, 406146) After the prayer, I first recounted to them what I had been through and then told them that I would not be taking service from them.
('73', 213, 2, 11, 406279) But both took this decision very badly.
('73', 213, 2, 12, 406319) Within twelve hours I reviewed my decision and continued to take service from them.
('73', 213, 2, 13, 406403) But my distress did not cease.
('73', 213, 2, 14, 406434) On the 14th I had another type of experience which increased my shame and added to my anguish.
('73', 213, 2, 15, 406529) I had not made any change in my outward behaviour.
('73', 213, 2, 16, 406580) But consciously or unconsciously, my mind was preparing itself.
('73', 213, 2, 17, 406644) While I was caught in that whirlpool, I had to meet Mr. Jinnah.
('73', 213, 2, 18, 406708) I thought it was my duty to write something for the occasion.
('73', 213, 2, 19, 406770) I wrote something and indicated my sense of shame in it.
('73', 213, 3, 20, 406827) I had lost my self confidence.
('73', 213, 3, 21, 406858) I had shamed my brahmacharya.
('73', 213, 3, 22, 406888) After a great deal of thought I have come to this decision.
('73', 213, 3, 23, 406948) For the time being, and so long as I am able to bear such physical contact with other people, I should not take any service from women which involves physical contact, unless it is absolutely unavoidable.
('73', 213, 3, 24, 407153) It is obvious that I must not touch them in jest or in affection.
('73', 213, 3, 25, 407219) This change is very important to me.
('73', 213, 3, 26, 407256) My whole life has been shaped in the belief that there is nothing wrong about innocent physical touch of women.
('73', 213, 3, 27, 407368) Before I took the vow of brahmacharya and after, I touched nume rous woman in a light hearted way or in affection, I have not expe rienced any adverse effect thereby and have not known any woman who may have been sensually aroused.
('73', 213, 3, 28, 407600) But a doubt arose after my experience of the 7th April.
('73', 213, 3, 29, 407656) Why have I not become free from passion in spite of my constant effortstowards brahmacharya?
('73', 213, 3, 30, 407749) Why have my thoughts and my mind not become purer and purer?
('73', 213, 3, 31, 407810) I can say that I have not felt myself free from carnal desire in India as much as I did in South Africa.
('73', 213, 3, 32, 407915) Could the contact with women have obstructed my path in some subtle way?
('73', 213, 3, 33, 407988) Who can answer that question?
('73', 213, 3, 34, 408018) The only solution is that unless God Himself answers it, I should try to shun all physical touch and
('73', 213, 4, 35, 408119) 1 Vide also  Letter to E. Raghavendra Rao 10 6 1938
('73', 214, 0, 1, 408171) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 215
('73', 214, 1, 2, 408221) understand my own mind and conquer it.
('73', 214, 1, 3, 408260) Yesterday it became clear to me as day that it was very wrong of me to prevent my colleagues from taking the liberties which I myself have taken.
('73', 214, 1, 4, 408406) I still cannot understand how I allowed it to happen for so many years.
('73', 214, 1, 5, 408478) It seems to me that behind that restriction was my pride.
('73', 214, 1, 6, 408536) It was a failing.
('73', 214, 1, 7, 408554) I should not have undertaken the experiment if it was so terrible.
('73', 214, 1, 8, 408621) If it was worth undertaking, I should have encouraged all my colleagues to pursue it on my condition.
('73', 214, 1, 9, 408723) My experiment was a transgression of the limits prescribed by brahmacharya.
('73', 214, 1, 10, 408799) Only a sage like Shukadevji who was always pure in thought, speech and action would be entitled to exercise such freedom.
('73', 214, 1, 11, 408921) Such thinking led me to the above decision yesterday.
('73', 214, 1, 12, 408975) I feel that the bitter experiences of Dahyabhai and others at Sabarmati had my experiment at their root.
('73', 214, 1, 13, 409080) Who can say in how many cases my behaviour has led to wrong actions?
('73', 214, 1, 14, 409149) Only he who can observe complete brahmacharya can give complete training in non violence.
('73', 214, 1, 15, 409239) I am the self appointed leader of the path of non violence!
('73', 214, 1, 16, 409299) What wonder if my non violence is weak to the extent that I cannot pass the above test?
('73', 214, 1, 17, 409387) Even then, I shall continue my experiment in non violence so long as I feel convinced that even my imperfect brahmacharya has lent considerable support to non violence.
('73', 214, 1, 18, 409556) Otherwise too my behaviour would remain the same at least for the present.
('73', 214, 1, 19, 409631) Who can say where the future will lead me?
('73', 214, 1, 20, 409674) My strongest desire is to submit lovingly to God and let myself be driven whither He wills.
('73', 214, 1, 21, 409766) It was my clear duty to convey this much to my co workers.
('73', 214, 1, 22, 409825) I assume that any co worker who wishes will let me know his reactions and point out any error he may find in my thinking.

('73', 228, 1, 2, 432804) 278. TO SEGAON WORKERS
('73', 228, 2, 3, 432827) June 6, 1938 The manager should copy out whatever I write herein and read it out to the others.
('73', 228, 2, 4, 432923) This note book should always be kept in front of me.
('73', 228, 2, 5, 432976) * * * I have been asked if there are any rules here about anything.
('73', 228, 2, 6, 433044) There are.
('73', 228, 2, 7, 433055) For when winding up Sabarmati Ashram I had said that we would from then on be a mobile Ashram and carry with us wherever we went Ashram life and Ashram rules.
('73', 228, 2, 8, 433214) Prayers, etc., thus stay as before as also the hour of rising.
('73', 228, 2, 9, 433277) We may certainly introduce changes, excepting in principles, according as circumstances may warrant, as has been done here.
('73', 228, 2, 10, 433401) We deliberately employ Harijan servants, because we want to serve the Harijans.
('73', 228, 2, 11, 433481) But though we employ them as servants we have to treat them as our brothers.
('73', 228, 2, 12, 433558) * * * * Therefore we must do even menial work that we can do ourselves.
('73', 228, 2, 13, 433630) If we cannot do some particular work ourselves we may have it done by others.
('73', 228, 2, 14, 433708) Only work that even others cannot do may we ask Harijans to do.
('73', 228, 3, 15, 433772) From Hindi: C. W. 4674; also G. N. 6866.
('73', 228, 4, 16, 433813) 279. LETTER TO ATULANAND CHAKRABARTY

('73', 228, 6, 18, 433879) MY DEAR ATULANAND, I have not been able to overtake your letter of 20th May earlier.

('73', 231, 2, 5, 438419) 283. TALKS ON VOCATIONAL EDUCATION 1
('73', 231, 3, 6, 438456) [Before June 11, 1938] I had long been impressed with the necessity for a new departure as I knew the failure modern education had been through the numerous students who came to see me on my return from South Africa.
('73', 231, 3, 7, 438673) So I started with the introduction of training in handicrafts in the Ashram school.
('73', 231, 3, 8, 438757) In fact an extra emphasis was placed on manual training, with the result that the children soon got tired of the manual training and thought that they had been deprived of literary training.
('73', 231, 3, 9, 438948) There they were wrong, for even the little that they gained was more than children ordinarily get in the orthodox schools.
('73', 231, 3, 10, 439071) But that set me thinking, and I came to the conclusion that not vocation cum literary training, but literary training through vocational training was the thing.
('73', 231, 3, 11, 439232) Then vocational training would cease to be a drudgery and literary training would have a new content and new usefulness.
('73', 231, 3, 12, 439353) The acceptance of office by the Congress prompted me to place the thought before the nation, and I am glad that it was welcomed in many quarters.
('73', 231, 3, 13, 439499) English we decided to taboo, because we knew that most of the time of the children was taken up with memorizing English words and phrases, and even then they could not put in their own language what they had learnt, and could not properly follow what the teacher taught them.
('73', 231, 3, 14, 439775) On the other hand they forgot their own language by sheer neglect.
('73', 231, 3, 15, 439842) Education through vocational training seemed to be the only way to avoid both these evils.
('73', 231, 3, 16, 439933) I should make a start on the first day with finding out the calibre of the boyswhether they know any reading and writing, any geography, and then start with trying to add to their equipment through the introduction of the takli.
('73', 231, 3, 17, 440162) Now you might well ask me why I picked up the takli out of the many other existing handicrafts.
('73', 231, 3, 18, 440258) Because takli was one of the first crafts that we found out and which has subsisted through the ages.In the earliest ages all our cloth used to be made of takli yarn.
('73', 231, 4, 19, 440425) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desais Education through VocationA synthesis, Desai does not say when or where the talks were delivered
('73', 232, 0, 1, 440554) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 233
('73', 232, 1, 2, 440604) spinning wheel came later, and [as] the finest counts could not be produced on the spinning wheel, one had to go back to the takli.
('73', 232, 1, 3, 440736) In devising the takli mans inventive genius reached a height that had not been reached before.
('73', 232, 1, 4, 440831) The cunning of the fingers was put to the best possible use.
('73', 232, 1, 5, 440892) But as the takli was confined to the artisans who were never educated, it fell into disuse.
('73', 232, 1, 6, 440984) If we want to revive it today in all its glory, if we are to revive and reconstruct the village life, we must begin the education of children with the takli.
('73', 232, 1, 7, 441142) My next lesson would therefore be to teach the boys the place the takli used to occupy in our daily life.
('73', 232, 1, 8, 441248) Next I would take them into a little history and teach them how it declined.
('73', 232, 1, 9, 441325) Then would follow a brief course in Indian history, starting from the East Indian Company, or even earlier from the Muslim period, giving them a detailed account of the exploitation that was the stock in trade of the East India company, how by a systematic process our main handicraft was strangled and ultimately killed.
('73', 232, 1, 10, 441647) Next would follow a brief course in mechanicsconstruction of the takli.
('73', 232, 1, 11, 441719) It must have originally consisted of a small ball of clay or even wet flour dried on to a bamboo splinter running through its centre.
('73', 232, 1, 12, 441853) This has still survived in some parts of Bihar and Bengal.
('73', 232, 1, 13, 441912) Then a brick disc took the place of the clay ball and then in our times iron or steel and brass have taken the place of the brick disc and a steel wire the place of the splinter.
('73', 232, 1, 14, 442091) Even here one might expatiate with profit on the size of the disc and the wire, why it is of a particular size and why not more or less.
('73', 232, 1, 15, 442228) Next would follow a few lectures on cotton, its habitat, its varieties, the countries and the provinces of India where it is at present grown and so on.
('73', 232, 1, 16, 442381) Again some knowledge about its cultivation, the soil best suited for it, and so on.
('73', 232, 1, 17, 442465) That would make us launch into a little agriculture.
('73', 232, 1, 18, 442518) You will see that this takes a fund of assimilated knowledge on the part of the teacher before he can impart it to his pupils.
('73', 232, 1, 19, 442645) The whole of elementary arithmetic can be taught through the counting of yards of spinning, finding out the count of yarn, making up of hanks, getting it ready for the weaver, the number of cross threads in the warp to be put in for particular textures of cloth and so on.
('73', 232, 1, 20, 442918) Every process from the growing of cotton to the manufacture of the finished productcotton picking, ginning.
('73', 232, 1, 21, 443026) carding, spinning, sizing, weavingall would have their mechanics and history and mathematics correlated to them.
('73', 232, 1, 22, 443139) The principle idea is to impart the whole education of the body and the mind and the soul through the handicraft that is taught to thechildren.
('73', 232, 1, 23, 443283) You have to draw out all that is in the child through teaching all the processes of the handicraft, and all your lessons in history, geography, arithmetic will be related to the craft.
('73', 233, 0, 1, 443468) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 233, 1, 2, 443510) If such education is given, the direct result will be that it will be self supporting.
('73', 233, 1, 3, 443597) But the test of success is not its self supporting character, but that the whole man has been drawn out through the teaching of the handicraft in a scientific manner.
('73', 233, 1, 4, 443764) In fact I would reject a teacher who would promise to make it self supporting under any circumstances.
('73', 233, 1, 5, 443867) The self supporting part will be the logical corollary of the fact that the pupil has learnt the use of every one of his faculties.
('73', 233, 1, 6, 443999) If a boy who works at a handicraft for three hours a day will surely earn his keep, how much more a boy who adds to the work a development of his mind and soul !
('73', 233, 1, 7, 444161) Harijan, 11 6 1938

('73', 234, 3, 10, 446241) I gave up the practice only for the sake of public good.
('73', 234, 3, 11, 446298) My heart never took it to mean that I would never place my hand on the shoulder of any girl whatsoever.
('73', 234, 3, 12, 446402) I have no recollection of the particular girl with whom the practice was resumed in Segaon.
('73', 234, 3, 13, 446494) But I do recollect that I fully remembered my vow of 1935 when I placed my hand on her shoulder.
('73', 234, 3, 14, 446591) Possibly I could not resist her request, or may be I needed her support.
('73', 234, 3, 15, 446664) I cannot of course say that the support became necessary because of my weak state for had that been the case I could have had the support of some man so as to keep the vow inviolate.
('73', 234, 3, 16, 446847) But my vow never had such a wide meaning, at least for me.
('73', 234, 3, 17, 446906) From the very begining I have regarded Sushilabehn in the same way as Ba, as an exception.

('73', 234, 3, 19, 447045) I would like to give up physical contact even with these two if it were possible, but I have no desire to do so at the cost of the deep hurt which I would be causing them while my heart feels no sin in the contact of these two.

('73', 234, 3, 23, 447506) Sushila has observed brahmacharya since childhood but her observance does not include the exclusion of innocent contact with men.
('73', 234, 3, 24, 447636) Pyarelal too is a brahmachari and one of the reasons for his joining me is that I do not advocate total avoidance of innocent contact between the two sexes and I have had a certain measure of success in this.
('73', 234, 3, 25, 447845) Once I intended to give up all personal services from Sushila but within twelve hours my soft heartedness had put an end to the intention.
('73', 234, 3, 26, 447984) I could not bear the tears of Sushila and the fainting away of Prabhavati.
('73', 234, 3, 27, 448059) I did not even want to.

('73', 237, 4, 18, 453098) 289. LETTER TO PRITHVISINGH MAGANWADI, WARDHA, C. P., June 13, 1938
('73', 237, 5, 19, 453166) DEAR PRITHVISINGH, I was delighted to have your letter and am happy to learn that you are quite comfortable there.
('73', 237, 5, 20, 453281) You have rightly asked me how a prisoner wishing to observe truth and non violence should behave in prison.
('73', 237, 5, 21, 453389) Your present beha viour is quite commendable, but let me put down here a few prin ciples: (1) A votary of truth and non violence may have nothing secret.
('73', 237, 5, 22, 453543) (2) He will observe all the jail regulations cheerfully.
('73', 237, 5, 23, 453600) (3) He may invite the attention of the authorities to such rules as may appear to him to be improper or hard.
('73', 237, 5, 24, 453710) (4) He has a right, and it may be even his duty, to disobey such rules as may offend his self respect.
('73', 237, 5, 25, 453813) But it is his duty first to make a representation to the authorities in respect of these rules, and he may

('73', 240, 1, 2, 457509) 293. DISCUSSION WITH KALIDAS NAG 1
('73', 240, 2, 3, 457544) [Before June 18, 1938]
('73', 240, 3, 4, 457567) KALIDAS NAG: Wherever I have been .
('73', 240, 3, 5, 457603) non violence is the question of questions.
('73', 240, 3, 6, 457646) But it is just a question or a matter of doubt .
('73', 240, 3, 7, 457695) has not Buddhism been responsible for widespread emasculation?
('73', 240, 3, 8, 457758) And whatever may be the potency of non violence, is it not impossible as a weapon of defence?
('73', 240, 3, 9, 457852) GANDHI: Do you want me to answer these questions or did you reply to them?
('73', 240, 4, 10, 457927) K.N. I have been replying to them after my own historical fashion, but I want you to answer them, for yours will be authentic answers.
('73', 240, 4, 11, 458062) G. Well, the answer is being given in India in actual practice.
('73', 240, 4, 12, 458126) It is no use citing the example of China and Japan.
('73', 240, 4, 13, 458178) India is the only place where if an answer must come can come.
('73', 240, 4, 14, 458241) Experience here is quite encouraging.
('73', 240, 4, 15, 458279) Intellectually of course even many people in the West have come to recognize the futility of violence and begun to ask if non violence may not after all be worth a trial.
('73', 240, 4, 16, 458450) Dr. Stanley Jones has sent me a copy of his recent article, Gandhian Solution of the Chinese Troubleand he has seriously discussed various forms of non co operation that may be successfully adopted.
('73', 240, 4, 17, 458649) There was time when Dr. Jones had not much belief in non co operation, but he now seriously suggests it as a non violent solution, and has pressed me to go to Europe to preach peace.
('73', 240, 4, 18, 458832) But so long as my mission in India remains unfulfilled, my visit to the West on a peace mission must be a vain effort.
('73', 240, 4, 19, 458951) Whilst it is true that non violence has made much head way in India, it is not of much value to an outsider and a critic at that.
('73', 240, 5, 20, 459081) K. N. What you say, Mahatmaji, is quite correct, viz., that the answer is being given, and if it is really given on such a scale as the size of our country it will be most effective.
('73', 240, 5, 21, 459264) For their acceptanceeven intellectualof non violence and non co operation is in a spirit of condescension.
('73', 240, 5, 22, 459371) G. It is impossible that a thing essentially of the soul can ever be imparted through the intellect.
('73', 240, 5, 23, 459472) It is just like trying to impart faith in God through the intellect.
('73', 240, 5, 24, 459541) It cannot be as it is essentially a matter of the heart.
('73', 240, 5, 25, 459598) Faith can be turned into knowledge by experience, and it can come only through the heart and not the intellect.
('73', 240, 5, 26, 459710) The intellect, if anything, acts as a barrier in matters of faith.
('73', 240, 5, 27, 459777) Harijan, 18 6 1938
('73', 240, 6, 28, 459796) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desais Weekly Letter.
('73', 240, 6, 29, 459843) Kalidas Nag had visited many foreign countries on cultural missions.
('73', 240, 6, 30, 459912) This time he was going to Australia.
('73', 240, 6, 31, 459949) On his way to Calcutta to board a ship, he stopped at Wardha to meet Gandhiji.
('73', 241, 0, 1, 460028) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 241, 1, 2, 460070) 294. A CRITICISM
('73', 241, 2, 3, 460087) A C. P. correspondent sends me a bitter letter criticizing the C. P. Ministry.
('73', 241, 2, 4, 460166) 1 I condense it below toning down the bitterest part: I have been wanting to write to you for some time but did not do so advisedly.
('73', 241, 2, 5, 460299) I do so now as one interested in the good government of my province which, I take it, is also your adopted home for the rest of your life.
('73', 241, 2, 6, 460438) We were led to believe that government by the representatives of the Congress would be so good as to escape calumny and be able to rule for all time merely by reason and by moral influence.
('73', 241, 2, 7, 460628) But the main purpose of the Congress Ministry appears to us to be.
('73', 241, 2, 8, 460695) (a) to worship your idol in public and break it in secret; (b)to worship the symbols of Imperialism in secret and denounce them in public; (c) to play the malefactor towards their opponents whom they cannot conquer by truthful and legitimate methods; (d) to carry on a brisk traffic in legislation and public offices.
('73', 241, 2, 9, 461013) The government of a people cannot be run, as the Congress Ministers in the C. P. seem to imagine, by the common argument of promised boons and by corrupting the electorate with hope.
('73', 241, 2, 10, 461196) During the past ten months your Ministers have left no stone unturned to shake the moral foundation of good government of this province.
('73', 241, 2, 11, 461333) The Ministry and its component parts are honey combed with intrigues and corruption.
('73', 241, 2, 12, 461418) To sum up my conclusion, which I wish to convey to you, is that the Congress Party might have been deemed capable of governing had they never assumed power and responsi bility.
('73', 241, 2, 13, 461595) Next to assumption of power is the responsibility of relinquishing it.
('73', 241, 2, 14, 461666) It is strange that your soul should not revolt against such a predatory Ministry for the creation of which the moral responsibility is entirely yours.
('73', 241, 2, 15, 461817) The Working Committee referred all the complaints against the Ministry to the Parliamentary Board which carried on an enquiry on the spot.
('73', 241, 2, 16, 461956) Its report 2 is public property.
('73', 241, 2, 17, 461989) The Congress is a wholly
('73', 241, 3, 18, 462014) 1 Vide Letter to E. Raghavendra Rao, 2 6 1938
('73', 241, 4, 19, 462060) 2 The Parliamentary Board which held a joint meeting with the C. P. Congress Legislature Party and the three Provincial Congress Committee presidents from the C. P. examined the various charges against the C. P. Ministry, including some of corruption.
('73', 241, 4, 20, 462312) In a statement Vallabhbhai Patel and Abul Kalam Azad declared that while the Committee found no evidence to substantiate the charges of corruption it found certain complaints not without justification.
('73', 241, 4, 21, 462514) For instance, raising from Rs. 15,000 to 1 lakh the limit of the Debt Conciliation Act and appointing underserving persons to professorships in the University.
('73', 241, 4, 22, 462674) They were glad to note among those concerned a readiness to admit mistakes and make amends and hoped that under promise of prompt rectification all public criticism will cease.
('73', 242, 0, 1, 462851) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 243
('73', 242, 1, 2, 462901) democratic organization with the widest possible franchise.
('73', 242, 1, 3, 462961) The Working Committee is its mouthpiece and has to work within the limits prescribed for it by the Congress Constitution.
('73', 242, 1, 4, 463083) It was open to the C. P. Congress representatives to demand resignation from the Ministers, but they did not.
('73', 242, 1, 5, 463193) On the contrary they wanted the present Ministers to compose their difference and carry on the Government.
('73', 242, 1, 6, 463300) The Parliamentary Board could not disregard the wishes of the representatives.
('73', 242, 1, 7, 463379) It had no power to do so.
('73', 242, 1, 8, 463405) But it did all it could to rid the Ministry of whatever short comings they had discovered.
('73', 242, 1, 9, 463496) The Ministers, it must be admitted, offered no opposition to whatever the Board wanted to do.
('73', 242, 1, 10, 463590) It now remains to be seen how the new arrangement works.
('73', 242, 1, 11, 463647) The point, however, that I wish to make is that the Working Committee does not hush up any evil that is found in the Congress organization.
('73', 242, 1, 12, 463787) It is not afraid to impose discipline which is readily obeyed in most cases.
('73', 242, 1, 13, 463864) I wholly endorse the correspondents proposition that the Congress can only rule by reason and moral influence.
('73', 242, 1, 14, 463975) He and critics like him may rest assured that the Congress will die a natural and deserved death if and when it substitutes reason and moral influence by goondaism.
('73', 242, 1, 15, 464140) One more point.
('73', 242, 1, 16, 464156) The Congress is composed of ordinary mortals.
('73', 242, 1, 17, 464202) They share the virtues and vices of the nation which they seek to represent.
('73', 242, 1, 18, 464279) But after all is said and done, it will not be denied that it is the oldest political organization in the country, it is the most representative, it has drawn to itself the best talent in the country, it has the highest amount of sacrifice to its credit.
('73', 242, 1, 19, 464534) Above all it is the one organization that has offered the greatest resistance to foreign rule and exploitation.
('73', 242, 1, 20, 464646) Whilst all honest criticism is to be welcomed, I would like to remind the correspondent and other critics that it is open to them to join the Congress and criticize it from within and to try to rid it of all the removable limitations they may discover in it.
('73', 242, 1, 21, 464905) Harijan, 18 6 1938
('73', 242, 2, 22, 464924) 295. QUALIFICATIONS OF A PEACE BRIGADE
('73', 242, 3, 23, 464963) Some time ago I suggested 1 the formation of a Peace Brigade whose members would risk their lives in dealing with riots, especially communal.
('73', 242, 3, 24, 465105) The idea was that this Brigade should substitute the police
('73', 242, 4, 25, 465165) 1 Vide, Our Failure
('73', 243, 0, 1, 465185) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 243, 1, 2, 465227) and even the military.
('73', 243, 1, 3, 465250) This reads ambitious.
('73', 243, 1, 4, 465272) The achievement may prove impossible.
('73', 243, 1, 5, 465310) Yet, if the Congress is to succeed in its non violent struggle, it must develop the power to deal peacefully with such situations.
('73', 243, 1, 6, 465441) Communal riots are engineered by politically minded men.
('73', 243, 1, 7, 465498) Many of those who take part in them are under the influence of the latter.
('73', 243, 1, 8, 465573) Surely it should not be beyond the wit of Congressmen to devise a method or methods of avoiding ugly communal situations by peaceful means.
('73', 243, 1, 9, 465713) I say this irrespective of whether there is or there is not a communal pact.
('73', 243, 1, 10, 465790) It cannot be that any party seeks to force a pact by violent means.
('73', 243, 1, 11, 465858) Even if such a pact were a possibility, it would not be worth the paper on which it might be written.
('73', 243, 1, 12, 465960) For behind such a pact there will be no common understanding.
('73', 243, 1, 13, 466022) What is more, even after a pact is arrived at, it would be too much to expect that there would never be any communal riots.
('73', 243, 1, 14, 466146) Let us therefore see what qualifications a member of the contemplated Peace Brigade should possess.
('73', 243, 1, 15, 466246) (1) He or she must have a living faith in non violence.
('73', 243, 1, 16, 466302) This is impossible without a living faith in God.
('73', 243, 1, 17, 466352) A non violent man can do nothing save by the power and grace of God.
('73', 243, 1, 18, 466421) Without it he wont have the courage to die without anger, without fear and without retaliation.
('73', 243, 1, 19, 466517) Such courage comes from the belief that God sits in the hearts of all and that there should be no fear in the presence of God.
('73', 243, 1, 20, 466644) The knowledge of the omnipresence of God also means respect for the lives of even those who may be called opponents or goondas.
('73', 243, 1, 21, 466772) This contemplated intervention is a process of stilling the fury of man when the brute in him gets the mastery over him.
('73', 243, 1, 22, 466893) (2) This messenger of peace must have equal regard for all the principal religions of the earth.
('73', 243, 1, 23, 466990) Thus, if he is a Hindu, he will respect the other faiths current in India.
('73', 243, 1, 24, 467065) He must therefore possess a knowledge of the general principles of the different faiths professed in the country.
('73', 243, 1, 25, 467179) (3) Generally speaking this work of peace can only be done by local men in their own localities.
('73', 243, 1, 26, 467276) (4) The work can be done singly or in groups.
('73', 243, 1, 27, 467322) Therefore no one need wait for companions.
('73', 243, 1, 28, 467365) Nevertheless one would naturally seek companions in ones own locality and form a local brigade.
('73', 243, 1, 29, 467461) (5) This messenger of peace will cultivate through personal service contacts with the people in his locality or chosen circle, so that when he appears to deal with ugly situations, he does not descend upon the members of a riotous assembly as an utter stranger liable to be looked upon as a suspect or an unwelcome visitor.
('73', 244, 0, 1, 467785) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 245
('73', 244, 1, 2, 467835) (6) Needless to say, a peace bringer must have a character beyond reproach and must be known for his strict impartiality.
('73', 244, 1, 3, 467957) (7) Generally there are previous warnings of coming storms.
('73', 244, 1, 4, 468017) If these are known, the Peace Brigade will not wait till the conflagration breaks out but will try to handle the situation in anticipation.
('73', 244, 1, 5, 468157) (8) Whilst, if the movement spreads, it might be well if there are some whole time workers, it is not absolutely necessary that there should be.
('73', 244, 1, 6, 468302) The idea is to have as many good and true men and women as possible.
('73', 244, 1, 7, 468371) These can be had only if volunteers are drawn from those who are engaged in various walks of life but have leisure enough to cultivate friendly relations with the people living in their circle and otherwise possess the qualifications required of a member of the Peace Brigade.
('73', 244, 1, 8, 468648) (9) There should be a distinctive dress worn by the members of the contemplated Brigade so that in course of time they will be recognized without the slightest difficulty.
('73', 244, 1, 9, 468820) These are but general suggestions.
('73', 244, 1, 10, 468855) Each centre can work out its own constitution on the basis here suggested.
('73', 244, 1, 11, 468930) Lest false hopes may be raised, I must warn workers against entertaining the hope that I can play any active part in the formation of Peace Brigades.
('73', 244, 1, 12, 469080) I have not the health, energy or time for it.
('73', 244, 1, 13, 469126) I find it hard enough to cope with the tasks I dare not shirk.
('73', 244, 1, 14, 469189) I can only guide and make suggestions through corrspondence or these columns.
('73', 244, 1, 15, 469267) Therefore let those who appreciate the idea and feel they have the ability, take the initiative themselves.
('73', 244, 1, 16, 469375) I know that the proposed Brigade has great possibilities and that the idea behind it is quite capable of being worked out in practice.
('73', 244, 1, 17, 469510) Harijan, 18 6 1938

('73', 250, 1, 2, 477940) 305. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('73', 250, 2, 3, 477972) SEGAON, WARDHA, June 22, 1938
('73', 250, 3, 4, 478002) CHHAGANLAL, I got your letter.
('73', 250, 3, 5, 478033) Replies tend to get delayed.
('73', 250, 3, 6, 478062) The reasons which you have mentioned also may be responsible for the scene on the 14th.
('73', 250, 3, 7, 478150) 1 But a great experiment can be carried out only by enlisting the support of those who are most likely to respond, and only thus can one discover truth.
('73', 250, 3, 8, 478303) I can now clearly see that it was a fundamental error on my part to have deliberately excluded other co workers from my experiment.
('73', 250, 3, 9, 478435) I should have tried to get a class of workers who would be able to carry on the experiment in accordance with conditions laid down by me.
('73', 250, 3, 10, 478573) My taking it upon myself, instead of finding such a class of workers, was the result of abysmal ignorance and certainly of conceit, too.
('73', 250, 3, 11, 478710) In consequence, while I would not tole rate even the most trivial departure from the conditions by my co workers.

('73', 250, 3, 13, 478870) This was the limit of intolerance.
('73', 250, 3, 14, 478905) The small mindedness implied in this attitude fills me with disgust for myself; but on the other hand the generosity dis played by all of you co workers delights me with its sweet fragrance.
('73', 250, 3, 15, 479096) This, in brief, is the truth.
('73', 250, 3, 16, 479126) The new experiment 2 started on the 2nd.
('73', 250, 3, 17, 479167) But it is only the beginning as yet.
('73', 250, 3, 18, 479204) The ship has set sail and is slowly leaving port.
('73', 250, 3, 19, 479254) It is not easy for one who has been used to sailing in one kind of weather continuously for 40 years to try to sail in weather of another kind.
('73', 250, 3, 20, 479398) Hence the slowness of speed.

('73', 251, 10, 18, 480901) 307. DISCUSSION WITH STUDENTS 2
('73', 251, 11, 19, 480933) [Before June 25, 1938]
('73', 251, 12, 20, 480956) Gandhiji explained to them how almost since the beginning of his public life in South Africa he had been closely associated with labour.
('73', 251, 12, 21, 481093) When he settled down to practise at the bar in South Africa he decided to give the whole of his spare time to work for the Indian settlers there, and the first man who came to him for assistance was an indentured labourer.
('73', 251, 12, 22, 481316) This case at once put him in touch with labour.
('73', 251, 12, 23, 481364) The labourers brought to him their troubles with their employers and also their personal and domestic worries, and that gave him a glimpse into their lives as nothing else could have done.
('73', 251, 12, 24, 481553) Non violence was the first thing he placed before them, and non 
('73', 251, 13, 25, 481618) 1 These two sentences are from the printed source.
('73', 251, 13, 26, 481669) 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desais Notes.
('73', 251, 13, 27, 481708) A group of university graduates after undergoing training in the organization of labour had come to see Gandhiji.
('73', 252, 0, 1, 481822) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 253
('73', 252, 1, 2, 481872) violence was the only thing that they had been pledged to observe when, at a critical stage in the satyagraha campaign, nearly 60,000 labourers downed their tools and faced imprisonment.
('73', 252, 1, 3, 482059) They went through untold hardships, suffering, starvation, and some even died, but they adhered to non violence until the end.
('73', 252, 1, 4, 482186) Their condition was particularly difficult and in a sense worse than the workers here.
('73', 252, 1, 5, 482273) They were not free, but indentured, and they had to fight not only for justice from their employers but for the abolition of the opprobrious 3 tax which threatened them with extinction.
('73', 252, 1, 6, 482459) But non violence helped them to pull through.
('73', 252, 1, 7, 482505) His work in Champaran and Ahmedabad was recent history.
('73', 252, 1, 8, 482561) Regarding Champaran he said that the condition of the peasants there was almost the same as the indentured labourers, and that they had failed in their agitation for nearly half a century for there was no cohesive power of non violence to hold them together.
('73', 252, 1, 9, 482820) There had been several riots and their condition had grown worse every year.
('73', 252, 1, 10, 482897) But the first taste of non violence breathed new life into them, and at the end of a remarkably brief struggle they were emancipated.
('73', 252, 1, 11, 483031) Without that necessary discipline in non violence, they would have internecine strife and would never be ready to develop the strength that is needed to enable them to realize the power that they possess.
('73', 252, 1, 12, 483236) Organization, technical skill and everything else would follow the acceptance of the fundamental principle of non violence.
('73', 252, 1, 13, 483360) Class collaboration would also follow as a matter of course.
('73', 252, 1, 14, 483421) They are strong in numbers and yet they feel so dependent, so very much at the mercy of their employers.
('73', 252, 1, 15, 483526) That is because they do not know their own inherent strength.
('73', 252, 1, 16, 483588) Otherwise what is there to prevent them from pooling their own resources and dictating terms as employers do now.
('73', 252, 1, 17, 483702) The thing that they have to realize is that labour is as much capital as metal.
('73', 252, 1, 18, 483782) That realization can come only through acceptance of non violence.
('73', 252, 1, 19, 483849) But after that realization has come and they have come to their own, non violence does not become superfluous.
('73', 252, 1, 20, 483960) If they were to bid good bye to it, they would be as bad as capitalists and turn exploiters themselves.
('73', 252, 1, 21, 484064) The realizaton of their strength combined with adherence to non violence would enable them to co operate with capital and turn it to proper use.
('73', 252, 1, 22, 484209) Then they will not regard it as a conflicting interest, they will not regard the mill and the machinery as belonging to the exploiting agents and grinding them down, but as their own instruments of production, and will therefore protect them as well as they would their own property.
('73', 252, 1, 23, 484493) They will not steal time and turn out less work, but will put in the most they can.
('73', 252, 1, 24, 484577) In fact, capital and labour will be mutual trustees and both will be trustees of consumers.
('73', 252, 1, 25, 484669) The trusteeship theory is not unilateral and does not in the least imply
('73', 253, 0, 1, 484742) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 253, 1, 2, 484784) superiority of the turstee.
('73', 253, 1, 3, 484812) It is, as I have shown, a perfectly mutual affair, and each believes that his own interest is best safeguarded by safeguarding the interest of the other.
('73', 253, 1, 4, 484966) May you propitiate the gods and may the gods propitiate you, and may you reach the highest good by this mutual propitiation, says the Bhagavad Gita.
('73', 253, 1, 5, 485115) There is no separate species called gods in the universe, but all who have the power of production and will work for the community using that power are godslabourers no less than the capitalists.
('73', 253, 2, 6, 485311) Harijan, 25 6 1938.

('73', 255, 2, 11, 488197) Before the proposed scheme can be accepted by us three it is necessary that even following out the method of the Government scheme, the result should approximate to what I have submitted in my letter of 13th April last.
('73', 255, 2, 12, 488417) It I accepted anything less I would be guilty of a breach of faith with the prisoners to whom I gave an absolute assurance, often repeated, that, subject to their subscribing to non violence, I should strain every nerve to secure early discharge for every one of them.

('73', 255, 2, 14, 488787) The method adopted for achieving the end would then cause no difficulty.

('73', 255, 2, 16, 488954) If, at any time, you desire my presence, and if it is likely to facilitate matters, you will please not hesitate to drop me a line and, health permitting, I would gladly visit Bengal.

('73', 265, 11, 26, 505197) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 1, 1938
('73', 265, 12, 27, 505226) CHHAGANLAL, Your letter was excellent, because it was so frank.
('73', 265, 12, 28, 505290) There was no reason at all for you to apologize for it.
('73', 265, 12, 29, 505346) I fully remember the dis cussion at the Sabarmati Ashram.

('73', 265, 12, 32, 505519) I have a faint impression that at the end of the discussion
('73', 266, 0, 1, 505579) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 267
('73', 266, 1, 2, 505629) on the first occasion some decision was arrived at regarding my practice of walking with my hand on a girls shoulder.
('73', 266, 1, 3, 505747) Kaka was not present at that discussion.
('73', 266, 1, 4, 505788) When he came to know about it, he raised the subject again, for he approved of the principle behind my practice.
('73', 266, 1, 5, 505901) At the end of the second discussion, my memory is that I had decided to maintain the status quo.
('73', 266, 1, 6, 505998) Be that as it may, the main point is that I do not think I have failed to do what I had promised to do.
('73', 266, 1, 7, 506102) As regards the Wardha decision, you will see if you read Harijan1 that the girls, while going in procession from Maganwadi to Mahilashram and from Mahilashram to Maganwadi, used to call at my hut and take me out with them.
('73', 266, 1, 8, 506325) I walked with my hands on their shoulders by turns.
('73', 266, 1, 9, 506377) This was observed by some people and became the subject of comment.
('73', 266, 1, 10, 506445) I myself raised the matter for discussion and published the decision at which I finally arrived.
('73', 266, 1, 11, 506542) It was not in my mind at all that I would never place my hands even on the shoulders of girls who live with me, for after writing that article I continued to use Manu and other girls as my walking sticks.
('73', 266, 1, 12, 506747) But that procession stopped, and the practice has not been revived and will not be revived.
('73', 266, 1, 13, 506839) The reason for stopping it had nothing to do with my vow of brahmacharya.
('73', 266, 1, 14, 506913) The only consideration was the good of society.
('73', 266, 1, 15, 506961) In this instance, too, there is no question of my having failed to do what I had declared I would do.
('73', 266, 1, 16, 507063) If I had made such a declaration and then failed to abide by it, knowing full well that I was doing so, I would be pained and feel humiliated in my own eyes.
('73', 266, 1, 17, 507221) It would give me no pleasure to know that I had weakened in my determination to keep a vow.
('73', 266, 1, 18, 507313) Yes, there may be self deception sometimes; as, for instance, when I decided to drink goats milk because my vow forbade me to use cows or buffalos milk, or when I compromised by counting several vegetables as one item in observing the vow of not consuming more than five items at any one meal.
('73', 266, 1, 19, 507607) This is a painful memory for me.
('73', 266, 1, 20, 507640) Even so, I have convinced myself that I have not violated the letter of my pledges and exercise the utmost strictness in observing a vow.
('73', 266, 1, 21, 507778) I have no comment to make about Thakkar Bapa having been pained.
('73', 266, 1, 22, 507843) You had no reply to give to the criticism of that muni of Kutch, for you had before you two instances of what you regard to be violation of pledges; you should, therefore, bear that criticism without resentment.
('73', 266, 1, 23, 508055) Your only reply can be: Even we, who live with him, are puzzled by some of his actions.
('73', 266, 1, 24, 508143) But we think we have lost nothing by
('73', 266, 2, 25, 508180) 1 Vide A Renunciation
('73', 267, 0, 1, 508202) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 267, 1, 2, 508244) our association with him, and so we cling to him.
('73', 267, 1, 3, 508294) I will ask him about the comparision which you have made. If you gave this reply, it was correct.
('73', 267, 1, 4, 508392) If you kept quiet, that also was right.
('73', 267, 1, 5, 508432) In any case, you can always give this reply: He has always touched girls with a pure feeling and never with a gross purpose.
('73', 267, 1, 6, 508557) But a doubt having occurred whether, unknown to him, there might not be an impure feeling in his heart, he has temporarily given up the practice to end that doubt. Personally, I cannot compare the munis conduct with mine.
('73', 267, 1, 7, 508779) According to me, there is a serious error in it.

('73', 271, 3, 4, 514995) KANTI, You must have received my letter of yesterday.
('73', 271, 3, 5, 515049) You are very cruel indeed, and also childish.
('73', 271, 3, 6, 515095) You may write as rude letters as you can but they will not make me angry.

('73', 271, 3, 8, 515198) You are wise and are capable of self sacrifice, but it pains me to know that you are eaten up by anger.
('73', 271, 3, 9, 515302) The knowledge that you are harming yourself does wring my heart.

('73', 271, 3, 11, 515389) It does not do you credit that I should weigh my words when writing to you.
('73', 271, 3, 12, 515465) Your letter to Saraswati was bad.

('73', 271, 3, 21, 515923) Remember that I am a man of experience.

('73', 273, 1, 2, 518311) 337. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('73', 273, 2, 3, 518339) SEGAON, July 6, 1938
('73', 273, 3, 4, 518360) QUESTION: What is the place of religious instruction in the Wardha Scheme of Education?
('73', 273, 4, 5, 518448) ANSWER: We have left out the teaching of religions from the Wardha Scheme of Education, because we are afraid that religions as they are taught and practised today lead to conflict rather than unity.
('73', 273, 4, 6, 518648) But on the other hand, I hold that the truths that are common to all religions can and should be taught to all children.
('73', 273, 4, 7, 518769) These truths cannot be taught through words or through books.
('73', 273, 4, 8, 518831) The children can learn these truths only through the daily life of the teacher.
('73', 273, 4, 9, 518911) If the teacher himself lives up to the tenets of truth and justice, then alone can the children learn that truth and justice are the basis of all religions.
('73', 273, 5, 10, 519068) When Mahatmaji was asked whether it was possible to teach children between the ages of seven and fourteen equal respect for all religions he said: Yes, I think so.
('73', 273, 5, 11, 519232) The truth that all religions are the same in essentials, that we must love and respect others' faiths as we respect our own, is a very simple truth, and can easily be understood and practised by children of seven.
('73', 273, 5, 12, 519446) But, of course, the first essential is that the teacher must have this faith himself.
('73', 273, 6, 13, 519532) The Bombay Chronicle, 7 7 1938

('73', 274, 1, 13, 520689) I began work among women when I was not even thirty years old.
('73', 274, 1, 14, 520752) There is not a woman in S.A. who does not know me.
('73', 274, 1, 15, 520803) But my work was among the poorest.
('73', 274, 1, 16, 520838) The intellectuals I could not draw.

('73', 274, 1, 19, 520992) Hence you are wrong in laying down the sweeping proposition you have.
('73', 274, 1, 20, 521062) You can't blame me for not having organized the intellectuals among women.

('73', 274, 1, 22, 521158) And then my method of organizing is out of the ordinary, not necessarily superior.

('73', 274, 1, 24, 521293) But just as I never fear coldness on the part of the poor when I approach them, I never fear it when I approach poor women.
('73', 274, 1, 25, 521417) There is invisible bond between them and me.
('73', 274, 1, 26, 521462) And why do you miss the agony I am passing through?
('73', 274, 1, 27, 521514) Is it not for woman kind?
('73', 274, 1, 28, 521540) I am wringing my soul for adequate purity, to enable me [to] render greater service to them and through them to the whole of humanity.
('73', 274, 1, 29, 521675) Ahimsa, which is my sheet anchor, demands all this.
('73', 274, 1, 30, 521727) I expect your next letter to tell me you are well.

('73', 275, 10, 18, 522785) 341. LETTER TO BALWANTSINHA
('73', 275, 11, 19, 522813) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 8, 1938
('73', 275, 12, 20, 522842) BALWANTSINHA, One point in brahmacharya is this that the vital fluid should not be wasted.
('73', 275, 12, 21, 522933) It is supposed that it is not wasted when it moves upward.
('73', 275, 12, 22, 522992) This is not correct.
('73', 275, 12, 23, 523013) A man giving way to anger mis spends it or rather destroys it, thus rendering it unfruitful.
('73', 275, 12, 24, 523106) To that extent brahmacharya has been damaged.
('73', 275, 12, 25, 523152) Similarly a man wastes his vital fluid when he indulges in intercourse for the sake of pleasure, as it is unproductive.
('73', 276, 0, 1, 523272) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 277
('73', 276, 1, 2, 523322) When a man has no desire for sensual pleasure and both the man and the woman desire a child and come together for that purpose, then alone is vital fluid completely fruitful.
('73', 276, 1, 3, 523497) Such a couple are truly brahmacharis.
('73', 276, 1, 4, 523535) But such a couple might be only one among crores.
('73', 276, 1, 5, 523585) Apart from the one single occasion of copulation they live like brother and sister and refrain from any sensual indulgence in thought, speech, contact or any other way.
('73', 276, 1, 6, 523754) Their intercourse for the purpose of procreation alone can in no way come under the category of gratification of the senses.
('73', 276, 1, 7, 523879) This ought to clear your doubt.
('73', 276, 2, 8, 523911) Blessings from
('73', 276, 4, 9, 523926) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 1905
('73', 276, 5, 10, 523967) 342. THE STATES
('73', 276, 6, 11, 523983) Events seem to have justified the wisdom of the Congress resolution of non intervention in the affairs of the States.
('73', 276, 6, 12, 524101) The constitution, however unjust, arbitrary and illogical it may be, is such that, legally and politically, every State, small or big, is an independent entity in its relation to the other States and that part of India which is called British in contradistinction from the States.
('73', 276, 6, 13, 524382) The similarity common to all is that they are under the iron grip of British Rule.
('73', 276, 6, 14, 524465) But geographically and ethnically the people of the States and the other parts of India are one and indivisible.
('73', 276, 6, 15, 524578) We, the thirty three crores of men and women, are blood relations who cannot be parted by any constitutional or military device.
('73', 276, 6, 16, 524707) This natural relationship is working itself without let or hindrance because of the recognition of the constitutional fact while it lasts.
('73', 276, 6, 17, 524846) That is the way of satyagraha or the way of non resistance to evil.
('73', 276, 6, 18, 524914) It is the aseptic method in which the physician allows the poison to work itself out by setting in motion all the natural forces and letting them have full play.
('73', 276, 6, 19, 525076) By its resolution of non interference the Congress put the States people on their mettle, in other words set in motion the natural forces, i.e., the powers latent in the people themselves.
('73', 276, 6, 20, 525265) In the few recent instances it has been found that the people having discovered their strength they used it without any aid from outside and won full victory.
('73', 276, 6, 21, 525424) The result also was that the assistance of Congressmen was invoked by the States authorities in order to settle the differences between themselves and their people.
('73', 276, 6, 22, 525589) No doubt this method like every other known to mankind has its limitations.
('73', 276, 6, 23, 525665) The Congress cannot
('73', 277, 0, 1, 525685) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 277, 1, 2, 525727) dictate unreasonable terms.
('73', 277, 1, 3, 525755) The people must have a real grievance and they must approach it with pure hands.
('73', 277, 1, 4, 525836) For the tool of satyagraha is ahimsa, i.e., self suffering without inflicting suffering on the opponent for the vindication of a cause which must be absolutely just.
('73', 277, 1, 5, 526002) If only the people of the States can realize the full meaning and potency of satyagraha, i.e., of non violence, they will win their relative freedom before India as a whole comes to its own.
('73', 277, 1, 6, 526193) And they will have to before India has Independence.
('73', 277, 1, 7, 526246) Thus they can have full liberty of non violent speech, writing and action without having to deal with cumbersome British machinery.
('73', 277, 1, 8, 526378) They can secure with comparative ease a more equitable, even if not an equal, distribution of the wealth produced in the States.
('73', 277, 1, 9, 526507) They can, without much effort, regulate the privy purse of their Princes and can have cheap and pure justice guaranteed.
('73', 277, 1, 10, 526628) They can deal with the problem of poverty and village reconstruction with infinitely greater ease than in unwieldy and bureaucracy ridden British India.
('73', 277, 1, 11, 526781) They can have real national education for the wanting.
('73', 277, 1, 12, 526836) This will be their swarajno doubt far short of the Indepen dence that the Congress wants.
('73', 277, 1, 13, 526926) But if the people of the majority of the major States attain their full height, the day of Independence will be hastened in a manner no one has dreamt of.
('73', 277, 1, 14, 527081) Let not the reformers in the States therefore be unduly impatient; let them not forget their limitations and above all the conditions of success, viz., strictest observance of truth and non violence.
('73', 277, 1, 15, 527281) They must be ready to face bullets without flinching but also without lifting their little finger in so called self defence.
('73', 277, 1, 16, 527406) A satyagrahi abjures the right of self defence.
('73', 277, 1, 17, 527454) Let it also be remembered that a satyagrahis minimum is also his maximum.
('73', 277, 2, 18, 527528) Harijan, 9 7 1938
('73', 277, 3, 19, 527546) 343. HIGHER EDUCATION
('73', 277, 4, 20, 527568) The Rt.
('73', 277, 4, 21, 527576) Shri Srinivasa Sastri has criticized, as he had a perfect right to do, the views I timidly and very briefly expressed some time ago on higher education.
('73', 277, 4, 22, 527729) I entertain a very high regard for him as man, patriot and scholar.
('73', 277, 4, 23, 527797) It is therefore always painful to me when I find myself disagreeing with him.
('73', 277, 4, 24, 527875) And yet duty compels me to re express my views on higher education more fully than before, so that the reader may make out for himself the difference between his views and mine.
('73', 278, 0, 1, 528053) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 279
('73', 278, 1, 2, 528103) I admit my limitations.
('73', 278, 1, 3, 528127) I have no university education worth the name.
('73', 278, 1, 4, 528174) My high school career was never above the average.
('73', 278, 1, 5, 528225) I was thankful if I could pass my examinations.
('73', 278, 1, 6, 528273) Distinction in the school was beyond my aspiration.
('73', 278, 1, 7, 528325) Nevertheless I do hold very strong views on education in general, including what is called higher education.
('73', 278, 1, 8, 528434) And I owe it to the country that my views should be clearly known and taken for what they may be worth.
('73', 278, 1, 9, 528538) I must shed the timidity that has led almost to self suppression.
('73', 278, 1, 10, 528604) I must not fear ridicule, and even loss of popularity or prestige.
('73', 278, 1, 11, 528671) If I hide my belief, I shall never correct errors of judgment.
('73', 278, 1, 12, 528734) I am always eager to discover them and more than eager to correct them.
('73', 278, 1, 13, 528806) Let me now state my conclusions held for a number of years and enforced wherever I had opportunity of enforcing them: (1) I am not opposed to education even of the highest type attainable in the world.
('73', 278, 1, 14, 529008) (2) The State must pay for it wherever it has definite use for it.
('73', 278, 1, 15, 529075) (3) I am opposed to all higher education being paid for from the general revenue.
('73', 278, 1, 16, 529157) (4) It is my firm conviction that the vast amount of the so called education in arts, given in our colleges, is sheer waste and has resulted in unemployment among the educated classes.
('73', 278, 1, 17, 529342) What is more, it has destroyed the health, both mental and physical, of the boys and girls who have the misfortune to go through the grind in our colleges.
('73', 278, 1, 18, 529498) (5) The medium of a foreign language through which higher education has been imparted in India has caused incalculable intellectual and moral injury to the nation.
('73', 278, 1, 19, 529662) We are too near our own times to judge the enormity of the damage done.
('73', 278, 1, 20, 529734) And we who have received such education have both to be victims and judgesan almost impossible feat.
('73', 278, 1, 21, 529835) I must now give my reason for the conclusions set forth above.
('73', 278, 1, 22, 529898) This I can best do, perhaps, by giving a chapter from my own experience.
('73', 278, 1, 23, 529971) Up to the age of 12 all the knowledge I gained was through Gujarati, my mother tongue.
('73', 278, 1, 24, 530058) I knew then something of arithmetic, history and geography.
('73', 278, 1, 25, 530118) Then I entered a high school.
('73', 278, 1, 26, 530148) For the first three years the mother tongue was still the medium.
('73', 278, 1, 27, 530214) But the school masters business was to drive English into the pupils head.
('73', 278, 1, 28, 530289) Therefore more than half of our time was given to learning English and mastering its arbitrary spelling and pronunciation.
('73', 278, 1, 29, 530412) It was a painful discovery to have to learn a language that was not pronounced as it was written.
('73', 278, 1, 30, 530510) It was a strange experience to have to learn the spelling by
('73', 279, 0, 1, 530571) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 279, 1, 2, 530613) But that is by the way, and irrelevant to my argument.
('73', 279, 1, 3, 530668) However, for the first three years, it was comparatively plain sailing.
('73', 279, 1, 4, 530740) The pillory began with the fourth year.
('73', 279, 1, 5, 530780) Everything had to be learnt through Englishgeometry, algebra, chemistry, astronomy, history, geography.
('73', 279, 1, 6, 530884) The tyranny of English was so great that even Sanskrit or Persian had to be learnt through English, not through the mother tongue.
('73', 279, 1, 7, 531015) If any boy spoke in the class in Gujarati which he understood, he was punished.
('73', 279, 1, 8, 531095) It did not matter to the teacher if a boy spoke bad English which he could neither pronounce correctly nor understand fully.
('73', 279, 1, 9, 531220) Why should the teacher worry?
('73', 279, 1, 10, 531250) His own English was by no means without blemish.
('73', 279, 1, 11, 531299) It could not be otherwise.
('73', 279, 1, 12, 531326) English was as much a foreign language to him as to his pupils.
('73', 279, 1, 13, 531390) The result was chaos.
('73', 279, 1, 14, 531412) We the boys had to learn many things by heart, though we could not understand them fully and often not at all.
('73', 279, 1, 15, 531523) My head used to reel as the teacher was struggling to make his exposition on geometry understood by us.
('73', 279, 1, 16, 531627) I could make neither head nor tail of geometry till we reached the 13th theorem of the first book of Euclid.
('73', 279, 1, 17, 531736) And let me confess to the reader that in spite of all my love for the mother tongue I do not to this day know the Gujarati equivalents of the technical terms of geometry, algebra and the like.
('73', 279, 1, 18, 531929) I know now that what I took four years to learn of arithmetic, geometry, algebra, chemistry and astronomy I should have learnt easily in one year if I had not to learn them through English but Gujarati.
('73', 279, 1, 19, 532132) My grasp of the subjects would have been easier and clearer.
('73', 279, 1, 20, 532193) My Gujarati vocabulary would have been richer.
('73', 279, 1, 21, 532240) I would have made use of such knowledge in my own home.
('73', 279, 1, 22, 532296) This English medium created an impassable barrier between me and the members of my family, who had not gone through English schools.
('73', 279, 1, 23, 532429) My father knew nothing of what I was doing.
('73', 279, 1, 24, 532473) I could not, even if I had wished it, interest my father in what I was learning.
('73', 279, 1, 25, 532554) For though he had ample intelligence, he knew not a word of English.
('73', 279, 1, 26, 532623) I was fast becoming a stranger in my own home.
('73', 279, 1, 27, 532670) I certainly became a superior person.
('73', 279, 1, 28, 532708) Even my dress began to undergo imperceptible changes.
('73', 279, 1, 29, 532762) What happened to me was not an uncommon experience.
('73', 279, 1, 30, 532814) It was common to the majority.
('73', 279, 1, 31, 532845) The first three years in the high school made little addition to my stock of general knowledge.
('73', 279, 1, 32, 532941) They were a preparation for fitting the boys for teaching them everything through English.
('73', 279, 1, 33, 533032) High schools were schools for cultural conquest by the English.
('73', 279, 1, 34, 533096) The knowledge gained by the three hundred boys of my high school became a circumscribed possession.
('73', 279, 1, 35, 533196) It was not for transmission to the masses.
('73', 280, 0, 1, 533239) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 281
('73', 280, 1, 2, 533289) A word about literature.
('73', 280, 1, 3, 533314) We had to learn several books of English prose and English poetry.
('73', 280, 1, 4, 533381) No doubt all this was nice.
('73', 280, 1, 5, 533409) But that knowledge has been of no use to me in serving or bringing me in touch with the masses.
('73', 280, 1, 6, 533505) I am unable to say that if I had not learnt what I did of English prose and poetry, I should have missed a rare treasure.
('73', 280, 1, 7, 533627) If I had, instead, passed those precious seven years in mastering Gujarati and had learnt mathematics, sciences, and Sanskrit and other subjects through Gujarati, I could easily have shared the knowledge so gained with my neighbours.
('73', 280, 1, 8, 533861) I would have enriched Gujarati, and who can say that I would not have, with my habit of application and my inordinate love for the country and the mother tongue, made a richer and greater contribution to the service of the masses?
('73', 280, 1, 9, 534092) I must not be understood to decry English or its noble litera ture.
('73', 280, 1, 10, 534160) The columns of Harijan are sufficient evidence of my love of English.
('73', 280, 1, 11, 534230) But the nobility of its literature cannot avail the Indian nation any more than the temperate climate or the scenery of England can avail her.
('73', 280, 1, 12, 534373) India has to flourish in her own climate and scenery and her own literature, even though all the three may be inferior to the English climate, scenery and literature.
('73', 280, 1, 13, 534540) We and our children must build on our own heritage.
('73', 280, 1, 14, 534592) If we borrow another, we impoverish our own.
('73', 280, 1, 15, 534637) We can never grow on foreign victuals.
('73', 280, 1, 16, 534676) I want the nation to have the treasures contained in that language, and for that matter the other languages of the world, through its own vernaculars.
('73', 280, 1, 17, 534827) I do not need to learn Bengali in order to know the beauties of Rabindranaths matchless produc tions.
('73', 280, 1, 18, 534929) I get them through good translations.
('73', 280, 1, 19, 534967) Gujarati boys and girls do not need to learn Russian to appreciate Tolstoys short stories.
('73', 280, 1, 20, 535058) They learn them through good translations.
('73', 280, 1, 21, 535101) It is the boast of Englishmen that the best of the worlds literary output is in the hands of that nation in simple English inside of a week of its publication.
('73', 280, 1, 22, 535261) Why need I learn English to get at the best of what Shakespeare and Milton thought and wrote?
('73', 280, 1, 23, 535355) It would be good economy to set apart a class of students whose business would be to learn the best of what is to be learnt in the different languages of the world and give the translation in the vernaculars.
('73', 280, 1, 24, 535564) Our masters chose the wrong way for us, and habit has made the wrong appear as right.
('73', 280, 1, 25, 535650) I find daily proof of the increasing and continuing wrong being done to the millions by our false de Indianizing education.
('73', 280, 1, 26, 535774) Those graduates who are my valued associates themselves flounder when they have to give expression to their innermost thoughts.
('73', 280, 1, 27, 535902) They are strangers in their own homes.
('73', 280, 1, 28, 535941) Their vocabulary in the mother tongue
('73', 281, 0, 1, 535979) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 281, 1, 2, 536021) is so limited that they cannot always finish their speech without having recourse to English words and even sentences.
('73', 281, 1, 3, 536140) Nor can they exist without English books.
('73', 281, 1, 4, 536182) They often write to one another in English.
('73', 281, 1, 5, 536226) I cite the case of my companions to show how deep the evil has gone.
('73', 281, 1, 6, 536295) For we have made a conscious effort to mend ourselves.
('73', 281, 1, 7, 536350) It has been argued that the wastage that occurs in our colleges need not worry us if, out of the collegians, one Jagadish Bose can be produced by them.
('73', 281, 1, 8, 536502) I should freely subscribe to the argument if the wastage was unavoidable.
('73', 281, 1, 9, 536576) I hope I have shown that it was and is even now avoidable.
('73', 281, 1, 10, 536635) Moreover, the creation of a Bose does not help the argument.
('73', 281, 1, 11, 536696) For Bose was not a product of the present education.
('73', 281, 1, 12, 536749) He rose in spite of the terrible handicaps under which he had to labour.
('73', 281, 1, 13, 536822) And his knowledge became almost intransmissible to the masses.
('73', 281, 1, 14, 536885) We seem to have come to think that no one can hope to be like a Bose unless he knows English.
('73', 281, 1, 15, 536979) I cannot conceive a grosser superstition than this.
('73', 281, 1, 16, 537031) No Japanese feels so helpless as we seem to do.
('73', 281, 1, 17, 537079) Nothing but a heroic remedy can deal with the deep seated evil which I have endeavoured to describe.
('73', 281, 1, 18, 537180) The Congress Ministers can, if they will, mitigate it if they cannot remove it.
('73', 281, 1, 19, 537260) Universities must be made self supporting.
('73', 281, 1, 20, 537303) The State should simply educate those whose services it would need.
('73', 281, 1, 21, 537371) For all other branches of learning it should encourage private effort.
('73', 281, 1, 22, 537442) The medium of instruction should be altered at once and at any cost, the provincial languages being given their rightful place.
('73', 281, 1, 23, 537570) I would prefer temporary chaos in higher education to the criminal waste that is daily accumulating.
('73', 281, 1, 24, 537671) In order to enhance the status and the market value of the provincial languages, I would have the language of the law courts to be the language of the province where the court is situated.
('73', 281, 1, 25, 537860) The proceedings of the Provincial Legislatures must be in the language, or even the languages of the province where a province has more than one language within its borders.
('73', 281, 1, 26, 538034) I suggest to the legislators that they could, by enough application, inside of a month, understand the languages of their provinces.
('73', 281, 1, 27, 538167) There is nothing to prevent a Tamilian from easily learning the simple grammar and a few hundred words of Telugu, Malayalam and Kanarese, all allied to Tamil.
('73', 281, 1, 28, 538326) At the centre Hindustani must rule supreme.
('73', 281, 1, 29, 538370) In my opinion this is not a question to be decided by acade micians.
('73', 281, 1, 30, 538439) They cannot decide through what language the boys and girls of a place are to be educated.
('73', 281, 1, 31, 538530) That question is already decided
('73', 282, 0, 1, 538563) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 283
('73', 282, 1, 2, 538613) for them in every free country.
('73', 282, 1, 3, 538645) Nor can they decide the subjects to be taught.
('73', 282, 1, 4, 538692) That depends upon the wants of the country to which they belong.
('73', 282, 1, 5, 538757) Theirs is the privilege of enforcing the nations will in the best manner possible.
('73', 282, 1, 6, 538840) When this country becomes really free the question of medium will be settled only one way.
('73', 282, 1, 7, 538931) The academicians will frame the syllabus and prepare text books accordingly.
('73', 282, 1, 8, 539008) And the products of the education of a free India will answer the requirements of the country as today they answer those of the foreign ruler.
('73', 282, 1, 9, 539151) So long as we the educated classes play with this question.
('73', 282, 1, 10, 539211) I very much fear we shall not produce the free and healthy India of our dream.
('73', 282, 1, 11, 539290) We have to grow by strenuous effort out of our bondage, whether it is educational, economical, social or political.
('73', 282, 1, 12, 539406) The effort itself is three fourths of the battle.
('73', 282, 1, 13, 539456) Thus I claim that I am not an enemy of higher education.
('73', 282, 1, 14, 539513) But I am an enemy of higher education as it is given in this country.
('73', 282, 1, 15, 539583) Under my scheme there will be more and better libraries, more and better laboratories, more and better research institutes.
('73', 282, 1, 16, 539707) Under it we should have an army of chemists, engineers and other experts who will be real servants of the nation and answer the varied and growing requirements of a people who are becoming increasingly conscious of their rights and wants.
('73', 282, 1, 17, 539946) And all these experts will speak not a foreign language but the language of the people.
('73', 282, 1, 18, 540034) The knowledge gained by them will be the common property of the people.
('73', 282, 1, 19, 540106) There will be truly original work instead of mere imitation.
('73', 282, 1, 20, 540167) And the cost will be evenly and justly distributed.
('73', 282, 2, 21, 540219) Harijan, 9 7 1938

('73', 283, 1, 2, 540279) 344. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI SEGAON, WARDHA, July 9, 1938
('73', 283, 2, 3, 540339) NARANDAS, I got your pamphlet1. The Rentia Baras day is or should be the time for drawing up an annual balance sheet of the progress of khadi work and thinking out ways and means of speeding it up.
('73', 283, 2, 4, 540537) I see that your resolutions are increasing in number every year.
('73', 283, 2, 5, 540602) But in comparison to what we have to achieve, even this increased number of resolutions are nothing.
('73', 283, 2, 6, 540703) According to the saying, drop by drop fills the lake, we should content ourselves with doing the best we are capable of.
('73', 283, 2, 7, 540824) Let all participants in this yajna remember that we should not rest satisfied till the daily income of all workers including the spinners reaches eight annas for a day of eight hours.
('73', 283, 2, 8, 541008) And in order to achieve that we should be proficient in all aspects of the charkha science.
('73', 283, 2, 9, 541100) In that way we shall be able to improve the quality of the khadi without raising the prices very much.
('73', 283, 2, 10, 541203) If we master that science, we can prove that khadi, though apparently costly, is actually bound to be cheap.
('73', 283, 2, 11, 541312) I hope to be able to send someone for the Rentia Baras day.

('73', 289, 1, 2, 549622) 355. A MESSAGE TO THE ARYAN PATH SEGAON, [July 14, 1938]
('73', 289, 2, 3, 549679) I welcome your advertising the principles in defence of which Hind Swaraj was written.1 The English edition is a translation of the original which was in Gujarati.
('73', 289, 2, 4, 549843) I might change the language here and there if I had to rewrite the booklet.
('73', 289, 2, 5, 549919) But after the stormy thirty years through which I have since passed, I have seen nothing to make me alter the views expounded in it.
('73', 289, 2, 6, 550052) Let the reader bear in mind that it is a faithful record of conversations I had with workers, one of whom was an avowed anarchist.
('73', 289, 2, 7, 550183) He should also know that it stopped the rot that was about to set in among some Indians in South Africa.
('73', 289, 2, 8, 550288) The reader
('73', 289, 3, 9, 550299) 1 A special issue of The Aryan Path exclusively devoted to Hind Swaraj, then being planned, came out in September.
('73', 289, 3, 10, 550414) The contributors included such eminent Western thinkers as Frederick Soddy, G.D.H. Cole, C. Delisle Burns, John Middleton Murry, Hugh IAnson Fausset, Gerald Heard and Irene Rathbone.
('73', 289, 3, 11, 550597) Though none of them found themselves wholly in agreement with the thesis advanced in Hind Swaraj they all nevertheless saw the great importance of the work.
('73', 289, 3, 12, 550754) Frederick Soddy, for instance, though disagreeing with Gandhiji, suggested that anyone who wishes to change the world would do well to study the book.
('73', 289, 3, 13, 550905) To G. D. H. Cole Gandhijis case against the West looked infinitely stronger than it did in 1908, when the ephemeral civilization of the West looked stable under Western eyes.
('73', 289, 3, 14, 551080) C. Delisle Burns saw the highest merit of Hind Swaraj in its emphasis upon moral issues and opposition to the pursuit of private wealth and power.
('73', 289, 3, 15, 551227) John Middleton Murry considered Hind Swaraj a great book, one of the spiritual classics of the world, and compared Gandhijis vision of real swaraj to the Christian vision of the Kingdom of Heaven.
('73', 289, 3, 16, 551424) Gerald Heard thought Hind Swaraj was superior to Rousseaus Social Contract and Karl Marxs Das Capital, for it did not mark the end of an age but the beginning of a new order.
('73', 289, 3, 17, 551599) Irene Rathbone found the book enormously powerful, the language of which forced her by its tremendous honesty to search my own honesty.
('73', 289, 3, 18, 551735) She thought the work was simple and logical, economical, condensed, poetic.
('73', 289, 3, 19, 551811) Hugh Fausset summed up Hind Swaraj as a book whose purpose was to save India, not from Englishmen, but from the modern civilization which is eating into the vitals of the West.
('73', 289, 3, 20, 551988) He had enough trust in the indestructible vitality of the human spirit to be sure that it would not allow itself to be lastingly mechanized.
('73', 289, 3, 21, 552129) The machine was exposing ruthlessly the consequences that must happen to men and nations who had lost their integrity.
('73', 289, 3, 22, 552248) Hind Swaraj was an attempt at restoring man to his true estate, and was, for this reason, one of the best modern handbooks of that real revolution which must happen in us all, if we are to fulfil the creative purpose of life.
('73', 290, 0, 1, 552474) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 291
('73', 290, 1, 2, 552524) may balance against this the opinion of a dear friend, who, also, is no more, that it was the production of a fool.
('73', 290, 2, 3, 552640) M. K. GANDHI The Aryan Path, September 1938, Vol. IX, No.
