('73', 292, 5, 17, 556768) 361. SPEAKERS AND POLITICS
('73', 292, 6, 18, 556795) Some controversy has raged round the propriety of the Speakers of the various Provincial Assemblies taking an active part in politics.
('73', 292, 6, 19, 556930) There has been the Speakers ruling and a full debate and a resolution in the U. P. Assembly to the effect that the Speaker can consistently with the due discharge of the obligations of office take an active part in politics.
('73', 292, 6, 20, 557155) Shri Sambamurti was with me for a few days and exhaustively discussed the question with me.
('73', 292, 6, 21, 557247) He read to me copious extracts from authoritative treatises dealing with the Speakers duties in the Parliaments of the world.
('73', 292, 6, 22, 557373) And there has appeared an article in Harijan by Shri Satyamurti.
('73', 292, 6, 23, 557438) I had a long discussion on the question with Shri Purushottamdas Tandon during his recent visit to Wardha.
('73', 292, 6, 24, 557545) After all these discussions and study of the subject I seem to hold a view perhaps different from those I have heard and read.
('73', 292, 6, 25, 557672) Mine is derived from my conception of the acceptance of office by Con gressmen.
('73', 292, 6, 26, 557752) When I advised the Working Committee to authorize accep tance of office, the idea was that whilst the letter of the Government of
('73', 293, 0, 1, 557882) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 294
('73', 293, 1, 2, 557924) India Act should not be transgressed, its interpretation should be stretched to the farthest limit so as to widen the liberty of the people and to strengthen the Congress.
('73', 293, 1, 3, 558096) The Act was not to be worked in the manner conceived by its authors, but while it lasted should be fully used for the advancement of the Congress goal and therefore in a manner least expected by its authors.
('73', 293, 1, 4, 558304) Such being my conception of office acceptance, British and foreign precedents are of little use to me.
('73', 293, 1, 5, 558407) Moreover, in the nature of things, they can help us but little for the simple reason that unlike ours the constitutions of the worlds Parliaments are not imposed on the respective peoples but are their own creation.
('73', 293, 1, 6, 558623) A Congressman who is a member of an Assembly, no matter what office he occupies there, is subject to the discipline of the Congress and has to carry out its instructions from time to time.
('73', 293, 1, 7, 558812) Therefore, so long as the Government of India Act does not in so many words prohibit it, the Congress may, if it thinks it necessary, require Speakers in the Congress Provinces to take an active part in the politics of the country.
('73', 293, 1, 8, 559044) But the Congress, as far as I know, has not considered the ques tion.
('73', 293, 1, 9, 559114) In my opinion Congressmen who are members of Assemblies, whether as mere members or Ministers or Speakers, have in every act of theirs to bear in mind the fact that they have, in virtue of the Congress constitution, to conform to truth and non violence.
('73', 293, 1, 10, 559368) Thus the conduct of a Congressman in an Assembly would have to be that of strictest honesty and courtesy in dealing with his opponents.
('73', 293, 1, 11, 559504) He will not resort to shady politics, will not hit below the belt, will never take a mean advantage of his adversary.
('73', 293, 1, 12, 559622) The greater his position in the Assembly, the greater is his responsibility in these matters.
('73', 293, 1, 13, 559716) A member in the Assembly no doubt represents his constituency and his party but he also represents the whole of his province.
('73', 293, 1, 14, 559842) A Minister no doubt advances his own party but never at the expense of the nation as a whole.
('73', 293, 1, 15, 559936) Indeed he advances the Congress only so far as he advances the nation.
('73', 293, 1, 16, 560007) For he knows that if he has no sword to give battle to the foreign ruler, he has it not to give battle to his adversary inside the nation itself.
('73', 293, 1, 17, 560153) And since the Assembly is the place where all commu nities meet together willy nilly, it is the place where by winning over his opponents he expects to forge sanctions which can be made irresistible.
('73', 293, 1, 18, 560353) All the problems that affect the body politic including communal unity can be solved if the Assembly is regarded not merely
('73', 294, 0, 1, 560477) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 295
('73', 294, 1, 2, 560527) in terms of the Government of India Act but as an instrument to be used for solving questions which representatives of different commu nities composing the nation can be expected to solve if they had unrestricted powers.
('73', 294, 1, 3, 560748) And the Government of India Act does not pre vent the use of the Assemblies for solving the many problems which are outside its scope but which are necessary for national progress.
('73', 294, 1, 4, 560929) Looked at from the point of view here suggested, the Speakers position assumes very high importance, greater than that of the Prime Minister.
('73', 294, 1, 5, 561071) For he has to discharge the functions of a judge while he occupies the chair.
('73', 294, 1, 6, 561149) He has to give impartial and just rulings.
('73', 294, 1, 7, 561192) He has to enforce decorum and laws of courtesy between members.
('73', 294, 1, 8, 561256) He has to be calm in the midst of storms.
('73', 294, 1, 9, 561298) He has opportunities of winning over opponents which no other member of the House can possibly have.
('73', 294, 1, 10, 561399) Now if a Speaker outside the House ceases to be impartial and indulges in party polemics, he cannot possibly carry the weight he would if he observed impartiality and calmness everywhere.
('73', 294, 1, 11, 561587) I claim that if a Speaker cultivates the habit of uniform impartiality outside his own very limited sphere, he will enhance the Congress prestige.
('73', 294, 1, 12, 561734) He can, if he realizes the unique opportunity his office gives him, pave the way for the solution of the Hindu Muslim tangle as also many others.
('73', 294, 1, 13, 561880) Thus in my opinion the Speaker, if he has to be that not only inside but outside the House, must be a first class Congressman.
('73', 294, 1, 14, 562007) As a man too he has to have a character without reproach.
('73', 294, 1, 15, 562065) He must be able, fearless, naturally just, and above all truthful and non violent in thought, word and deed.
('73', 294, 1, 16, 562174) Then he may stand on any platform he likes.
('73', 294, 1, 17, 562218) Harijan, 16 7 1938
('73', 294, 2, 18, 562237) 362. SOME OBJECTIONS
('73', 294, 3, 19, 562258) A Muslim correspondent writes:
('73', 294, 4, 20, 562289) During the last four months opinions have been appearing in the Urdu Press regarding the Wardha scheme.
('73', 294, 4, 21, 562393) As usual nobody seems to have read the report carefully or to have thought out the subject of basic educations.
('73', 294, 4, 22, 562505) The objections centre round three points:
('73', 294, 5, 23, 562547) (a) that religious instruction has been completely ignored;
('73', 294, 6, 24, 562607) (b) that boys and girls are to be taught together; and
('73', 294, 7, 25, 562662) (c) that a respect for all religions is to be inculcated.
('73', 294, 8, 26, 562720) These objections have been culled from the Urdu Press.
('73', 294, 8, 27, 562775) Religious instruction in the sense of denominational religion has been deliberately omitted.
('73', 294, 8, 28, 562868) Unless there is a State religion it is very
('73', 295, 0, 1, 562912) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 296
('73', 295, 1, 2, 562954) difficult, if not impossible, to provide religious instruction as it would mean providing for every denomination.
('73', 295, 1, 3, 563068) Such instruction is best given at home.
('73', 295, 1, 4, 563108) The State should allow enough time for every child to receive such instruction at home or otherwise.
('73', 295, 1, 5, 563209) It is also conceivable that the State should provide facilities for private tuition by those denominations which may wish to instruct their children at school provided that such instruction is paid for by such denominations.
('73', 295, 1, 6, 563434) As for co education, the Zakir Husain Committee has not made it compulsory.
('73', 295, 1, 7, 563510) Where there is a demand for a separate school for girls, the State will have to make provision.
('73', 295, 1, 8, 563606) The question of co education has been left open.
('73', 295, 1, 9, 563655) It will regulate itself according to the time spirit.
('73', 295, 1, 10, 563709) So far as I am aware the members of the Committee were not all of one mind.
('73', 295, 1, 11, 563785) Personally I have an open mind.
('73', 295, 1, 12, 563817) I think that there are just as valid reasons for as against co education.
('73', 295, 1, 13, 563891) And I would not oppose the experiment wherever it is made.
('73', 295, 1, 14, 563950) As to the necessity of teaching equal regard for all religions, I personally hold strong views.
('73', 295, 1, 15, 564046) Till we reach that happy state, I see no prospect of real unity among all the different communities.
('73', 295, 1, 16, 564147) I regard it as fatal to the growth of a friendly spirit among the children belonging to the different faiths if they are taught either that their religion is superior to every other or that it is the only true religion.
('73', 295, 1, 17, 564367) If that exclusive spirit is to pervade the nation, the necessary corollary would be that there should be separate schools for every denomi nation with freedom to each to decry every other, or that the mention of religion must be entirely prohibited.
('73', 295, 1, 18, 564617) The result of such a policy is too dreadful to contemplate.
('73', 295, 1, 19, 564677) Fundamental principles of ethics are common to all religions.
('73', 295, 1, 20, 564739) These should certainly be taught to the children and that should be regarded as adequate religious instruction so far as the schools under the Wardha scheme are concerned.
('73', 295, 1, 21, 564911) Harijan, 16 7 1938
('73', 295, 2, 22, 564930) 363. A FALLACY
('73', 295, 3, 23, 564945) July 16, 1938 An A.I.S.A. agent asks what he is to say to his co workers who have formed a union and presented him with terms.
('73', 295, 3, 24, 565072) I regard the for mation of such unions a fallacy.
('73', 295, 3, 25, 565122) The workers have evidently missed the scope and the message of the A.I.S.A. It is a philanthropic organization formed by the Congress and has been given an autonomous charter for the specific purpose of developing the central village industry of hand spinning and all it implies.
('73', 295, 3, 26, 565402) Those who are
('73', 296, 0, 1, 565416) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 297
('73', 296, 1, 2, 565466) engaged in this voluntary organization not only derive no pecuniary advantage from it but are expected, if they can, to give their labour free of any hire.
('73', 296, 1, 3, 565622) And since in this the poorest country in the world many persons cannot do so, a large number are paid an emolument only enough to sustain them.
('73', 296, 1, 4, 565766) Whilst every attempt is made to make them comfortable, they are not regarded as employees in the ordinary sense.
('73', 296, 1, 5, 565879) There are no profits shared by anyone.
('73', 296, 1, 6, 565918) If there are share holders or proprietors, they are the spinners, weavers and the like.
('73', 296, 1, 7, 566006) Even the consumers are not beneficiaries.
('73', 296, 1, 8, 566048) They are expected to wear khadi not because it is cheaper or better to look at than mill cloth, but because it gives employment to the largest number of half starved half employed persons, mostly women.
('73', 296, 1, 9, 566251) The whole of the takings go to these dumb artisans after deducting the salaries and other expenses incurred in running this vast philanthropic organization.
('73', 296, 1, 10, 566408) If, therefore, any body of workers form unions as against the Association, they are against the artisans.
('73', 296, 1, 11, 566514) What they take has to come out of the pockets of the artisans or the consumers.
('73', 296, 1, 12, 566594) It would be manifestly absurd to tax the consumers in the interest of the workers.
('73', 296, 1, 13, 566677) Will they, the workers, not realize that the agents are themselves as much workers as they themselves?
('73', 296, 1, 14, 566780) In several cases the agents are purely honorary.
('73', 296, 1, 15, 566829) It is of course a different thing where an agent is found to be going beyond his sphere of duty and acting as if he was the lord and master of, instead of being co worker with, the men working with and under him.
('73', 296, 1, 16, 567042) In such a case the workers have their remedy through the central office but surely not through unions after the orthodox style.
('73', 296, 1, 17, 567170) In the one case they are a necessity, in the other they are not only superfluous, but they are, as I have said above, a fallacy and, if persisted in on a wide scale, they may kill the Asso ciation of which they are part creators and trustees.
('73', 296, 2, 18, 567413) Harijan, 16 7 1938

('73', 303, 1, 2, 576774) 376. LETTER TO NAWAB OF BHOPAL

('73', 303, 3, 9, 577108) This means 35 per month for 3 years at the end of which Harold should finish his education.
('73', 303, 3, 10, 577200) Dr. Ansari has left petty debts amounting to Rs. 12,000. I know the intimate friendship that existed between you and the late Dr. Ansari.
('73', 303, 3, 11, 577338) I know too that you sent some help after Dr. Ansaris death.
('73', 303, 3, 12, 577398) But as Zohra and Shaukat were talking to me I could not help thinking of you and asking you to come to the rescue if it is at all possible for you to do so.

('73', 303, 3, 14, 577613) For I know that you had known Dr. Ansari before I had the privilege of knowing him.
('73', 303, 3, 15, 577697) I hope you are keeping excellent health.

('73', 310, 0, 1, 586775) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 311
('73', 310, 1, 2, 586825) 389. WHAT IS SARVODAYA?
('73', 310, 2, 3, 586849) SEGAON, July 21, 1938 Sarvodaya is impossible without satyagraha.
('73', 310, 2, 4, 586915) The word satyagraha should be understood here in its etymological sense.
('73', 310, 2, 5, 586988) There can be no insistence on truth where there is no non violence.
('73', 310, 2, 6, 587056) Hence the attainment of sarvodaya depends upon the attainment of non violence.
('73', 310, 2, 7, 587135) The attainment of non violence in its turn depends upon tapascharya.
('73', 310, 2, 8, 587204) Tapascharya, again, should be pure.
('73', 310, 2, 9, 587240) Ceaseless effort, discretion, etc., should form part of it.
('73', 310, 2, 10, 587300) Pure tapascharya leads to pure knowledge.
('73', 310, 2, 11, 587342) Experience shows that although people talk of non violence, many are mentally so lazy that they do not even take the trouble of familiarizing themselves with the facts.
('73', 310, 2, 12, 587511) Take an example.
('73', 310, 2, 13, 587528) India is a poor country.
('73', 310, 2, 14, 587553) We wish to do away with poverty.
('73', 310, 2, 15, 587586) But how many people have made a study of how this poverty came about, what its implications are, how it can be removed, etc.?
('73', 310, 2, 16, 587712) A devotee of non violence, should be full of such knowledge.
('73', 310, 2, 17, 587773) It is the duty of Sarvodaya to create such means and not to enter into controversies.
('73', 310, 2, 18, 587859) Editors of Sarvodaya should forget Gandh ism.
('73', 310, 2, 19, 587905) There is no such thing as Gandhism.
('73', 310, 2, 20, 587941) I have not put anything new before India; I have only presented an ancient thing in a new way.
('73', 310, 2, 21, 588036) I have tried to utilize it in a new field.
('73', 310, 2, 22, 588079) Hence my ideas cannot be appropriately called Gandhism.
('73', 310, 2, 23, 588135) We shall adopt truth wherever we find it, praise it wherever we see it, and pursue it.
('73', 310, 2, 24, 588222) In other words, in every sentence of Sarvodaya, we should catch a glimpse of non violence and knowledge.
('73', 310, 3, 25, 588327) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 7680.

('73', 311, 9, 14, 589125) 392. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('73', 311, 10, 15, 589155) SEGAON, July 21, 1938
('73', 311, 11, 16, 589177) KRISHNACHANDRA, I re read your letter with care.
('73', 311, 11, 17, 589226) I think that my answer should have sufficed.
('73', 311, 11, 18, 589271) The only answer to the question as to when the desire for procreation may be regarded justified is when a couple desires offspring without desiring sexual pleasure.
('73', 311, 11, 19, 589436) This was believed so in the case of Dasharatha.
('73', 311, 11, 20, 589484) The whole process has been given the character of dharma.
('73', 311, 11, 21, 589542) What you write about the mastery over sexual passion is correct.
('73', 311, 11, 22, 589607) My interpretation of  1 is that he who is wholly free from attachment will not kill at all.
('73', 311, 11, 23, 589699) Thus the expression may be regarded as an exaggeration.
('73', 311, 11, 24, 589755) My walking up to Wardha may not be called dharma but it is not adharma either.
('73', 311, 11, 25, 589834) The same is true of the utterance on procreation.
('73', 311, 11, 26, 589884) Now this answers all your doubts.
('73', 311, 11, 27, 589918) If not, put them to me in the form of questions and I shall answer.

('73', 314, 3, 4, 591861) BHAI JAYAPRAKASH, Prabha writes in great distress that you totally neglect your health.
('73', 314, 3, 5, 591949) The decision to go to Malabar also seems to be cracking up.
('73', 314, 3, 6, 592009) After all even for your own work preservation of health is necessary.
('73', 314, 3, 7, 592079) I would request you to go for the sake of Prabhas peace if not for any other reason.
('73', 314, 3, 8, 592164) Her health too is not good.
('73', 314, 3, 9, 592192) But she will automatically improve when you get well.
('73', 314, 3, 10, 592246) I hope you will follow my advice.

('73', 315, 7, 12, 593455) 398. HOW NON VIOLENCE WORKS
('73', 315, 8, 13, 593483) A Congress leader said to me the other day in the course of our conversation, How is it that in quality the Congress is not what it used to be in 1920 25 ?
('73', 315, 8, 14, 593639) It has deteriorated.
('73', 315, 8, 15, 593660) Ninety percent of the members are not carrying out the Congress discipline.
('73', 315, 8, 16, 593736) Can you not do something to mend this state of things ? The question is apposite and timely.
('73', 315, 8, 17, 593829) I cant shirk responsibility by saying I am no longer in the Congress.
('73', 315, 8, 18, 593899) I have gone out of it for the purpose of serving it better.
('73', 315, 8, 19, 593959) I know that I still influence the Congress policy.
('73', 315, 8, 20, 594010) As the author of the Congress constitution of 1920. I must hold myself responsible for such deterioration as is avoidable.
('73', 315, 8, 21, 594133) The Congress started with an initial handicap in 1920. Very few believed in truth and non violence as a creed.
('73', 315, 8, 22, 594244) Most members accepted them as a policy.
('73', 315, 8, 23, 594284) It was inevitable.
('73', 315, 8, 24, 594303) I had hoped that many would accept them as their creed after they had watched the working of the Congress under the new policy.
('73', 315, 8, 25, 594431) Only some did, not many.
('73', 315, 8, 26, 594456) In the beginning stages, the change that came over the foremost leaders was profound.
('73', 315, 8, 27, 594542) Readers will recall the letters from the late Pandit Motilal Nehru and Deshbandhu Das reproduced in Young India.
('73', 315, 8, 28, 594655) They had experienced a new joy and a new hope in a life of self denial, simplicity and self sacrifice.
('73', 315, 8, 29, 594758) The Ali Brothers had almost become fakirs.
('73', 315, 8, 30, 594801) As we toured from place to place, I watched with delight the
('73', 316, 0, 1, 594862) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 317
('73', 316, 1, 2, 594912) change that was coming over the Brothers.
('73', 316, 1, 3, 594954) What was true of these four leaders was true of many others whom I can name.
('73', 316, 1, 4, 595031) The enthusiasm of the leaders had infected the rank and file.
('73', 316, 1, 5, 595093) But this phenomenal change was due to the spell of swaraj in one year.
('73', 316, 1, 6, 595164) The conditions I had attached to the fulfilment of the formula were forgotten.
('73', 316, 1, 7, 595243) Khwaja Saheb Abdul Majid even went so far as to suggest that, as the general of the satyagraha army, which the Congress had then become and still is (if only Congressmen realize the meaning of satyagraha), I should have made sure that the conditions were such that they would be fulfilled.
('73', 316, 1, 8, 595533) Perhaps he was right.
('73', 316, 1, 9, 595555) Only I had no such prevision in me.
('73', 316, 1, 10, 595591) The use of non violence on a mass scale and for political purposes was even for myself an experiment.
('73', 316, 1, 11, 595693) I could not therefore dogmatize.
('73', 316, 1, 12, 595726) My conditions were meant to be a measure of popular response.
('73', 316, 1, 13, 595788) They might or might not be fulfilled.
('73', 316, 1, 14, 595826) Mistakes, miscalculations were always possible.
('73', 316, 1, 15, 595874) Be that as it may, when the fight for swaraj became prolonged and Khilafat ceased to be a live issue, enthusiasm began to wane, confidence in non violence even as a policy began to be shaken, and untruth crept in.
('73', 316, 1, 16, 596088) People who had no faith in the twin virtues or the khadi clause stole in, and many even openly defied the Congress constitution.
('73', 316, 1, 17, 596217) The evil has continued to grow.
('73', 316, 1, 18, 596249) The Working Committee has been making some attempt to purge the Congress of the evil but has not been able to put its foot down and risk the loss of numbers on the Congress register.
('73', 316, 1, 19, 596432) I myself believe in quality rather than quantity.
('73', 316, 1, 20, 596482) But there is no such thing as compulsion in the scheme of non violence.
('73', 316, 1, 21, 596554) Reliance has to be placed upon ability to reach the intellect and the heartthe latter rather than the former.
('73', 316, 1, 22, 596664) It follows that there must be power in the word of a satyagraha generalnot the power that the possession of limitless arms gives, but the power that purity of life, strict vigilance, and ceaseless application produce.
('73', 316, 1, 23, 596882) This is impossible without the observance of brahmacharya.
('73', 316, 1, 24, 596941) It must be as full as it is humanly possible.
('73', 316, 1, 25, 596987) Brahmacharya here does not mean mere physical self control.
('73', 316, 1, 26, 597047) It means much more.
('73', 316, 1, 27, 597067) It means complete control over all the senses.
('73', 316, 1, 28, 597114) Thus an impure thought is a breach of brahmacharya; so is anger.
('73', 316, 1, 29, 597179) All power comes from the preservation and sublimation of the vitality that is responsible for creation of life.
('73', 316, 1, 30, 597291) If the vitality is husbanded instead of being dissipated, it is transmuted into creative energy of the highest order.
('73', 316, 1, 31, 597409) This vitality is continuously and even unconsciously dissipated by evil, or even
('73', 317, 0, 1, 597490) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 317, 1, 2, 597532) rambling, disorderly, unwanted thoughts.
('73', 317, 1, 3, 597573) And since thought is the root of all speech and action, the quality of the latter corresponds to that of the former.
('73', 317, 1, 4, 597690) Hence perfectly controlled thought is itself power of the highest potency and can become self acting.
('73', 317, 1, 5, 597792) That seems to me to be the meaning of the silent prayer of the heart.
('73', 317, 1, 6, 597862) If man is after the image of God, he has but to will a thing in the limited sphere allotted to him and it becomes.
('73', 317, 1, 7, 597977) Such power is impossible in one who dissipates his energy in any way whatsoever, even as steam kept in a leaky pipe yields no power.
('73', 317, 1, 8, 598110) The sexual act divorced from the deliberate purpose of generation is a typical and gross form of dissipation and has therefore been specially and rightly chosen for condemnation.
('73', 317, 1, 9, 598289) But in one who has to organize vast masses of mankind for non violent action the full control described by me has to be attempted and virtually achieved.
('73', 317, 1, 10, 598443) This control is unattainable save by the grace of God.
('73', 317, 1, 11, 598498) There is a verse in the second chapter of Gita which freely rendered means.: Sense effects remain in abeyance whilst one is fasting or whilst the particular sense is starved, but the hankering does not cease except when one sees God face to face. 1 This control is not mechanical or temporary.
('73', 317, 1, 12, 598792) Once attained it is never lost.
('73', 317, 1, 13, 598824) In that state vital energy is stored up without any chance of escaping by the innumerable outlets.
('73', 317, 1, 14, 598923) It has been said that such brahmacharya, if it is at all attainable, can be so only by cave dwellers.
('73', 317, 1, 15, 599025) A brahmachari, it is said, should never see, much less touch a woman.
('73', 317, 1, 16, 599095) Doubtless a brahmachari may not think of, speak of, see or touch a woman lustfully.
('73', 317, 1, 17, 599179) But the prohibition one finds in books on brahmacharya is mentioned without the important adverb.
('73', 317, 1, 18, 599277) The reason for the omission seems to be that man is no impartial judge in such matters, and therefore cannot say when he is or is not affected by such contacts.
('73', 317, 1, 19, 599438) Cupids visitations are often unperceivable.
('73', 317, 1, 20, 599482) Difficult though therefore brahmacharya is of observance when one freely mixes with the world.
('73', 317, 1, 21, 599577) it is not of much value if it is attainable only by retirement from the world.
('73', 317, 1, 22, 599656) Anyway, I have practised brahmacharya for over thirty years with considerable success though living in the midst of activities.
('73', 317, 1, 23, 599784) After the decision to lead the life of a brahmachari there was little change in my outward practice, except with my wife.
('73', 317, 1, 24, 599906) In the course of my work among the Indians in South Africa, I mixed freely with women.
('73', 317, 1, 25, 599993) There was hardly an Indian woman in the Transvaal and Natal
('73', 317, 2, 26, 600053) 1 Bhagavad Gita, II.
('73', 318, 0, 1, 600074) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 319
('73', 318, 1, 2, 600124) whom I did not know.
('73', 318, 1, 3, 600145) They were so many sisters and daughters to me.
('73', 318, 1, 4, 600192) My brahmacharya was not derived from books.
('73', 318, 1, 5, 600236) I evolved my own rules for my guidance and that of those who, at my invitation, had joined me in the experiment.
('73', 318, 1, 6, 600349) If I have not followed the prescribed restrictions, much less have I accepted the description found even in religious literature of woman as the source of all evil and temptation.
('73', 318, 1, 7, 600529) Owing as I do all the good there may be in me to my mother, I have looked upon woman never as an object for satisfaction of sexual desire but always with the veneration due to my own mother.
('73', 318, 1, 8, 600720) Man is the tempter and aggressor.
('73', 318, 1, 9, 600754) It is not woman whose touch defiles man but he is often himself too impure to touch her.
('73', 318, 1, 10, 600843) But recently a doubt has seized me as to the nature of the limitation that a brahmachari or brahmacharini should put upon himself or herself regarding contacts with the opposite sex.
('73', 318, 1, 11, 601026) I have set limitations which do not satisfy me.
('73', 318, 1, 12, 601074) What they should be I do not know.
('73', 318, 1, 13, 601109) I am experimenting.
('73', 318, 1, 14, 601129) I have never claimed to have been a perfect brahmachari of my definition.
('73', 318, 1, 15, 601203) I have not acquired that control over my thoughts that I need for my researches in non violence.
('73', 318, 1, 16, 601300) If my non violence is to be contagious and infectious, I must acquire greater control over my thoughts.
('73', 318, 1, 17, 601404) There is perhaps a flaw somewhere which accounts for the apparent failure of leadership adverted to in the opening sentence of this writing.
('73', 318, 1, 18, 601545) My faith in non violence remains as strong as ever.
('73', 318, 1, 19, 601597) I am quite sure that not only should it answer all our requirements in our country, but that it should, if properly applied, prevent the bloodshed that is going on outside India and is threatening to overwhelm the Western world.
('73', 318, 1, 20, 601826) My aspiration is limited.
('73', 318, 1, 21, 601852) God has not given me the power to guide the world on the path of non violence.
('73', 318, 1, 22, 601931) But I have imagined that he has chosen me as His instrument for presenting non violence to India for dealing with her many ills.
('73', 318, 1, 23, 602060) The progress already made is great.
('73', 318, 1, 24, 602096) But much more remains to be done.
('73', 318, 1, 25, 602130) And yet I seem to have lost the power to evoke the needed response from Congressmen in general.
('73', 318, 1, 26, 602226) It is a bad carpenter who quarrels with his tools.
('73', 318, 1, 27, 602277) It is a bad general who blames his men for faulty workmanship.
('73', 318, 1, 28, 602340) I know I am not a bad general.
('73', 318, 1, 29, 602371) I have wisdom enough to know my limitations.
('73', 318, 1, 30, 602416) God will give me strength enough to declare my bankruptcy if such is to be my lot.
('73', 318, 1, 31, 602499) He will perhaps take me away when I am no longer wantedfor the work which I have been permitted to do for nearly half a century.
('73', 318, 1, 32, 602628) But I do entertain the hope that there is yet work for me to do, that the darkness that seems to have enveloped me will disappear,
('73', 319, 0, 1, 602759) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 319, 1, 2, 602801) and that, whether with another battle more brilliant than the Dandi March or without, India will come to her own demonstrably through non violent means.
('73', 319, 1, 3, 602954) I am praying for the light that will dispel the darkness.
('73', 319, 1, 4, 603012) Let those who have a living faith in non violence join me in the prayer.
('73', 319, 1, 5, 603085) Harijan, 23 7 1938
('73', 319, 2, 6, 603104) 399. DUTY OF KHADI WEARERS
('73', 319, 3, 7, 603131) July 23, 1938 I have before me several letters, some protesting against the constant rise in the price of khadi, and some piteously appealing to me to show the way to poor middle class people for buying dear khadi.
('73', 319, 3, 8, 603346) The A. I. S. A. exists only for the betterment of the khadi producers, the majority of whom are poor women spinners.
('73', 319, 3, 9, 603463) I hold that the Association cannot be satisfied till every woman who puts in an honest hour in spinning gets one anna per hour.
('73', 319, 3, 10, 603591) We are on the point of reaching half an anna per hour, and if the consumers and the Congress Governments do their duty, the Association expects to give the anna per hour much earlier than most people expect.
('73', 319, 3, 11, 603799) This must mean some rise in the price of khadi, but not a proportionate rise.
('73', 319, 3, 12, 603877) City people should know that ceaseless effort is being made to evoke greater skill among the artisans so that the whole of the increase in the wages may not fall upon khadi.
('73', 319, 3, 13, 604051) Overhead charges are also being constantly reduced.
('73', 319, 3, 14, 604103) Skill overhead increases with experience.
('73', 319, 3, 15, 604145) But sixteen times increase in the wages of spinners cannot all be brought about merely by increased efficiency Therefore some rise in the price of khadi is inevitable with the increase in the wages.
('73', 319, 3, 16, 604344) This is being unequally distributed among the different varieties so that the heaviest rise will take place in the khadi that is purchased by the monied classes.
('73', 319, 3, 17, 604506) Everything that can be done to ease the burden on poor buyers is being done and will be done by the Association.
('73', 319, 3, 18, 604619) But khadi wearers should know that the economics of khadi are different from the ordinary economics which are based on competi tion in which patriotism, sentiment and humanity play little or no part.
('73', 319, 3, 19, 604819) Khadi economics are based on patriotism sentiment and humanity.
('73', 319, 3, 20, 604883) Before the new policy of the Association was laid down, its aim was to cheapen khadi, mostly in disregard of the wages of the
('73', 320, 0, 1, 605009) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 321
('73', 320, 1, 2, 605059) spinners, the most helpless artisans perhaps in the world.
('73', 320, 1, 3, 605118) This con tinued for nearly a decade.
('73', 320, 1, 4, 605155) It was a mistaken ploicy, but the mistake was unconscious and based on faulty reasoning.
('73', 320, 1, 5, 605244) I must take the largest share of the blame for the mistake.
('73', 320, 1, 6, 605304) Khadi wearers had the sole benefit of the mistake.
('73', 320, 1, 7, 605355) Is it right for them to complain when the mistake is being repaired and the spinners are gradually being paid what is their due ?
('73', 320, 1, 8, 605485) The Association has expected hearty co operation from the khadi wearers and I am glad to be able to say that on the whole the increase in the price of khadi has not been resented by them.
('73', 320, 1, 9, 605673) Many consider it a privilege that they are partners in the tardy justice that is being done to the dumb sisters whose need is infinitely greater than that of the wearers of khadi.
('73', 320, 1, 10, 605853) I know that there are many middle class persons who find it difficult to make the two ends meet, and for them every additional anna becomes a problem.
('73', 320, 1, 11, 606004) And they will not spin.
('73', 320, 1, 12, 606028) They have my sym pathy.
('73', 320, 1, 13, 606052) But they cannot have it both ways.
('73', 320, 1, 14, 606087) If they will not spin, they should cut down their requirements or reduce other expenses.
('73', 320, 1, 15, 606176) In this climate we do not need the clothes we use.
('73', 320, 1, 16, 606227) Where there is a will there is a way.
('73', 320, 1, 17, 606265) A correspondent suggests that khadi is mainly supported by the poor middle class, and contends that if the prices are not brought down to the level at which they can buy it, it will not survive me.
('73', 320, 1, 18, 606463) If that is the condition on which alone khadi can live, it deserves to predecease me.
('73', 320, 1, 19, 606549) Happily there is a fallacy behind the argument.
('73', 320, 1, 20, 606597) The question of cheapness mainly affects the city dwellers.
('73', 320, 1, 21, 606657) If all of them, rich and poor, took to khadi, they could hardly use more than ten percent of the possible production of khadi.
('73', 320, 1, 22, 606784) The rest has to be used by the producers themselves who are villagers.
('73', 320, 1, 23, 606855) The question of price does not affect them materially, if at all.
('73', 320, 1, 24, 606921) It is true that khadi has not penetrated the villages to the extent expected.
('73', 320, 1, 25, 606999) During the transition period, therefore, it has to depend upon the patriotic spirit of city dwellers both rich and poor.
('73', 320, 1, 26, 607120) Those who believe in the message of khadi will not consider any price too dear for khadi.
('73', 320, 1, 27, 607210) It is the only real insurance against famine and unemployment.
('73', 320, 1, 28, 607273) Even if India were to be industrialized overnight, much of the unemployment would remain.
('73', 320, 1, 29, 607363) In this country the problem is to find work for a whole nation which has one fourth of her time without occupation.
('73', 320, 1, 30, 607479) If pestilence, poverty and blood shed are to be avoided, there is no remedy but khadi and
('73', 321, 0, 1, 607569) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 321, 1, 2, 607611) other village industries.
('73', 321, 1, 3, 607637) Those who believe in this mission of khadi and who believe also in a living wage being paid to the spinners, will not grudge the increase that has to be made in the price of khadi.
('73', 321, 1, 4, 607818) They may rely upon the Association moving with the utmost caution.
('73', 321, 1, 5, 607885) The past two years experience warrants the hope that the public welcome the increase in the wages that the spinners are receiving.
('73', 321, 2, 6, 608016) Harijan, 23 7 1938

('73', 331, 1, 2, 622110) 420. LETTER TO C. A. TULPULE
('73', 331, 2, 3, 622139) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 29, 1938
('73', 331, 3, 4, 622169) DEAR FRIEND, Though the fullest brahmacharya is unattainable whilst one is in the flesh a very near approach is perfectly possible in my opinion.
('73', 331, 3, 5, 622315) The way to it is yet unexplored.
('73', 331, 3, 6, 622348) So far as I am concerned I am exploring it in the hope of finding it.
('73', 331, 3, 7, 622418) What progress I have made makes me hopeful.
('73', 331, 3, 8, 622462) The sphere of limitations simply means the limits nature has put upon us as fractions of the Divine.
('73', 331, 3, 9, 622563) A fraction is not the whole.
('73', 331, 3, 10, 622592) If a person has as full control as is possible for a human, his willing affects his surroundings.
('73', 331, 3, 11, 622690) I have personal experience of that in several instances.
('73', 331, 3, 12, 622747) It may be argued that correspondence between the willing and the alleged response were mere coincidences.
('73', 331, 3, 13, 622853) For such doubters I have no reply.
('73', 331, 3, 14, 622888) I hope this answers all your questions.
('73', 331, 4, 15, 622928) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('73', 331, 5, 16, 622958) SHRI C. A. TULPULE TILAK ROAD POONA CITY
('73', 331, 6, 17, 622999) From a copy:C.W. 2898. Courtesy:C.A. Tulpule
('73', 331, 7, 18, 623044) 421. A CLARIFICATION
('73', 331, 8, 19, 623065) July 30, 1938 An ex professor writes a long letter on my article on higher education 1 from which I take the following relevant extracts :
('73', 331, 9, 20, 623204) There is need for further clarification of your views on higher education as they have appeared in the Harijan of the 9th inst.
('73', 331, 9, 21, 623332) I agree with many of your viewsespecially those regarding the enormity of the damage caused by the foreign medium.
('73', 331, 9, 22, 623447) I also feel that what passes as higher education today contains much brass mistaken for gold.
('73', 331, 9, 23, 623541) I speak from experience as I was a teacher in the line of the so called higher education till very recently.
('73', 331, 10, 24, 623650) 1 Vide Higer Education
('73', 332, 0, 1, 623673) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 333
('73', 332, 1, 2, 623723) your third conclusion about general revenue and claims of higher education and its corollary, viz., that universities should be self supporting, that has left me unconvinced.
('73', 332, 1, 3, 623898) I believe that every country to be a progressive country must have sufficient faicilities for the pursuit of all branches of knowledge not merely chemistry, medicine and engineering, but every kind of knowledgeliterature, philosophy, history, sociology, both abstract and applied.
('73', 332, 1, 4, 624179) All higher pursuits require many facilities which cannot be had without State support.
('73', 332, 1, 5, 624266) A country depending only on voluntary effort for such pursuits is sure to fall behind and suffer.
('73', 332, 1, 6, 624364) It can never hope to be free and be able to maintain that freedom.
('73', 332, 1, 7, 624431) The State must be jealously watchful over the position of higher education in all fields.
('73', 332, 1, 8, 624521) Voluntary effort must be there and we must have our Nuffields and Rockefellers 1. But the State cannot and must not be allowed to remain a silent spectator.
('73', 332, 1, 9, 624678) It must actively come forward to organize, help and direct.
('73', 332, 1, 10, 624738) I wish you to clarify this aspect of the question.
('73', 332, 2, 11, 624789) You say at the end of your article:Under my scheme there will be more and better libraries. I do not find the scheme you speak of in your article, nor am I able to make out how more and better libraries and laboratories will come into being thereunder.
('73', 332, 2, 12, 625042) I am of opinion that such libraries and laboratories must be maintained and so long as donors and voluntary agencies are not coming forward in sufficient numbers, the State cannot divest itself of this responsibility.
('73', 332, 2, 13, 625260) My article is clear enough if the expression definite use mentioned in it is given its extensive meaning.
('73', 332, 2, 14, 625366) I have not pictured a poverty stricken Indian containing ignorant millions.
('73', 332, 2, 15, 625442) I have pictured to myself an India continually progressing along the lines best suited to her genius.
('73', 332, 2, 16, 625544) I do not, however, picture it as a third class or even a first class copy of the dying civilization of the West.
('73', 332, 2, 17, 625657) If my dream is fulfilled, and every one of the seven lacs of villages becomes a well living republic in which there are no illiterates, in which no one is idle for want of work, in which everyone is usefully occupied and has nourishing food, well ventilated dwellings and sufficient khadi for covering the body, and in which all the villagers know and observe the laws of hygiene and sanitation, such a State must have varied and increasing needs, which it must supply unless it would stagnate.
('73', 332, 2, 18, 626152) I can therefore well imagine the State financing all the education my correspondent mentions and much more that I could add.
('73', 332, 2, 19, 626277) And if the
('73', 332, 3, 20, 626288) 1 Viscount Nuffield established the Nuffield Foundation fo medical, scientific and social research and John D. Rockefeller similarly endowed many charitable corporations for the advancement of learning.
('73', 333, 0, 1, 626491) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 333, 1, 2, 626533) State has such requirements, surely it will have corresponding libraries.
('73', 333, 1, 3, 626607) What, however, according to my view the State will not have is an army of B.A.s and M.A.s with their brains sapped with too much cramming and minds almost paralysed by the impossible attempt to speak and write English like Englishmen.
('73', 333, 1, 4, 626842) The majority of these have no work, no employment.
('73', 333, 1, 5, 626893) And when they have the latter, it is usually clerkships at which most of the knowledge gained during their twelve years of high school and college is of no use whatsoever to them.
('73', 333, 1, 6, 627073) University training becomes self supporting when it is utilized by the State.
('73', 333, 1, 7, 627151) It is criminal to pay for a training which benefits neither the nation nor the individual.
('73', 333, 1, 8, 627242) In my opinion there is no such thing as individual benefit which cannot be proved to be also national benefit.
('73', 333, 1, 9, 627353) And since most of my critics seem to be agreed that the existing higher education, and for that matter both primary and secondary, are not connected with realitites, it cannot be of benefit to the State.
('73', 333, 1, 10, 627557) When it is directly based on realities and is wholly given through the mother tongue, I shall perhaps have nothing to say against it.
('73', 333, 1, 11, 627691) To be based on realities is to be based on national, i.e., State, requirements.
('73', 333, 1, 12, 627771) And the State will pay for it.
('73', 333, 1, 13, 627802) Even when that happy time comes, we shall find that many institutions will be conducted by voluntary contributions.
('73', 333, 1, 14, 627918) They may or may not benefit the State.
('73', 333, 1, 15, 627957) Much of what passes for education today in India belongs to that category and would therefore not be paid for from the general revenue, if I had the way.
('73', 333, 1, 16, 628111) But the agreement of my critics on the two main points, medium and the realities, cannot lull me to rest.
('73', 333, 1, 17, 628217) They have criticized and tolerated all these many years the existing system.
('73', 333, 1, 18, 628294) Now that the opportunity for reform has come, Congressmen ought to become impatient.
('73', 333, 1, 19, 628379) If the medium is changed at once and not gradually, in an incredibly short time we shall find text books and teachers coming into being to supply the want.
('73', 333, 1, 20, 628535) And if we mean business, in a years time we shall find that we need never have been party to the tragic waste of the nations time and energy in trying to learn the essentials of culture through a foreign medium.
('73', 333, 1, 21, 628747) The condition of success is undoubtedly that provincial languages are introduced at once in Government offices and courts, if the Provincial Governments have the power or the influence over the courts.
('73', 333, 1, 22, 628949) If we believe in the necessity of the reform, we can achieve it in no time.
('73', 333, 2, 23, 629025) Harijan, 30 7 1938
('73', 334, 0, 1, 629044) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 335
('73', 334, 1, 2, 629094) 422. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('73', 334, 2, 3, 629122) [July 30, 1938] With regard to the recent ministerial crisis in C.P., it has been suggested that Dr. Khare was asked to sign a prepared draft containing humiliating admissions.
('73', 334, 2, 4, 629299) I have no hesitation in saying that this suggestion is baseless.
('73', 334, 2, 5, 629364) Dr. Khare accompanied by several members of the Working Committee, came to Segaon on July 25, and after discussion he prepared a statement to be issued to the Press.
('73', 334, 2, 6, 629530) 1 I made corrections and additions to it, but after reading my corrections and additions he changed his mind and said that he would consult his friends and then decide whether to issue it or not.
('73', 334, 2, 7, 629726) In my opinion there was nothing humiliating in it, if only because it contained nothing but facts.
('73', 334, 2, 8, 629825) I hardly think Dr. Khare will dispute this.
('73', 334, 2, 9, 629869) The best thing, however, is for the public to have the statement itself before it.
('73', 334, 2, 10, 629952) I invite Dr. Khare to publish a facsimile of it.
('73', 334, 2, 11, 630001) I have kept no copy of his own with my amendments.
('73', 334, 2, 12, 630052) He took it with him to Nagpur.
('73', 334, 3, 13, 630083) Harijan, 6 8 1938

('73', 336, 10, 22, 632544) 428. INSTRUCTIONS ON PRECAUTIONS AGAINST CHOLERA 2
('73', 336, 11, 23, 632595) August 1, 1938 Segaon has cholera.
('73', 336, 11, 24, 632630) Therefore nothing should be taken by anybody from Segaon.
('73', 336, 11, 25, 632688) Those who have got cholera may be isolated where they are, unless they could be conveniently shifted elsewhere.
('73', 336, 12, 26, 632800) 1 Not traceable 2 According to the source D.B. Kalelkar, Narhar Athavale, Pandurang Bhurke, Gajanan Dabke, Murlidhar Sabnis and Shripad Joshi had drunk of unfermented palm juice, nira, on July 30 and on July 31 developed symptoms which the Civil Surgeon of Wardha diagnosed as those of cholera.
('73', 336, 12, 27, 633095) On August 1 Aryanayakum reported the matter to Gandhiji who wrote out these instructions.
('73', 336, 12, 28, 633185) Athavale, Bhurke and Dabke later succumbed to the disease.
('73', 337, 0, 1, 633244) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 337, 1, 2, 633286) No one should be allowed near them except those who have been entrusted with nursing.
('73', 337, 1, 3, 633372) The latter should be bare bodied or have special clothes which should be put away when they come into contact with the outside world.
('73', 337, 1, 4, 633506) They should wash themselves in per manganated water (rose coloured) every time they come in contact with others.
('73', 337, 1, 5, 633619) All should drink only boiled water and have simple food, rather underfeed than overfeed.
('73', 337, 1, 6, 633708) Those who have no scruples may be inoculated.
('73', 337, 1, 7, 633754) Send me report through Mahadev.
('73', 337, 1, 8, 633786) He starts from Maganwadi at about 12.30 p.m.
('73', 337, 1, 9, 633831) Did Kaka drink nira ?
('73', 337, 1, 10, 633853) It should be stopped for the time being.
('73', 337, 1, 11, 633894) The Bombay Chronicle, 12 9 1938

('73', 343, 4, 8, 641493) 443. LETTER TO VIJAYA N. PATEL

('73', 343, 10, 23, 642218) 444. FUNCTIONS OF THE WORKING COMMITTEE
('73', 343, 11, 24, 642258) August 6, 1938 Press cuttings on the ministerial crisis in C.P. 1 make most
('73', 343, 12, 25, 642334) 1 The crisis in the C. P. Ministry had begun soon after the assumption of office by the ministry headed by N. B. Khare.
('73', 343, 12, 26, 642454) First a minister had made recommendation direct to the Governor concerning the release of certain convicts (see footnote 1, p.
('73', 343, 12, 27, 642581) 178) and later there were differences among ministers leading to tension.
('73', 343, 12, 28, 642655) In April the
('73', 344, 0, 1, 642668) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 345
('73', 344, 1, 2, 642718) instructive reading.
('73', 344, 1, 3, 642739) That the resolution of the Working Committee condemning the action of veteran leader like Dr. Khare would come in for some severe criticism was a foregone conclusion.
('73', 344, 1, 4, 642906) 1 But I was not prepared for the ignorance betrayed by the critics on the functions of the Working Committee.
('73', 344, 1, 5, 643016) Dr. Khare was not only guilty of gross indiscipline in flouting the warnings of the Parliamentary Board, but he betrayed incompet ence as a leader by allowing himself to be fooled by the Governor, or not knowing that by his precipitate action he was compromising the Congress.
('73', 344, 1, 6, 643293) He heightened the measure of indiscipline by refusing the advice of the Working Committee to make a frank confession of his guilt and withdraw from leadership.
('73', 344, 1, 7, 643453) The Working committee would have been guilty of gross neglect of duty if it had failed to condemn Dr. Khares action and adjudge his incompetence.
('73', 344, 1, 8, 643599) I write these lines in sorrow.
('73', 344, 1, 9, 643630) It was no pleasure to me to advise the Working Committee to pass the resolution it did.
('73', 344, 1, 10, 643718) Dr. Khare is a friend.
('73', 344, 1, 11, 643741) He has run to my aid as a physician when quick medical assistance was needed.
('73', 344, 1, 12, 643819) He has often come to me for advice and guidance and has expressed himself to be in need of my blessings.
('73', 344, 1, 13, 643924) I banked on this friendship when, on the 25th ultimo, I appealed to him bravely to stand down and work as a camp follower.
('73', 344, 1, 14, 644047) He himself seemed to be willing but he was badly advised, and not only declined to accept the Working Committees advice but sent a letter instead, questioning the propriety of the whole of the action of the Working Committee in connection with his ill advised and hasty resignation of office and equally hasty formation of a new Cabinet.
('73', 344, 1, 15, 644385) I hope that on mature reflection he would have seen the error of his conduct and taken the action of the Working Committee in a sportsmanlike spirit.
('73', 344, 1, 16, 644535) There is no moral turpitude involved in his action.
('73', 344, 1, 17, 644587) He is a good fighter.
('73', 344, 1, 18, 644609) He is free with his purse in helping friends.
('73', 344, 1, 19, 644655) These are qualities of which anyone may be proud.
('73', 344, 1, 20, 644705) But these qualities need not make the possessor a good Prime Minister
('73', 344, 2, 21, 644775) Congress Parliamentary Committee managed at a meeting at Pachmarhi to resolve these differences and achieve a settlement.
('73', 344, 2, 22, 644897) But Khare did not keep the terms of the settlement and continued to function without consulting the Working Committee or the Parliamentary Committee.
('73', 344, 2, 23, 645047) In order to get rid of certain ministers he submitted his resignation to the Governor and asked the ministers concerned to resign.
('73', 344, 2, 24, 645178) When they refused to oblige, the Governor dismissed them and later invited Khare to form a new ministry.
('73', 344, 2, 25, 645283) 1 The Working Committee condemning the action of Khare held him to be unworthy of holding positions of responsibility in the Congress organization.
('73', 344, 2, 26, 645431) For the text of the resolution, vide Working Committee Resolution on C. P. Crisis
('73', 345, 0, 1, 645513) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 345, 1, 2, 645555) or administrator.
('73', 345, 1, 3, 645573) I would urge him as a friend to work for the time being as a camp follower and give the Congress the benefit of the admitted qualities I have recited.
('73', 345, 1, 4, 645724) If Dr. Khare was impatient of his recalcitrant colleagues he should have rushed, not to the Governor, but to the Working Comm ittee and tendered his resignation.
('73', 345, 1, 5, 645886) If he felt aggrieved by its decision, he could have gone to the A. I. C. C. But in no case could any Minister take internal quarrels to the Governor and seek relief through him without the previous consent of the Working Committee.
('73', 345, 1, 6, 646118) If the Congress machinery is slow moving, it can be made to move faster.
('73', 345, 1, 7, 646191) If the men at the helm are self seekers or worthless, the A. I. C. C. is there to remove them.
('73', 345, 1, 8, 646286) Dr. Khare erred grievously in ignoring or, what is worse, not knowing this simple remedy and rushing to the Governor on the eve of the meeting of the Working Committee to end his agony.
('73', 345, 1, 9, 646472) It is suggested that the men who succeed him are self seekers and incapable, and can make no approach to Dr. Khare in character.
('73', 345, 1, 10, 646601) If they are as they have been portrayed by their critics, they are bound to fail in the discharge of the onerous responsibility they have undertaken.
('73', 345, 1, 11, 646751) But here again the Working Committee has to work within the limits prescribed for it.
('73', 345, 1, 12, 646837) It cannot impose ministers on a province.
('73', 345, 1, 13, 646879) After all they are elected members, and if the party that has the power to elect them chooses to do so, the Working Committee has no authority to interfere so long as they remain under discipline and are not known to be persons unworthy of public confidence.
('73', 345, 1, 14, 647138) But the crisis should surely put the Ministers on their mettle.
('73', 345, 1, 15, 647202) It is up to them to show by their conduct that the charges levelled against them are baseless, and that they are capable of discharging their trust ably and selflessly.
('73', 345, 1, 16, 647371) It speaks well for the impartiality of the Indian Press in that several journals found it necessary to condemn the action of the Working Committee in pronouncing the opinion it did on the part H. E. the Governor of C. P. played during the unfortunate crisis.
('73', 345, 1, 17, 647630) I am not in the habit of hastily judging opponents.
('73', 345, 1, 18, 647682) The criticism of the resolution has left me unconvinced of any injustice done to the Governor by it.
('73', 345, 1, 19, 647783) In estimating his action, time is of the essence.
('73', 345, 1, 20, 647833) In accepting the resignations of Dr. Khare and his two colleagues, in demanding resignations from the other three Ministers, in expecting an immediate answer, in summarily rejecting their explanation and
('73', 346, 0, 1, 648037) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 347
('73', 346, 1, 2, 648087) dismissing them, and for this purpose keeping himself, his staff and the poor Ministers awake almost the whole night, the Governor betrayed a haste which I can only call indecent.
('73', 346, 1, 3, 648267) Nothing would have been lost if instead of accepting Dr. Khares resignation there and then, he had awaited the meeting of the Working Committee which was to meet two days after the strange drama.
('73', 346, 1, 4, 648463) In dealing with a similar crisis the Bengal Governor acted differently from the C. P. Governor.
('73', 346, 1, 5, 648559) Of course, the Governors action conformed to the letter of the law, but it killed the spirit of the tacit compact between the British Government and the Congress.
('73', 346, 1, 6, 648722) Let the critics of the Working Committees action read the Viceroys carefully prepared declaration which, among other declarations, induced the Working Committee to try the office experiment, and ask themselves whether the Governor was not bound to take official notice of what was going on between the Working Committee and Dr. Khare and his colleagues.
('73', 346, 1, 7, 649076) These indisputable facts lead one to the irresistible conclusion that the Governor, in his eagerness to discredit the Congress, kept a vigil and brought about a situation which he knew was to be uncomfortable for the Congress.
('73', 346, 1, 8, 649303) The unwritten compact between the British Government and the Congress is a gentlemans agreement in which both are expected to play the game.
('73', 346, 1, 9, 649444) The resolution therefore gives English administrators more credit than evidently the critics would give.
('73', 346, 1, 10, 649549) Englishmen are sports men.
('73', 346, 1, 11, 649576) They have ample sense of humour.
('73', 346, 1, 12, 649609) They can hit hard and take a beating also in good grace.
('73', 346, 1, 13, 649666) I have no doubt that the Governor will take the Congress resolution in good part.
('73', 346, 1, 14, 649748) But whether he does so or not, the Working Committee was bound to express what it felt about the Governors action.
('73', 346, 1, 15, 649863) It wishes to avoid a fight if it can; it will take it up if it must.
('73', 346, 1, 16, 649932) If the fight is to be avoided, the Governors must recognize the Congress as the one national organization that is bound some day or other to replace the British Government.
('73', 346, 1, 17, 650105) The U.P., the Bihar and the Orissa Governors waited for the Congress lead when a crisis faced them.
('73', 346, 1, 18, 650205) No doubt, in the three cases, it was obviously to their interest to do so.
('73', 346, 1, 19, 650280) Is it to be said that in C.P. it was obviously to the British interest to precipitate the crisis in order to discomfit the Congress?
('73', 346, 1, 20, 650413) The Working Committee resolution is a friendly warning to the British Government that if they wish to avoid an open rupture with the Congress, the powers that be should not allow a repetition of what happened at Nagpur on the night of the 20th July.
('73', 347, 0, 1, 650663) 348 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 347, 1, 2, 650705) Let us understand the functions of the Congress.
('73', 347, 1, 3, 650754) For internal growth and administration, it is as good a democratic organization as any to be found in the world.
('73', 347, 1, 4, 650867) But this democratic organization has been brought into being to fight the greatest imperialist power living.
('73', 347, 1, 5, 650976) For this external work, therefore, it has to be likened to an army.
('73', 347, 1, 6, 651044) As such it ceases to be democratic.
('73', 347, 1, 7, 651080) The central authority possesses plenary powers enabling it to impose and enforce discipline on the various units working under it.
('73', 347, 1, 8, 651211) Provincial organizations and Provincial Parliamentary Boards are subject to the central authority.
('73', 347, 1, 9, 651310) It has been suggested that, whilst my thesis holds good when there is active war in the shape of civil resistance going on, it cannot whilst the latter remains under suspension.
('73', 347, 1, 10, 651488) But suspension of civil disobedience does not mean suspension of war.
('73', 347, 1, 11, 651558) The latter can only end when India has a Constitution of her own making.
('73', 347, 1, 12, 651631) Till then the Congress must be in the nature of an army.
('73', 347, 1, 13, 651688) Democratic Britain has set up an ingenious system in India which, when you look at it in its nakedness, is nothing but a highly organized efficient military control.
('73', 347, 1, 14, 651854) It is not less so under the present Government of India Act.
('73', 347, 1, 15, 651915) The Ministers are mere puppets so far as the real control is concerned.
('73', 347, 1, 16, 651987) The collectors and the police, who sir them today, may at a mere command from the Governors, their real masters, unseat the Ministers, arrest them and put them in lock up.
('73', 347, 1, 17, 652159) Hence it is that I have suggested that the Congress has entered upon office not to work the Act in the manner expected by the framers but in a manner so as to hasten the day of substituting it by a genuine Act of Indias own coining.
('73', 347, 1, 18, 652392) Therefore the Congress conceived as a fighting machine has to centralize control and guide every department and every Congress man, however highly placed, and expect unquestioned obedience.
('73', 347, 1, 19, 652582) The fight cannot be fought on any other terms.
('73', 347, 1, 20, 652629) They say this is fascism pure and simple.
('73', 347, 1, 21, 652671) But they forget that fascism is the naked sword.
('73', 347, 1, 22, 652720) Under it Dr. Khare should lose his head.
('73', 347, 1, 23, 652761) The Congress is the very antithesis of fascism, because it is based on non violence pure and undefiled.
('73', 347, 1, 24, 652865) Its sanctions are all moral.
('73', 347, 1, 25, 652894) Its authority is not derived from the control of panoplied black shirts.
('73', 347, 1, 26, 652967) Under the Congress regime Dr. Khare can remain the hero of Nagpur, and the students and citizens of Nagpur, and for that matter other places, may execrate me or/and the Working Committee without a hair of the demonstrators heads being touched so long as they remain non violent.
('73', 347, 1, 27, 653246) That is the glory and strength of the Congressnot its weakness.
('73', 347, 1, 28, 653310) Its authority is derived from that non violent attitude.
('73', 348, 0, 1, 653367) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 349
('73', 348, 1, 2, 653417) the only purely non violent political organization of importance, to my knowledge, throughout the world.
('73', 348, 1, 3, 653522) And let it continue to be the boast of the Congress that it can command the willing and hearty obedience from its followers, even veterans like Dr. Khare, so long as they choose to belong to it.
('73', 348, 2, 4, 653717) Harijan, 6 8 1938

('73', 349, 5, 11, 655331) 448. TO SEGAON WORKERS
('73', 349, 6, 12, 655354) August 6, 1938 We should bear in mind the following: 1. Spittle is also excretion.
('73', 349, 6, 13, 655437) Therefore we must never clean the untensils where we spit or wash our soiled hands.
('73', 349, 6, 14, 655521) 2. We should not use water direct from the tap as it wastes water and not many poeple can use the tap at the same time.
('73', 349, 6, 15, 655641) Therefore everyone must collect the water he needs in a lota.
('73', 349, 6, 16, 655703) 3. No one should brush his teeth at the place meant for washing hands and mouth.
('73', 349, 6, 17, 655784) The teeth must be brushed at a separate place and the mouth rinsed with water from a lota.
('73', 349, 6, 18, 655875) Brushing of the teeth too should be done near a hedge or where people do not happen to walk.
('73', 349, 6, 19, 655968) 4. We should never spit or blow the nose on the paths.
('73', 349, 8, 20, 656023) From a copy of the Hindi: C.W. 4674

('73', 350, 5, 10, 656769) 450. HARIJANS AND HINDU HOTELS
('73', 350, 6, 11, 656800) The strike of the Hindu hotel owners does credit neither to them, nor to Ahmedabad, nor does it afford protection to Hindusim.
('73', 350, 6, 12, 656927) These hotel owners could close down their hotels if others did not go to their hotels because of the presence of Harijans there.
('73', 350, 6, 13, 657056) But resorting to strike is tantamount to preventing the Congress Government from doing justice.
('73', 350, 6, 14, 657152) The question arises whether the Hindus on strike are on the side of the Congress or opposed to it.
('73', 350, 6, 15, 657251) Are they enemies of Hinduism or are they its well wishers?
('73', 350, 6, 16, 657310) If they consider themselves supporters of the Congress, they should lovingly feed Harijans despite having to put up with difficulties.
('73', 350, 6, 17, 657445) If, while doing so, other Hindus stop coming to their restaurants, they should put up with this.
('73', 350, 6, 18, 657542) If all Hindu restaurant owners practise this dharma, other Hindus would either be forced to take advantage of those very restaurants or wholly give up eating in such restaurants.
('73', 350, 6, 19, 657721) In the latter eventuality the restaurant owners should look for a new source of livelihood.
('73', 350, 6, 20, 657813) They should on no account forsake their dharma.

('73', 352, 1, 2, 660802) A few words about the duties of the Government.
('73', 352, 1, 3, 660850) So long as public opinion is in favour of the Congress, the dharma of the latter is clear.
('73', 352, 1, 4, 660941) On no account will it tolerate untouchability.
('73', 352, 1, 5, 660988) It will sink or swim with Harijans.
('73', 352, 1, 6, 661024) Even if the Congress can rule over the entire world by doing injustice to Harijans, it should regard it as dirt.

('73', 352, 1, 8, 661210) If no one starts a restaurant which would be open to all, either the municipality or the Government should run such places as required at its own expense.
('73', 352, 1, 9, 661365) If such a restaurant does not find enough customers it could be closed down.
('73', 352, 1, 10, 661442) But not a single Hindu restaurant should be allowed to function which does not permit the entry of Harijans.
('73', 352, 1, 11, 661551) Now a few words to the Harijans.
('73', 352, 1, 12, 661584) Just as Congressmen and sanatanist Hindus have to practise their dharma, so have the Harijans.
('73', 352, 1, 13, 661679) These men and women have to see to it that they do not lose the game which is almost theirs.
('73', 352, 1, 14, 661772) I have before me letters written by some proven Harijan workers.
('73', 352, 1, 15, 661837) In these they have mentioned that at some places either in order to show their enthusiasm or to show their gratitude towards the Government, or for some other reason, Harijans, in large numbers, had surrounded restaurants and attempted to enter them.
('73', 352, 1, 16, 662088) They were not even properly dressed.
('73', 352, 1, 17, 662125) Those who do so render no service to Harijans but rather do them harm.
('73', 352, 1, 18, 662196) They misuse laws laid down by the Government.
('73', 352, 1, 19, 662242) Some rights are such that they cannot be utilized fully as soon as they are given.
('73', 352, 1, 20, 662325) Some time must elapse before they are fully enjoyed and we should patiently put up with it.
('73', 352, 1, 21, 662417) This right to enter restaurants is of this nature.
('73', 352, 1, 22, 662468) Not a single Harijan must visit them to assert a right.
('73', 352, 1, 23, 662524) Any Harijan who is really hungry and is passing by a restaurant, who has the money and is clad in clean clothes, should certainly go to the restaurant.
('73', 352, 1, 24, 662676) He should suffer any insult which he encounters while doing so, he should inform the Harijan Sevak Sangh of this without taking any offence and the latter will certainly take steps to ensure that he is not insulted again.
('73', 352, 1, 25, 662898) And, finally, if steps outside of the law prove to be futile, he will resort to legal help.
('73', 352, 1, 26, 662990) The statement made by Shri Muldas in this connection is very useful.
('73', 352, 1, 27, 663059) Harijan men and women will see it published in the current issue and I hope that they will put it into practice.
('73', 352, 1, 28, 663172) [From Gujarati]
('73', 352, 2, 29, 663188) Harijanbandhu, 7 8 1938

('73', 368, 6, 23, 685374) 484. IS VIOLENCE CREEPING IN?
('73', 368, 7, 24, 685404) Mahadev has passed on to me information containing com plaints about violence being done by Congressmen.
('73', 368, 7, 25, 685509) One complaint is that, in the name of peaceful picketing, picketers are resorting to methods bordering on violence, such as making a living wall beyond which no one can pass without being hurt or hurting those who make the wall.
('73', 368, 7, 26, 685738) As the author of peaceful picketing I cannot recall a single instance in which I had encouraged such picketing.
('73', 368, 7, 27, 685850) A friend has quoted Dharasana against me.
('73', 368, 7, 28, 685892) I had suggested the occupation of salt works.
('73', 368, 7, 29, 685938) But that is wholly inapplicable to the case under consideration.
('73', 368, 7, 30, 686003) In Dharasana the objective was the salt works of which possession had to be taken and maintained as against the Government.
('73', 368, 7, 31, 686127) The action could hardly be called picketing.
('73', 368, 7, 32, 686172) But to prevent workers from going
('73', 369, 0, 1, 686206) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 369, 1, 2, 686248) to their work by standing in front of them is pure violence and must be given up.
('73', 369, 1, 3, 686330) The owners of mills or other factories would be fully justified in invoking the assistance of the police and a Congress Government would be bound to provide it if the Congressmen concerned would not desist.
('73', 369, 1, 4, 686537) Another instance brought to my notice is that of a body of Congressmen having taken possession of the offices of a Congress Committee recognized by the Provincial Congress Committee.
('73', 369, 1, 5, 686720) This is surely unpardonable unruliness.
('73', 369, 1, 6, 686760) The third instance is that of breaking up meetings by shouting and otherwise creating disturbances.
('73', 369, 1, 7, 686860) The fourth is that of reviling capitalists as a class and inciting people to loot them.
('73', 369, 1, 8, 686948) All these are clear instances of violence and indiscipline.
('73', 369, 1, 9, 687008) I am told that such unruliness is on the increase.
('73', 369, 1, 10, 687059) I have before me a letter which bitterly complains that whereas capitalists used to get justice during the old regime, now under the Congress regime they not only get no justice but are even insulted and humiliated.
('73', 369, 1, 11, 687275) There can be no doubt that the British system favours capi talism.
('73', 369, 1, 12, 687342) The Congress, which aims at securing full justice for the famishing millions, cannot favour capitalism.
('73', 369, 1, 13, 687446) But the Congress, so long as it retains non violence as its basic policy, cannot resort to usurpation, much less allow any class of persons to be insulted or humiliated in any way whatsoever or allow any Congressman or a body of Congressmen to take the law into their own hands.
('73', 369, 1, 14, 687725) Nor can the Congress tolerate violent picketing or speeches inciting to violence.
('73', 369, 1, 15, 687807) If violence is not checked in time, the Congress will go to pieces purely from internal decay.
('73', 369, 1, 16, 687902) It is up to the heads of provincial and subordinate committees to root out the evil without the least delay.
('73', 369, 1, 17, 688011) If on the other hand Congressmen in general are tired of non violence, the sooner the first article of the constitution is revised the better it will be for all concerned and the country.
('73', 369, 1, 18, 688199) Let it not be said of the great organization that it used truth and non violence as a cloak to cover untruth and violence.
('73', 369, 2, 19, 688322) Harijan, 13 8 1938
('73', 370, 0, 1, 688341) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 371
('73', 370, 1, 2, 688391) 485. TWISTING OR INTERPRETING?
('73', 370, 2, 3, 688422) A friend writes a long letter with reference to my article on Speakers and Politics.
('73', 370, 2, 4, 688507) 2 What is discussed in the letter can be put thus in the form of a question: When you say that the language of the Government of India Act should be stretched to the farthest limit, so as to give the greatest strength to the movement for Independence, do you imply that the Speaker should, or can, knowingly twist any section of the Act so as to give it the desired meaning?
('73', 370, 2, 5, 688882) I should be surprised if such an implication could be extracted from my article.
('73', 370, 2, 6, 688963) It will amount to encouraging untruth.
('73', 370, 2, 7, 689002) A Speaker who knowingly gives an interpretation contrary to the plain meaning of a text, renders himself unfit for the high office and discredits the Congress cause.
('73', 370, 2, 8, 689168) He must, at all cost, preserve the Congress credit for honesty and integrity.
('73', 370, 2, 9, 689246) What, however, I have meant is that where a section is manifestly capable of two meanings or more, he is bound to give that which favours the national cause.
('73', 370, 2, 10, 689404) And when a section bears only one meaning which is manifestly restrictive of the peoples liberty, he must unhesitatingly give that meaning.
('73', 370, 2, 11, 689544) I have no doubt that such impartiality on the part of a Speaker will enhance his reputation and to the extent increase the moral prestige of the Congress.
('73', 370, 2, 12, 689699) Having discarded violence, the strength of the Congress depends wholly upon the moral fibre and fearlessness of individual Congressmen.
('73', 370, 3, 13, 689835) Harijan, 13 8 1938
