('73', 373, 11, 22, 693290) 493. DISCUSSION WITH HENGCHIH TAO 1
('73', 373, 12, 23, 693326) [Before August 15, 1938] 2
('73', 373, 13, 24, 693353) GANDHIJI: I am exceedingly sorry to receive you when I am in distress.
('73', 373, 13, 25, 693424) I may not break my silence even to speak to you.
('73', 373, 13, 26, 693473) But of course you will say whatever you want to.
('73', 373, 13, 27, 693522) You may speak, I may not.
('73', 373, 13, 28, 693548) Tao explained that he was a member of the Peoples Council of Action of all China.
('73', 373, 13, 29, 693630) This was a body of 140 or 150 drawn from all parties in China, under which the whole of China was united to meet Japanese aggression .
('73', 373, 13, 30, 693765) All parties.
('73', 373, 14, 31, 693778) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desais Notes.
('73', 373, 14, 32, 693817) Since Gandhiji was observing silence his part of the discussion was conducted in writing.
('73', 373, 14, 33, 693907) 2 Vide Letter to Mahadev Desai, 15 8 1938, from which it would appear that Gandhiji had met Tao before that date.
('73', 374, 0, 1, 694021) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 375
('73', 374, 1, 2, 694071) united in fighting the common danger, under one supreme military command of Chiang Kai shek.
('73', 374, 1, 3, 694164) Tao was happy that a Medical Mission from India was sailing to China as a token of Indias sympathy, and he asked Gandhiji if he had any suggestions to offer in order to fight the war to a successful conclusion.
('73', 374, 2, 4, 694375) G. I do not know that I can throw any light on the problem at the present moment.
('73', 374, 2, 5, 694457) My method is so radical that it is wholly inapplicable to your struggle.
('73', 374, 2, 6, 694530) You cannot all of a sudden change the course of the struggle.
('73', 374, 2, 7, 694592) A nation in arms cannot all at once give up arms and accept non violence as its weapon.
('73', 374, 3, 8, 694680) Tao saw the difficulty and explained that the Chinese had not even time to think, the aggression was so sudden and so unprovoked.
('73', 374, 3, 9, 694810) But he would like to discuss problems of national reconstructions.
('73', 374, 3, 10, 694877) He had given up University work in order to take up peasants education and he was deeply interested in the Wardha Education Scheme.
('73', 374, 3, 11, 695009) What exactly is the core of the Scheme? he asked.
('73', 374, 4, 12, 695059) G. The central fact is some village craft through which the whole of the man or the woman in the child can be drawn out.
('73', 374, 5, 13, 695180) But there was the difficulty of teachers, said Prof.
('73', 374, 5, 14, 695233) Tao, and Gandhiji laughed.
('73', 374, 5, 15, 695260) We had the same difficulty.
('73', 374, 5, 16, 695288) Would you have trained teachers to learn a craft or craftsmen to learn the art of teaching? asked Prof.
('73', 374, 6, 17, 695392) G. The average educated man can be expected easily to master a craft.
('73', 374, 6, 18, 695462) Our craftsmen will require much longer time to acquire the necessary general instruction than an educated man, say like you, can require to learn say, carpentry.
('73', 374, 7, 19, 695624) But, said Prof.
('73', 374, 7, 20, 695640) Tao, our educated man is after fat jobs and money.
('73', 374, 7, 21, 695691) How can he be interested in this?
('73', 374, 8, 22, 695725) G. If the scheme is sound and appeals to the educated mind, it must prove attractive in itself and thus wean the educated youth from the lure of gold.
('73', 374, 8, 23, 695876) It must fail, if it does not evoke sufficient patriotism from the educated youth.
('73', 374, 8, 24, 695958) There is one advantage with us.
('73', 374, 8, 25, 695990) Those who have received instruction through the Indian languages cannot enter colleges.
('73', 374, 8, 26, 696078) It is just possible that they will find the scheme attractive.
('73', 374, 9, 27, 696141) Tao was deeply interested in our present political struggle.
('73', 374, 9, 28, 696202) How were we going to acquire power at the centre?
('73', 374, 9, 29, 696252) G. If we are true to our salt in the seven provinces, the accession of strength that will come to us will put us on the way to power at the centre.
('73', 374, 10, 30, 696400) T. But the power is being felt everywhere, and the Congress prestige has risen.
('73', 374, 10, 31, 696480) Has it not?
('73', 375, 0, 1, 696492) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 375, 1, 2, 696534) G. The Congress prestige has risen.
('73', 375, 1, 3, 696570) The people have become conscious of their power and strength.
('73', 375, 1, 4, 696632) The Government also recog nize this.
('73', 375, 1, 5, 696669) My fear is that this power may throw us off our balance.
('73', 375, 2, 6, 696726) Tao reverted to the question of mass education.
('73', 375, 2, 7, 696774) He made an attempt to
('73', 375, 3, 8, 696796) describe the Chinese system of relay teachers whereby each man or woman who had
('73', 375, 4, 9, 696876) learnt something had to pass it on to the next one he or she came across.
('73', 375, 4, 10, 696950) Even the
('73', 375, 5, 11, 696959) child, the little teacher, had to share his or her learning with his illiterate parents,
('73', 375, 6, 12, 697048) and the Chinese through this system were liquidating illiteracy and ignorance on a
('73', 375, 7, 13, 697131) mass scale.
('73', 375, 8, 14, 697143) G. I have no doubt that it can.
('73', 375, 8, 15, 697175) I would like you to write for me a short note on how the relay teachers and the little teachers are taught, how they teach and with what result.
('73', 375, 9, 16, 697320) Tao said he would gladly comply.
('73', 375, 10, 17, 697353) Tao would not go without a message from Gandhiji for the people of
('73', 375, 11, 18, 697420) He explained that even a non violent message would be welcome .
('73', 375, 12, 19, 697484) were engaged in a war of self defence, but in other respects they were observing non 
('73', 375, 13, 20, 697570) violence .
('73', 375, 13, 21, 697581) On May 20 Chinese planes had flown over Japanese towns, and they
('73', 375, 14, 22, 697646) might easily have spread death and destruction among the people of Japan in
('73', 375, 15, 23, 697722) retaliation for the bombing of so many Chinese ports by Japan.
('73', 375, 15, 24, 697785) But instead of
('73', 375, 16, 25, 697800) raining bombs they rained handbills and leaflets showing the wrong of the war .
('73', 375, 17, 26, 697880) G. But the self inflicted restraint wont last when the real stress comes.
('73', 375, 17, 27, 697954) The temptation will be irresistible.
('73', 375, 17, 28, 697991) I shall not be surprised.
('73', 375, 17, 29, 698017) It is inevitable.
('73', 375, 17, 30, 698035) There is no love in war.
('73', 375, 17, 31, 698060) We have got to come to the conclu sion that either there is to be complete non violence or undiluted violence.
('73', 375, 17, 32, 698171) Is not this enough message?
('73', 375, 18, 33, 698199) Tao wondered if some day the Chinese might expect to have Gandhiji in
('73', 375, 19, 34, 698269) their midst.
('73', 375, 20, 35, 698282) G. I almost came to your country when those who had invited me had to stop me from going owing to the disturbances that had taken place.
('73', 375, 20, 36, 698419) I do want to see peace reigning in your land during my lifetime.

('73', 389, 11, 23, 717837) 523. HOW TO SAVE HANDLOOM WEAVERS
('73', 389, 12, 24, 717871) August 20, 1938
('73', 389, 13, 25, 717887) The statement that the handloom industry has defied mill competition is only partially true.
('73', 389, 13, 26, 717980) There are not today half as many handloom weavers as there were, say, twenty five years ago.
('73', 389, 13, 27, 718073) There was a time when, as the spinning wheel spun the whole of the yarn
('73', 389, 14, 28, 718145) 1 From the reference to Nana Dharmadhikari in the preceding item.
('73', 389, 14, 29, 718211) 2 The letter was signed by Kanu Gandhi, under instructions from Gandhiji.
('73', 389, 14, 30, 718285) 3 From the reference to rakhi in the letter of August 19 to the addressee.
('73', 390, 0, 1, 718360) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 391
('73', 390, 1, 2, 718410) required by the nation, the handloom wove all the cloth required.
('73', 390, 1, 3, 718476) When the mills were established the spinning wheel all but died out for the very simple reason that it gave a paltry return and was never a whole time occupation.
('73', 390, 1, 4, 718639) But the loom offered stubborn resistance, for the reason, among others, that it was a full time occupation by itself and paid the weaver enough to eke out a living.
('73', 390, 1, 5, 718804) When the spinning mill came, the weaver fell back upon it for his hanks of yarn.
('73', 390, 1, 6, 718885) He even welcomed the change because he could get more evenly spun and stronger yarn.
('73', 390, 1, 7, 718970) Little did he know that he was to become perfectly helpless if the mills for any reason could not supply him with yarn.
('73', 390, 1, 8, 719090) Unlike the village spinner the millowner dictated the price of his yarn.
('73', 390, 1, 9, 719163) By and by the weaver who wove simple patternless khadi could not withstand the mill competition and he died.
('73', 390, 1, 10, 719272) And for the past few years the weaver of fancy cloth has felt the pressure from weaving mills.
('73', 390, 1, 11, 719367) Public taste is slowly but surely changing.
('73', 390, 1, 12, 719411) If the mills cannot exactly copy the patterns woven by the village weaver, they can, as they do, produce new patterns and by efficient advertising attract customers.
('73', 390, 1, 13, 719577) Therefore several thousand Orissa weavers are idle for want of custom.
('73', 390, 1, 14, 719648) A similar cry came to me the other day from Ahmednagar,a strong weaving centre.
('73', 390, 1, 15, 719728) My advice to them all was that if these weaving families would but introduce carding and spinning in their homes, they could be wholly independent of mill yarn and enlist the never failing assistance of the A. I. S. A. It might be that the weavers might not earn as much as before because of part of their time being given to spinning.
('73', 390, 1, 16, 720064) But now, under the revised policy of the A. I. S. A. which aims at giving one anna per hour to the spinner and is actually giving one and half pice per hour, the weaver would hardly feel the reduction in his income.
('73', 390, 1, 17, 720280) And in any case a reduced wage is surely better than starvation.
('73', 390, 1, 18, 720345) Let it be borne in mind that the weaver, in introducing spinning and carding in his family, has to go in for very little outlay.
('73', 390, 1, 19, 720474) The wheel he already has.
('73', 390, 1, 20, 720500) It will no doubt require some improvment.
('73', 390, 1, 21, 720542) He has to invest in a carding bow costing a few annas.
('73', 390, 1, 22, 720597) I understand that the Orissa Government is banishing mill yarn from their jails and restricting their cloth purchases to khadi.
('73', 390, 1, 23, 720725) They deserve congratulations for conforming to the constructive pro gramme of the Congress.
('73', 390, 1, 24, 720817) Let the workers in charge of the organiza tion remember the prescription herein suggested, and they will find that production of the yarn required will be the easiest by educating
('73', 391, 0, 1, 720997) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 391, 1, 2, 721039) the weavers to take up spinning.
('73', 391, 1, 3, 721072) They will also by this method pro bably find that khadi can be, comparatively speaking, more cheaply produced than if they were to wait till they trained raw villagers to become efficient spinners.
('73', 391, 1, 4, 721270) No doubt they will have to introduce spinning in all the villages.
('73', 391, 1, 5, 721337) For that is the goal of the A. I. S. A. But they may not neglect the handloom weavers till the high purpose is accomplished.
('73', 391, 1, 6, 721462) Harijan, 20 8 1938
('73', 391, 2, 7, 721481) 524. RECENT RIOTS IN BURMA
('73', 391, 3, 8, 721508) August 20, 1938 A telegram says :
('73', 391, 4, 9, 721542) Burma riots deserve more attention than you paid.
('73', 391, 4, 10, 721592) Whatever Govern ment information, no peace till tenth, when I left Rangoon by aeroplane.
('73', 391, 4, 11, 721681) Indians frightfully perturbed.
('73', 391, 4, 12, 721712) They adopted your non violence, suffered terribly.
('73', 391, 4, 13, 721763) Effective steps urgently solicited.
('73', 391, 4, 14, 721799) The step that I took immediately on receipt of a wire from Rangoon was the only effective step I could then take.
('73', 391, 4, 15, 721913) 1 I was not then even in possession of facts.
('73', 391, 4, 16, 721959) Now there is before me a narrative of the cause of the Burmese fury.
('73', 391, 4, 17, 722028) It appears that a Burman wrote a tract in disparagement of Islam some time ago.
('73', 391, 4, 18, 722108) A Burman Buddhist who had become a convert to Islam wrote a counter tract attacking the original and also attacking Buddhism.
('73', 391, 4, 19, 722234) No Indian had a hand in the writing of the counter tract.
('73', 391, 4, 20, 722292) It did not attract notice at once, but the Burmese Press fiercely criticized it and inflamed the Burmese mind.
('73', 391, 4, 21, 722403) The result was the savagery which took many precious, innocent lives and destroyed property worth, it is said, millions.
('73', 391, 4, 22, 722524) Nor was it confined to Rangoon; it spread throughout Burma wherever there were Indian settlers.
('73', 391, 4, 23, 722620) If, as my correspondent says,Indians adopted your (i.
('73', 391, 4, 24, 722674) e., my) non violence, I can only say they suffered less than they would have otherwise done.
('73', 391, 4, 25, 722767) Non violence has no limits.
('73', 391, 4, 26, 722795) If a particular dose does not seem to answer, more should be administered.
('73', 391, 4, 27, 722870) It is a never failing remedy.
('73', 391, 4, 28, 722900) But why call it my non violence?
('73', 391, 4, 29, 722933) Probably the wire is a gentle rebuke to me, so much as to say that my remedy failed.
('73', 391, 4, 30, 723018) The pertinent question is whether they believed in non violence as a sure remedy against violence, or was it undertaken because there was no help for it ?
('73', 391, 4, 31, 723173) I, however, need not wait for a reply.
('73', 391, 4, 32, 723212) If one is to believe the papers,
('73', 391, 5, 33, 723245) 1 Vide Telegram to President, Burma Congress Committee, 5 8 1938
('73', 392, 0, 1, 723310) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 393
('73', 392, 1, 2, 723360) there was not complete non violence practised by the Indians.
('73', 392, 1, 3, 723422) I have, however, no difficulty in believing that a considerable number observed non violence whether from belief or necessity.
('73', 392, 1, 4, 723549) The question for consideration, however, is: what of the future ? There will no doubt be some kind of an inquiry.
('73', 392, 1, 5, 723663) There may be some compensation paid to the losers.
('73', 392, 1, 6, 723714) There would be some punish ment meted out to the offenders who are not likely to be the prime movers but their dupes.
('73', 392, 1, 7, 723832) I must confess that I am uninterested in these proceedings.
('73', 392, 1, 8, 723892) There will be no insurance against future out breaks.
('73', 392, 1, 9, 723946) Indians in Burma should realize that they are at the mercy of the inhabitants of Burma.
('73', 392, 1, 10, 724034) They have no Government in India that can really afford them protection.
('73', 392, 1, 11, 724107) We know what is happening in the other parts of the world; nor is it to be wondered at.
('73', 392, 1, 12, 724195) England will never go to war with any nation or country because it has insulted or wronged Indian settlers in that country.
('73', 392, 1, 13, 724319) It may, it will, make represen tations, sincere of course; it will lodge energetic protests even.
('73', 392, 1, 14, 724417) But there her help will end.
('73', 392, 1, 15, 724446) And in a case like the Burmese riots, the relief that the Government of India can afford will be next to nothing.
('73', 392, 1, 16, 724560) What does it do when riots take place in India itself ?
('73', 392, 1, 17, 724616) It can do very little after they are over.
('73', 392, 1, 18, 724659) The utmost it can do is to take measures to quell riots when they take place.
('73', 392, 1, 19, 724737) What have even Congress Governments been able to do after the riots that have recently taken place in some Congress Provinces?
('73', 392, 1, 20, 724864) They do not admit of relief being granted to the sufferers except in rare cases.
('73', 392, 1, 21, 724945) What is possible in Burma I do not know.
('73', 392, 1, 22, 724986) I am concerned with attainment of permanent peace in so far as permanence is possible in this very impermanent life.
('73', 392, 1, 23, 725103) When once religious animosity is roused, it has a knack of repeating itself with periodic regularity, if radical measures are not adopted by the communities concerned.
('73', 392, 1, 24, 725271) One such measure is cultivation of mutual respect for the several religions professed by the parties.
('73', 392, 1, 25, 725373) If the Buddhists of Burma have little regard for Islam and the Muslims for Buddhism, the seeds of dissension are there.
('73', 392, 1, 26, 725493) They will take little watering to sprout into the savagery such as we saw the other day.
('73', 392, 1, 27, 725582) I would, therefore, suggest a mutual understanding of these great religions.
('73', 392, 1, 28, 725659) My fear is that at the bottom of the riots there is an anti Indian
('73', 393, 0, 1, 725726) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 393, 1, 2, 725768) feeling, due, perhaps to economic causes.
('73', 393, 1, 3, 725810) For though Muslims seem to have suffered most, Hindus too seem to have come in for a fair share of the Burman fury.
('73', 393, 1, 4, 725926) Therefore, Indian settlers must see to it that their dealings with the Burmans are fair and above board.
('73', 393, 1, 5, 726031) It is said that everything is fair in trade, and that no turpitude attaches to a trader taking advantage of his customers ignorance and demanding from him even an unconscionable price for his goods.
('73', 393, 1, 6, 726230) That kind of dealings will surely acerbate feelings.
('73', 393, 1, 7, 726283) Wherever we have gone, even before the British rulers took possession of our country, we have depended solely on the goodwill of those among whom we have lived and with whom we have traded.
('73', 393, 1, 8, 726473) Such is the history of our relations with Zanzibar, Aden, Java, etc.
('73', 393, 1, 9, 726542) Times have however changed.
('73', 393, 1, 10, 726570) The people all over the world have become conscious of their rights.
('73', 393, 1, 11, 726639) Whereas formerly foreign settlers in other lands did questionable things with impunity, they cannot do so now.
('73', 393, 1, 12, 726750) Honesty has never been so much proved to be the best policy as it is now for those who do not or cannot back their dishonesty with gunpowder and poison gas.
('73', 393, 1, 13, 726907) If India is to escape that training and is to adopt, as a free nation, peace as her motto in every walk of life and in every country where her children go, they will have to practise strictest honesty in their human dealings.
('73', 393, 1, 14, 727133) To the Burmese friends one word.
('73', 393, 1, 15, 727166) When I was in Burma some years ago, Burmese priests were good enough to invite me to their conference and honour me with their address under the shadow of the mighty Pagoda.
('73', 393, 1, 16, 727340) They were good enough, as Buddhists, to claim me as one of them.
('73', 393, 1, 17, 727405) It therefore hurt me when I read of the mob fury which knew no distinction of sex or age and wreaked vengeance on persons who could never have had anything to do with the offending pamphlet.
('73', 393, 1, 18, 727596) I have the greatest veneration for the Buddha.
('73', 393, 1, 19, 727643) He is one of the greatest preachers of peace.
('73', 393, 1, 20, 727689) The gospel of the Buddha is gospel of love.
('73', 393, 1, 21, 727733) It passes comprehension how representatives of that faith could give themselves up to savagery, and that on an apparently flimsy pretext.
('73', 393, 1, 22, 727871) The pity of it is that, if the newspaper reports were true, even priests, the repositories of the Buddhas gospel, were to be seen among the mob, not stilling its fury, but actually taking part in loot, arson and murder.
('73', 393, 1, 23, 728091) Would that the wise men among them would do a little heart searching and take steps to prevent a recurrence of the tragedy which all right thinking persons must deplore !
('73', 393, 2, 24, 728262) Harijan, 20 8 1938

('73', 398, 9, 18, 734557) 536. REPLY TO NAGPUR DEPUTATIONISTS 2
('73', 398, 10, 19, 734595) August 21, 1938 I realize your regard and support for Dr. Khare, I also have great love for Dr. Khare, but we who are fighting the independence battle have to forget family relations while doing our duty.
('73', 398, 10, 20, 734800) After introspection I found that no wrong or injustice had been done to Dr. Khare.
('73', 398, 10, 21, 734883) You have no material for comparison.
('73', 398, 10, 22, 734920) I myself framed the Congress constitution in 1920 wherein the All India Congress is the final appellate authority which everybody can approach.
('73', 398, 10, 23, 735064) The Working
('73', 398, 11, 24, 735076) 1 A word is illegible here.
('73', 398, 11, 25, 735104) 2 A deputation of over 150 students and others led by V. A. Khare had come from Nagpur to see Gandhiji.
('73', 398, 11, 26, 735208) They expressed support for Dr. N. B. Khare and demanded withdrawal of the Working Committees resolution concerning him.
('73', 398, 11, 27, 735328) Since Gandhiji was observing silence he wrote out this reply
('73', 399, 0, 1, 735389) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 399, 1, 2, 735431) Committee or leaders referred to, if found guilty, deserve punishment.
('73', 399, 1, 3, 735502) I advise you to prepare your case in favour of Dr. Khare to be placed before the A. I. C. C. I have said whatever I wanted to.
('73', 399, 1, 4, 735629) I cannot address a public meeting at seventy.
('73', 399, 1, 5, 735675) I have no desire to prove Dr. Khares guilt, nor do I wish you to lessen your love for Dr. Khare.
('73', 399, 1, 6, 735772) Time alone will tell and Dr. Khare will admit his mistake.

('73', 409, 0, 1, 748749) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 409, 1, 2, 748791) 558. MY SO CALLED INCONSISTENCIES
('73', 409, 2, 3, 748825) During my student days improperly so called (for they properly began after the period of examinations and are not yet over for me) I learnt a saying of Emersons which I never forgot.
('73', 409, 2, 4, 749008) Foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, said the sage.
('73', 409, 2, 5, 749077) I cannot be a little mind, for foolish consistency has never been my hobgoblin.
('73', 409, 2, 6, 749157) My critics are shocked over my recent remarks on picketing.
('73', 409, 2, 7, 749217) They think that in describing as a species of violence the formation of a living wall of pickets in order to prevent the entry of persons into picketed places, I have contradicted my sayings and doings during the civil disobedience campaign.
('73', 409, 2, 8, 749459) If such is really the case, my recent writing must be held as cancelling my comparatively remote sayings and doings.
('73', 409, 2, 9, 749576) Though my body is deteriorating through age, no such law of deterioration, I hope, operates against wisdom which I trust is not only not deteriorating but even growing.
('73', 409, 2, 10, 749745) Whether it is or not, my mind is clear on the opinion I have given on picketing.
('73', 409, 2, 11, 749826) If it does not appeal to Congressmen, they may reject it, and if they do, they will violate the laws of peaceful picketing.
('73', 409, 2, 12, 749950) But there is no discrepancy between my past practice and the present statement.
('73', 409, 2, 13, 750030) When civil disobedience was first orgainzed by me in South Africa, my companions discussed with me the question of picketing.
('73', 409, 2, 14, 750156) The registration office had to be picketed in Johannesburg, and the suggestion made was that we should form there a living wall of pickets.
('73', 409, 2, 15, 750296) I at once rejected the idea as violent.
('73', 409, 2, 16, 750336) And pickets were posted in marked positions in a big public square so that no one could elude the eagle eyes of the pickets and yet everyone could go to the registration office, if he liked, without touching anyone.
('73', 409, 2, 17, 750552) Reliance was put upon the force of public opprobrium which would be evoked by the publication of the names of black legs.
('73', 409, 2, 18, 750674) This method was copied by me here when liquor shops were to be picketed.
('73', 409, 2, 19, 750747) The work was specially entrusted to the women as better representatives of non violence than men.
('73', 409, 2, 20, 750845) Thus there was no question of the formation of a living wall.
('73', 409, 2, 21, 750907) Many unauthorized things were no doubt done during those days as they are now.
('73', 409, 2, 22, 750986) But I cannot recall a single instance in which I countenanced the kind of picketing condemned by the article that has come in for sharp criticism.
('73', 409, 2, 23, 751133) And is there really any difficulty about regarding a living wall of pickets as naked violence ?
('73', 409, 2, 24, 751229) What is the difference between force used against a man wanting to do a
('73', 410, 0, 1, 751301) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 411
('73', 410, 1, 2, 751351) particular thing, and force exercised by interposing yourself between him and the deed ?
('73', 410, 1, 3, 751440) When, during the non co operation days, the students in Benares blocked the passage to the University gates I had to send a peremptory message and, if my recollection serves me right, I strongly condemned their action in the columns of Young India.
('73', 410, 1, 4, 751689) Of course I have no argument against those who hold different views from mine regarding violence and non violence.
('73', 410, 1, 5, 751804) The other inconsistency imputed to me has reference to my advice to factory owners to invoke the assistance of the police to defend themselves against what I have described as violent picketing.
('73', 410, 1, 6, 751999) Having condemned the Ministries for calling in the aid of the police and even the military for suppressing riots, how could I advise employers of labour to ask for, and Ministers to supply, police assis tance, ask my critics.
('73', 410, 1, 7, 752225) This is what I wrote 1 in Harijan about the Ministerial action in U.P.:
('73', 410, 2, 8, 752297) It has been suggested that when we have our independence riots and the like will not occur.
('73', 410, 2, 9, 752389) This seems to me to be an empty hope, if in the course of the struggle for freedom we do not understand and use the technique of non violent action in every conceivable circumstance.
('73', 410, 2, 10, 752572) To the extent that the Congress Ministers have been obliged to make use of the police and the military, to that extent, in my opinion, we must admit our failure.
('73', 410, 2, 11, 752734) That the Ministers could not have done otherwise is unfortunately only too true.
('73', 410, 2, 12, 752815) I should like every Congressman, I should like the Working Committee, to ask themselves why we have failed, if they think with me that we have.
('73', 410, 2, 13, 752959) Surely here there is no condemnation of the Ministers action.I have deplored the necessity for it as I would deplore such necessity in the matter of picketing.
('73', 410, 2, 14, 753119) But till the Congress has developed a peaceful method of dealing with violent crimes, its Ministers must use the police and, I fear, even the military, if they are to undertake the administration of the affairs of the country in the present stage of its career.
('73', 410, 2, 15, 753381) But it will bode ill for them and the country if they do not devise methods of dispensing with the use both of the police and the military or at least of visibly reducing their use to such an extent that he who runs may notice the reduction.
('73', 410, 2, 16, 753623) There certainly is a way.
('73', 410, 2, 17, 753649) I have ventured to give a faint indication of it.
('73', 410, 2, 18, 753699) But it may be that the Congress organization is not really fitted for the great task.
('73', 410, 2, 19, 753785) Without a living faith in non violence, neither the military nor the police can be supplanted.
('73', 410, 3, 20, 753880) 1 Vide Letter to Sharda C. Shah, 22 3 1938
('73', 411, 0, 1, 753923) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 411, 1, 2, 753965) Cries come in from many quarters of growing insubordination, indiscipline and even open violence among Congressmen.
('73', 411, 1, 3, 754081) I hope that the charge is untrue of the majority of Congressmen.

('73', 411, 6, 10, 754382) 560. LETTER TO VALJI G. DESAI
('73', 411, 7, 11, 754412) August 27, 1938
('73', 411, 8, 12, 754428) VALJI, I read your third article and am returning all the three.
('73', 411, 8, 13, 754493) The idea of composing a new Smriti is a tempting one, but I am not qualified.
('73', 411, 8, 14, 754571) If I assume that I am qualified, I would require the leisure that is posible in jail.
('73', 411, 8, 15, 754657) Outside I have no choice.
('73', 411, 8, 16, 754683) I have to take up the work that comes to me and do it as best as I can.
('73', 411, 8, 17, 754755) There is some freedom of choice in jail.
('73', 411, 8, 18, 754796) If you wish to contribute in the compositon of a new Smriti, you will have to go deep into the thing.
('73', 411, 8, 19, 754898) There are many interpolations in the Smritis.
('73', 411, 8, 20, 754944) Some portions, though not interpolations, deserve to be rejected.
('73', 411, 8, 21, 755010) Even in the Vedas everything contained is not eternal truth.
('73', 411, 8, 22, 755071) The Vedas are a mixture of poetry, history and eternal verities.
('73', 411, 8, 23, 755136) We should try to pick out the last.
('73', 411, 8, 24, 755172) We should formulate rules of interpretation.
('73', 411, 8, 25, 755217) And after that, we may place before the people our interpretations right from the Vedas to the Puranas, as the substance of Hinduism.
('73', 411, 8, 26, 755351) You have got the necessary ability for this, but have I ?
('73', 411, 8, 27, 755409) This task is beyond the ability of a single person.
('73', 411, 8, 28, 755461) For this we should have a group from among ourselves.
('73', 411, 8, 29, 755515) You will now get some faint idea about how my mind is working.
('73', 411, 8, 30, 755578) I do know what is dharma, but I do not know how to put it as the Vedas do.
('73', 411, 8, 31, 755653) I am not sufficiently well versed in the Shastras.
('73', 411, 8, 32, 755704) And the most important thing is that I am not completely free from attachment.
('73', 411, 8, 33, 755783) I aspire to be so in this life.
('73', 411, 8, 34, 755815) But I will not feel sorry if I fail.
('73', 411, 8, 35, 755852) I am using all the strength God has given me to destroy attachment, etc.
('73', 411, 8, 36, 755925) It is not impossible for me to attain to that state, but I do not know whether I have that much time left to me.

('73', 415, 1, 2, 760063) 564. DISCUSSION WITH HARIJAN SATYAGRAHIS 1
('73', 415, 2, 3, 760106) [August 27, 1938] 2
('73', 415, 3, 4, 760126) Harijan friends .
('73', 415, 3, 5, 760144) calling themselves satyagrahis marched to Segaon on Saturday last and demanded justice from Gandhiji.
('73', 415, 3, 6, 760246) Gandhiji was of course silent, but he received them and asked them in writing if they would be content with written replies.
('73', 415, 3, 7, 760371) They said they would.
('73', 415, 3, 8, 760393) He asked them to explain the purpose of their visit.
('73', 415, 4, 9, 760446) We gave you notice, their spokesman said, that unless you could have a Harijan appointed as a Cabinet Minister we should go to Segaon and do satyagraha there.
('73', 415, 4, 10, 760605) You asked us to desist.
('73', 415, 4, 11, 760629) We did so and wrote to you to say so.
('73', 415, 4, 12, 760667) But after that, having heard nothing from you we decided to fulfil our promise.
('73', 415, 5, 13, 760747) GANDHIJI: But what do you want, and what do you mean by satyagraha?
('73', 415, 6, 14, 760815) HARIJANS: We want a Harijan to be in the Cabinet and a seat reserved in the Cabinet for a Harijan as there is one reserved for a Mussalman.
('73', 415, 7, 15, 760955) G. But that is not in my power.
('73', 415, 8, 16, 760987) H. It is.
('73', 415, 8, 17, 760997) You were prepared to lay down your life for the Harijans at Yeravda and your fast led to the Yeravda Pact.
('73', 415, 8, 18, 761104) You can do everything for the Harijans.
('73', 415, 9, 19, 761144) G. I am doing all that is in my power.
('73', 415, 9, 20, 761183) But let that be.
('73', 415, 9, 21, 761200) What do you mean by satyagraha?
('73', 415, 10, 22, 761232) H. We will remain here without food until another party from Nagpur comes to relieve us.
('73', 415, 11, 23, 761321) G. You are welcome to do so.
('73', 415, 11, 24, 761350) You want me to provide you with room.
('73', 415, 11, 25, 761388) Well we are cramped for space, but you tell us where you will sit, and we will vacate the place for you.
('73', 415, 12, 26, 761493) H. We will be fasting, and five or six people will have to stay with us to attend to our needs whilst we are fasting.
('73', 415, 13, 27, 761611) G. I am not concerned with that.
('73', 415, 13, 28, 761644) You select the place and we vacate it for you.
('73', 415, 13, 29, 761691) One of the Ashram inmates went out with them to show them over the place.
('73', 415, 13, 30, 761765) He returned to say that they wanted a room adjoining a hut reserved for women and also the verandah in front of it.
('73', 415, 14, 31, 761881) G. Explain to them that that room is reserved for women and
('73', 415, 15, 32, 761941) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desais Notes 2 Desai says the Harijans met Gandhiji on Saturday last.
('73', 415, 15, 33, 762036) This would be August 27.
('73', 416, 0, 1, 762061) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 417
('73', 416, 1, 2, 762111) they might select some other place.
('73', 416, 2, 3, 762147) He did so, but came and reported that they would have no other place.
('73', 416, 3, 4, 762217) G. Vacate it then.
('73', 416, 3, 5, 762236) Let not Ba be perturbed.
('73', 416, 3, 6, 762261) She can come and occupy my room, and I will go there or in the house outside which is built for Aryanayakum.

('73', 421, 1, 2, 768560) 576. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('73', 421, 2, 3, 768591) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 30, 1938
('73', 421, 3, 4, 768623) NARANDAS, Rajkumari Amrit Kaur was born in 1887 A. D. She is the only daughter of the late Raja Sir Harnam Singh.
('73', 421, 3, 5, 768737) The late Raja Saheb was the uncle of the Maharaja of Kapurthala.
('73', 421, 3, 6, 768802) The Rajkumari was educated in England for eight years.
('73', 421, 3, 7, 768857) She has been taking a prominent part in the womens movement since 1928. At present she is President of the All India Womens Conference.
('73', 421, 3, 8, 768993) Her way of living is exceedingly simple.
('73', 421, 3, 9, 769034) She has been wearing khadi for years.
('73', 421, 3, 10, 769072) She is a member of the Spinners Association and the Village Industries Association and takes great interest in both these activities.
('73', 421, 3, 11, 769206) This information should suffice for you.
('73', 421, 3, 12, 769247) Tell Chhaganlal that if he wants to arrange a tour of Kathiawar for her for a few days, he may do so.
('73', 421, 3, 13, 769349) It is not absolutely obligatory to arrange the tour.
('73', 421, 3, 14, 769402) It may be dropped if the atmosphere at present is not favourable.
('73', 421, 3, 15, 769468) I have prepared her for it.
('73', 421, 4, 16, 769496) Blessings from
('73', 421, 5, 17, 769511) BAPU [PS.] The Rajkumari is a Christian by birth, and a Hindu by conduct.
('73', 421, 5, 18, 769585) She cannot be taken to a temple.
('73', 421, 6, 19, 769618) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II.

('73', 426, 12, 20, 776179) [About August 1938] 2
('73', 426, 13, 21, 776201) For what is Rajaram going to Wardha?
('73', 426, 13, 22, 776238) Are the mosambis over?
('73', 426, 13, 23, 776261) Ba says that there are still many mosambis left.
('73', 426, 13, 24, 776310) Find out correctly and tell me.
('73', 426, 13, 25, 776342) How many are there?
('73', 426, 13, 26, 776362) They are more than enough.
('73', 426, 13, 27, 776389) Pyarelal would need very few or none at all.
('73', 426, 13, 28, 776434) Who all are taking mosambis?
('73', 426, 13, 29, 776463) Chimanlal, etc.?
('73', 426, 13, 30, 776480) The point is that it should not be made a duty for Rajaram to go.
('73', 426, 13, 31, 776546) If it can be managed, he should not be sent in such rains.
('73', 426, 13, 32, 776605) I have been facing such problems from the days of South Africa.
('73', 426, 13, 33, 776669) There too a particular man went to the city every day.
('73', 426, 13, 34, 776724) I came to know about it.
('73', 426, 13, 35, 776749) I took up cudgels and resolved that he should go only twice a week.
('73', 426, 13, 36, 776817) Thereby, I saved energy, time and money.
('73', 426, 13, 37, 776858) Any one

('73', 431, 1, 2, 783390) 595. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('73', 431, 2, 3, 783418) September 3, 1938 I have been in close touch with the prime movers affected by the tragedy which is now being enacted in Travancore, and I had hoped that I should be able to avoid having to make any public statement.
('73', 431, 2, 4, 783635) After a study of the available evidence and interviews with rep resentative men from Travancore, I have come to the conclusion that the Travancore Government are resorting to repressive methods, far in excess of the requirements, if there are any.
('73', 431, 2, 5, 783883) The Travancore Government contend that the Travancore State Congress activities are disloyal and subversive.
('73', 431, 2, 6, 783992) I have studied the documents alleged to contain evidence in support of such a charge and have failed to find anything of that nature.
('73', 431, 2, 7, 784126) On the contrary, I have seen emphatic repudiaton by the State Congress of the charge unless constitutional agitation for responsible government is to be called subversive.
('73', 431, 2, 8, 784298) I have, however, read the memorial of the Working Committee of the Travancore State Congress, making the most serious charges unsupported by any evidence against the able Dewan, Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar.
('73', 431, 2, 9, 784503) They should never have been made, even if the memorialists had evidence in support.
('73', 431, 2, 10, 784587) Such evidence is irrelevant to the case for responsible government.
('73', 431, 2, 11, 784655) It would have its place in a memorial for the removal of the Dewan.
('73', 431, 2, 12, 784723) There is no doubt that these charges have harmed the memorialists and therefore the State Con gress, though they cannot weaken the case for responsible govern ment.
('73', 431, 2, 13, 784888) I have no doubt whatsoever that the case for responsible government will be strengthened by the frightfulness being committed by the Government of Travancore if only the people will not be demoralized and will continue to adhere to non violence.
('73', 431, 2, 14, 785134) If reports about violence by students are true, I appeal to the students to desist and allow the movement to develop non violently.
('73', 431, 2, 15, 785266) Leaders who have been locked up should make amends by with drawing the charges against the Dewan.
('73', 431, 2, 16, 785364) I had the honour of meeting the young Maharaja and the Maharani.
('73', 431, 2, 17, 785429) I have had the privilege of knowing Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar for many years.
('73', 431, 2, 18, 785507) I appeal to them to retrace their steps and allow
('73', 432, 0, 1, 785557) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 433
('73', 432, 1, 2, 785607) the State Congress to function so long as its activities remain peaceful.
('73', 432, 1, 3, 785681) Surely the common law of the State is enough to cope with individuals using violent language or resorting to actual violence.
('73', 432, 1, 4, 785807) But at this hour of the day, to expect the people to submit to the suppression of free speech or of demands, however advanced these may be is to invite trouble.
('73', 432, 1, 5, 785968) In my humble opinion, the prevention of Shrimati Kamaladevi Chattopadhyaya from entering the State was a first class tactical blunder.
('73', 432, 1, 6, 786103) it passes comprehension how Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar, himself a foreigner, prohibited the entry of a distinguished Indian lady on the grounds, according to him, of her being an outsider.
('73', 432, 1, 7, 786291) She was amenable to the State law if she had committed any breach thereof.
('73', 432, 1, 8, 786366) I thought it was only reserved for the English administrators to treat Indians going from one province to another as foreigners.
('73', 432, 1, 9, 786495) It ill becomes the Indian Princes and their advisers to follow the perni cious practice of the English administratorsa practice of which many Englishmen are heartily ashamed.
('73', 432, 1, 10, 786670) The Government may, by the terrible repression they have resorted to, succeed in killing the move ment for the time being, but it will never die and will leave a bitter memory behind.
('73', 432, 1, 11, 786854) I hope that wiser counsels will yet prevail and the State Congress will be permitted to function properly.
('73', 432, 2, 12, 786961) Harijan, 10 9 1938
('73', 432, 3, 13, 786980) 596. CHOICE BEFORE CONGRESSMEN
('73', 432, 4, 14, 787011) Since the publication of my article 1 on violence said to be creeping into the Congress ranks, evidence is coming in to corro borate the complaints made by my correspondents.
('73', 432, 4, 15, 787186) Violence at Con gress elections, they say, is on the increase.
('73', 432, 4, 16, 787249) It looks as if Congressmen are not able to digest the power that has come to the Congress.
('73', 432, 4, 17, 787340) Everyone wants to have a share in the spoils of office.
('73', 432, 4, 18, 787396) And so there is an unhealthy competition to capture committees.
('73', 432, 4, 19, 787460) This is not the way to win swaraj, nor is it the way to work the office programme.
('73', 432, 4, 20, 787543) The holding of any office in the Congress Government must be in the spirit of service without the slightest expectation of personal gain.
('73', 432, 4, 21, 787681) If A is satisfied in ordinary life with getting Rs. 25 per month, he has no right to expect Rs. 250 on becoming a minister or obtaining any other office under the Govern 
('73', 432, 5, 22, 787852) 1 Vide Our Failure, 22 3 1938
('73', 433, 0, 1, 787882) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 433, 1, 2, 787924) And there are many Congressmen who are taking only Rs. 25 per month in voluntary organizations and who are well able to shoulder ministerial responsibility.
('73', 433, 1, 3, 788081) Bengal and Maharashtra are teem ing with able men who have dedicated themselves to public service on a mere pittance and who are well able to give a good account of themselves no matter where they are put.
('73', 433, 1, 4, 788287) But they are not to be tempted to leave the fields they have chosen, and it would be wrong to drag them out of their invaluable self chosen obscurity.
('73', 433, 1, 5, 788438) It is true all the world over, and more true perhaps of this country, that as a rule the best and the wisest men will not become ministers or accept positions under Governments.
('73', 433, 1, 6, 788616) But I have digressed.
('73', 433, 1, 7, 788638) We may not always get the best and the wisest men and women to run Congress Governments, but swaraj will become a distant dream if the ministers and other Congressmen holding offices are not self less, able and incorruptible.
('73', 433, 1, 8, 788864) We are not likely to have such men if congress committees become job hunting arenas in which the most violent would win.
('73', 433, 1, 9, 788985) How to preserve the purity of the organization is the question.
('73', 433, 1, 10, 789049) Anyone who subscribes to the credal article of the Congress and pays 4 annas can demand registration as a member.
('73', 433, 1, 11, 789163) Many sign the congress pledge without believing in the necessity for observing truth and non violence as conditions of attainment of swaraj.
('73', 433, 1, 12, 789304) Let no one cavil at my use of the expressions truthful and non violent as synonymous with legitimate and peaceful.
('73', 433, 1, 13, 789419) From the very comm encement of the Congress constitution I have used those adjectives without challenge.
('73', 433, 1, 14, 789524) The word non violence was first introduced by me in the resolution on non co operation carried in Calcutta by the Congress.
('73', 433, 1, 15, 789648) Can anything be untruthful and yet be legitimate, violent and yet be peaceful?
('73', 433, 1, 16, 789727) Be that as it may, I claim that those who commit a breach of these two primary conditions, no matter by what adjectives they are known, can have no place in the Congress organization so long as it is governed by the present constitution.
('73', 433, 1, 17, 789965) Similarly those who do not use khadi as habitual wear have no place in any Congress committee.
('73', 433, 1, 18, 790060) This condition should apply also to those who do not carry out vital resolutions of the Congress, A.I.C.C. or the Working Committee.
('73', 433, 1, 19, 790193) My prescription would be that those who commit a breach of any of these conditions should automatically cease to belong to the Congress.
('73', 433, 1, 20, 790330) It may be urged that the remedy is too drastic.
('73', 433, 1, 21, 790378) It is, if it is regarded as a punishment.
('73', 433, 1, 22, 790420) If it is the automatic
('73', 434, 0, 1, 790443) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 435
('73', 434, 1, 2, 790493) result of a particular act or omission of a person, it is no punishment.
('73', 434, 1, 3, 790566) I know that thrusting my finger into a furnace will surely burn it and still I thrust it; my suffering is no punishment, it is the natural consequence of my action.
('73', 434, 1, 4, 790731) Punishment depends upon the will of the judge.
('73', 434, 1, 5, 790778) Natural consequences are independent of any persons will.
('73', 434, 1, 6, 790836) It will be urged that under these conditions the Congress will cease to be a democratic organization, it will become a close corpo ration.
('73', 434, 1, 7, 790975) I hold a wholly contrary view.
('73', 434, 1, 8, 791006) Democracy of the West is, in my opinion, only so called.
('73', 434, 1, 9, 791063) It has germs in it, certainly, of the true type.
('73', 434, 1, 10, 791112) But it can only come when all violence is eschewed and malpractices disappear.
('73', 434, 1, 11, 791191) The two go hand in hand.
('73', 434, 1, 12, 791216) Indeed malpractice is a species of violence.
('73', 434, 1, 13, 791261) If India is to evolve the true type, there would be no compromise with violence or untruth.
('73', 434, 1, 14, 791353) Ten million men and women on the Congress register with violence and untruth in their breasts would not evolve real democracy or bring swaraj.
('73', 434, 1, 15, 791496) But I can conceive the possibility of ten thousand Con gressmen and women who are cent per cent true, and free from having to carry the burden of innumerable doubtful companions, bringing swaraj.
('73', 434, 1, 16, 791692) Let us reflect upon the past a little.
('73', 434, 1, 17, 791731) Over fifty years ago a handful of men and women took it into their heads to meet together and represent and speak in the name of the dumb millions.
('73', 434, 1, 18, 791879) Time has proved the validity of their claim.
('73', 434, 1, 19, 791924) Since then the prestige of the Congress has risen not in proportion to its numbers, not in proportion to the display of intellect on the platform or in committee rooms, but it has risen in proportion to the ability of Congressmen to suffer and sacrifice, themselves for the nation.
('73', 434, 1, 20, 792206) No one will deny that when in 1920 the Congress definitely became a democratic, duly elected body having a large number of voters on its rolls, it found itself possessed of new power only because it deliberately adopted truth and non violence as its means of reaching its goal.
('73', 434, 1, 21, 792484) And even at the present day, the Congress has quite an insignificant number of men and women on its register compared to the tremendous power it wields.
('73', 434, 1, 22, 792637) The reason to my mind is that it shows a measure of sacrifice cohesion and discipline unequalled by any other organization in India.
('73', 434, 1, 23, 792770) But as an experienced servant and general I make bold to say that we shall have to show a much higher measure of these qualities if we are to win independence before many years are out.
('73', 434, 1, 24, 792956) It is my deliberate convic tion based on closest observation that we can secure all we want, within
('73', 435, 0, 1, 793056) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 435, 1, 2, 793098) much less time than perhaps any one of us imagines, simply by showing high efficiency and equally high honesty in every one of the Congress activities.
('73', 435, 1, 3, 793250) It would ill become us as truly brave men and women to wish ill to the British in order to gain our end.
('73', 435, 1, 4, 793355) In non violent warfare wishing ill to the enemy is not permissible A non violent person relies upon his own strength and refuses to trade upon his opponents weakness.
('73', 435, 1, 5, 793522) With all the earnestness I can command I, therefore, plead with every Congressman who believes in his pledge to make his choice: either to apply the purge I have suggested, or, if that is not feasible because of the Congress being already overmanned by those who have lost faith in its creed and its constructive programme on which depends its real strength, to secede from it for its own sake and prove his living faith in the creed and programme by practising the former and prosecuting the latter as if he had never seceded from the Congress of his ideal.
('73', 435, 1, 6, 794081) If one or the other thing is not done, I see grave danger of the Congress collapsing by the weight of its own weaknesses.
('73', 435, 1, 7, 794203) It has given me no pleasure to pen these lines.
('73', 435, 1, 8, 794251) But having felt the urge, I would have been untrue to the Congress if I had not uttered the warning.
('73', 435, 1, 9, 794352) It is the voice of silence.
('73', 435, 1, 10, 794380) For the reader should know I took silence over a fortnight ago for an indefinite period.
('73', 435, 1, 11, 794469) It has given me peace I cannot describe, and it enables me to commune with Nature.
('73', 435, 1, 12, 794552) Harijan, 3 9 1938

('73', 441, 8, 19, 803529) 609. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('73', 441, 9, 20, 803557) September 6, 1938 I have read the Travancore Dewans statement with the attention it deserves.
('73', 441, 9, 21, 803651) I fear I cannot take shelter under ignorance of the Press messages published from time to time on the tragedy that is being continued in Travancore.
('73', 441, 9, 22, 803800) 2 Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyars defence reads like an edition of the reports that used to be issued on behalf of the British Government during the civil disobedience campaign.
('73', 441, 9, 23, 803973) Not even the massacre of Jallianwalla was justified exactly as the Travancore shootings are now being justified.
('73', 441, 9, 24, 804086) Was not General Dyers action subsequently condemned?
('73', 441, 9, 25, 804139) So is it likely to be in this case.
('73', 441, 10, 26, 804175) 1 Mohanlal Saxena, General Manager, Associated Journals, Lucknow, the publishers of the The National Herald, the first issue of which appeared on September 9, 1938; vide also Letter to Amtussalaam, 9 9 1938
('73', 441, 11, 27, 804382) 2 The Dewan in his statement had said, Mahatma Gandhi is thoroughly unaware of the facts.
('73', 442, 0, 1, 804472) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 443
('73', 442, 1, 2, 804522) I ask Sir C. P. Ramaswami to copy Sir Mirza Ismail and appoint an outsider of unimpeachable integrity to enquire into the whole affair.
('73', 442, 1, 3, 804658) Let him declare a general amnesty and allow free expression of opinion.
('73', 442, 1, 4, 804730) Instead of importing the military and a Special Officer to carry on repression, I invite the Travancore Government to request someone like the Rt.
('73', 442, 1, 5, 804877) Honble V. S. Srinivasa Sastri, if Congressmen are anathema, to go to Travancore and help them to re establish peace there without further military action.
('73', 442, 2, 6, 805032) Harijan, 10 9 1938

('73', 453, 2, 3, 818973) APPENDIX I
('73', 453, 3, 4, 818984) LETTER FROM M. A. JINNAH 1
('73', 453, 4, 5, 819011) NEW DELHI, March 3, 1938
('73', 453, 5, 6, 819036) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('73', 453, 6, 7, 819053) I have received your letter of the 24th February, 1938. I am sorry for the delay in replying as I was not well.
('73', 453, 6, 8, 819165) In your letter I missed the note of response, first whether you are of opinion that you see light now and the moment has come, and secondly, if so, whether you are prepared to take the matter up in right earnest, and thirdly, I find that there is no change in your attitude and mentality when you say you would be guided by Maulana Abul Kalam Azad as Dr. Ansari is no more.
('73', 453, 6, 9, 819539) If you pursue this line you will be repeating the same tragedy as you did when you expressed your helplessness because Dr. Ansari, holding pronounced and die hard views, did not agree and you had to say that although you were willing, but what could you do?
('73', 453, 6, 10, 819797) This happened, as you know, before you went to the Round Table Conference.
('73', 453, 6, 11, 819872) At the Round Table Conference the tragedy was repeated by you when you seemed to be willing to accept provisionally certain terms: but you there also expressed that you were helpless as the Hindus were unwilling and you, as a representative of the Congress, would have no objection, if the Hindus and Mussalmans came to an agreement.
('73', 453, 7, 12, 820206) We have reached a stage when no doubt should be left that you recognize the All India Muslim League as the one authoritative and representative organization of the Mussalmans of India and on the other hand you represent the Congress and other Hindus throughout the country.
('73', 453, 7, 13, 820480) It is only on that basis that we can proceed further and devise machinery of approach.
('73', 453, 8, 14, 820567) Of course, I shall be glad to see you, although I shall be equally glad to see Pandit Jawaharlal or Mr. Bose, [as] you may desire.
('73', 453, 8, 15, 820698) The matter as you know will not be clinched without reference again to you by either of them.
('73', 453, 8, 16, 820792) Therefore, I will prefer to see you first.
('73', 453, 8, 17, 820835) In any case, I am sorry to say that I cannot come to Segaon to see you before the 10th March.
('73', 453, 8, 18, 820929) I have to go to Bombay and also I have fixed various other engagements of my tour.
('73', 453, 8, 19, 821012) But we can fix up the time and place that may suit us both.
('73', 453, 8, 20, 821072) Yours sincerely,
('73', 453, 9, 21, 821089) M. A. JINNAH
('73', 453, 10, 22, 821102) The Bombay Chronicle, 16 6 1938
('73', 453, 11, 23, 821134) 1 Vide Letter to M. A. Jinnah, 24 2 1938
('73', 454, 0, 1, 821175) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 455
('73', 454, 1, 2, 821225) APPENDIX II
('73', 454, 2, 3, 821237) A TRAGEDY 1
('73', 454, 3, 4, 821249) I proudly write in these columns about Gandhijis health, discussing the causes of its breakdown, warning people, asking them to give him more rest.
('73', 454, 3, 5, 821397) Ruthlessly I have turned out people wanting to see him, and have even interrupted talks and interviews, lest they should strain him over much and raise his blood pressure.
('73', 454, 3, 6, 821569) Fancy, therefore, my misery and my shame when I found one morning at Delang that what he considered a serious blunder on my part had raised his blood pressure to the breaking point and might have brought about a catastrophe.
('73', 454, 3, 7, 821794) Tuesday and Wednesday and Thursday, 29th, 30th and 31stwhich in that peaceful atmosphere of Orissa should have been the most blissful dayswere the most miserable days I have ever had in my life.
('73', 454, 3, 8, 821989) But they were, if anything, more miserable for Gandhiji, as I found from his heart broken and heart breaking utterance on the afternoon of the 30th.
('73', 454, 3, 9, 822138) I thought I had made amends indeed at that mornings prayer by telling everyone present how I had been the cause of the terrible breakdown, but Gandhiji was not present when I spoke.
('73', 454, 3, 10, 822320) But he knew that I had spoken about the incident, and so he devoted his speech to the incident.
('73', 454, 3, 11, 822416) I bespeak the indulgence of the reader for inflicting on him this tale of personal woe.
('73', 454, 3, 12, 822504) But I do it on public grounds, as he will find at the end of the story.
('73', 454, 4, 13, 822576) The circumstances were somewhat like these.
('73', 454, 4, 14, 822620) My wife, who rarely attends the annual meetings of the Gandhi Seva Sangh, or for that matter any such meetings, came to Delang, especially, I was told, with a view to being able to go to Puri.
('73', 454, 4, 15, 822813) And Gandhiji told me that I should make every arrangement for her going to Puri.
('73', 454, 4, 16, 822894) Personally I disliked her having come for the sake of Puri, and had no heart to make any arrangements.
('73', 454, 4, 17, 822997) I was once again asked if I had made the arrangements, and asked a third time.
('73', 454, 4, 18, 823076) My wife to my surprise did not know that the Puri temple was not open to the Harijans.
('73', 454, 4, 19, 823163) During Gandhijis Harijan tour she was in jail.
('73', 454, 4, 20, 823210) But that was no excuse for the ignorance.
('73', 454, 4, 21, 823252) On the very first day in the course of his exhibition speech Gandhiji made it clear that the temple of the Lord of the World was not open to the Harijans, and so long as it remained so, the Lord was not, in his opinion, the Lord of the World, but the Lord of those who fed and feasted under His shelter.
('73', 454, 4, 22, 823556) I had hoped that this speech would be a warning to all, including my wife, though I had a fear that she would go into the temple.
('73', 454, 4, 23, 823686) I must also confess that I had a lurking suspicion thatGandhijis repeated insistence on my making arrangements for her going to Puri sprang out of the depth of his ahimsathe ahimsa that had made him serve liquor to Tommies in the Zulu Rebellion, and to serve meat to his friends at table in South Africa.
('73', 454, 4, 24, 823991) I had also hoped that because she was going there with a number of other friends, including Gandhijis second son Manilal, she would not go into the temple when the rest stood out.
('73', 454, 4, 25, 824171) What I did not do was to din into her head that her going into
('73', 454, 5, 26, 824234) 1 Vide Letter to Mirabehn,4 4 1938
('73', 455, 0, 1, 824269) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 455, 1, 2, 824311) the temple would break Gandhijis heart.
('73', 455, 1, 3, 824351) As I have said, I was stupid enough not to realize the possible reaction and had even fancied that in the boundless charity of his heart he had found room for forgiving a temple goer like my wife.
('73', 455, 1, 4, 824548) I must therefore confess that even if she had definitely told me before going that she had made up her mind to go into the temple, I should not have resisted her.
('73', 455, 1, 5, 824711) I did not want to disturb her faith to that extent.
('73', 455, 1, 6, 824763) She knew that I was against it, she also knew that I have a horror of these templestemples which even when they are opened to the Harijans, would not be better unless they were purged of the unscrupulous pandas.
('73', 455, 1, 7, 824975) But if she thought it would do her soul good to go into the temple, I did not in my heart of hearts feel like standing in the way.
('73', 455, 1, 8, 825106) As for Kasturba Gandhi, I must say that I had assumed she would stand out and her presence would perhaps act as a check on my wife and others.
('73', 455, 1, 9, 825249) But as it happened, my wife went in, another friend went in, and also went in Kasturba.
('73', 455, 1, 10, 825337) Some members of the party stayed out, including my little son who put up a plucky fight with the pandas.
('73', 455, 2, 11, 825442) On Monday evening when they returned and Gandhiji knew the whole story, he was sad.
('73', 455, 2, 12, 825526) He had a sleepless night.
('73', 455, 2, 13, 825552) He called Kasturba and my wife and me to account.
('73', 455, 2, 14, 825602) The explanation, part of which is contained in the argument above, failed to satisfy him.
('73', 455, 2, 15, 825692) It even irritated him.
('73', 455, 2, 16, 825715) He held that I was primarily to blame.
('73', 455, 2, 17, 825754) He held that I should have explained to them the history of the movement, how Gandhiji had gone to Puri in 1934, how violence was organized there, how he had to undertake the Orissa pilgrimage on foot, how reformers were warned not to go to the temple until Harijans were admitted, and if my wife still did not listen, Gandhijis assistance should have been sought, and if then too she insisted on going she should have been free to go.
('73', 455, 2, 18, 826190) He held hat I had not been watchful enough and that I had thus been unjust to him, my wife, myself and to the cause.
('73', 455, 2, 19, 826307) And so he thus poured out his heart to the members of the Sangh : 1
('73', 455, 3, 20, 826375) This pouring out of the agony of his heart was for me an added agony.
('73', 455, 3, 21, 826445) He was so disconsolate.
('73', 455, 3, 22, 826469) The next day he felt too weak to speak and went into silence for the whole day as a measure of precaution.
('73', 455, 3, 23, 826576) What could I do in the circumstances?
('73', 455, 3, 24, 826614) I was afraid lest I should make matters worse by entering into explanations and arguments.
('73', 455, 3, 25, 826705) I felt like waiting until he had regained his normal pressure and strength.
('73', 455, 3, 26, 826781) But the thought of my having been the cause of the collapse tormented me.
('73', 455, 3, 27, 826855) If I was guilty of a grievous error of judgment, how could I continue to serve him?
('73', 455, 3, 28, 826939) How could I correctly represent and serve the Harijan cause?
('73', 455, 3, 29, 827000) What right had I to be his door keeper?
('73', 455, 3, 30, 827040) I had the hell of a night, and in sheer desperation I wrote to him a note imploring him to put me away.
('73', 455, 3, 31, 827144) This exasperated him all the more and made the cross heavier to bear.
('73', 455, 3, 32, 827214) He would prefer death, he said, at the hands of one who loved, to life at the hands of one who did not love him !
('73', 455, 3, 33, 827328) Instead of realizing my folly and repairing it by going to Puri with a band of satyagrahi pilgrims, he said, I had gone into hysterics over a well meant rebuke !
('73', 455, 3, 34, 827490) Instead of serving my wife, he said, I had in my blind love of her
('73', 455, 4, 35, 827557) 1 For the full text of the speech, vide Speech at Gandhi Seva Sangh Meeting, 30 3 1938
('73', 456, 0, 1, 827644) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 457
('73', 456, 1, 2, 827694) encouraged her superstition !
('73', 456, 2, 3, 827724) All this was too stunning for words.
('73', 456, 2, 4, 827761) I felt that Gandhiji, who has performed
('73', 456, 3, 5, 827801) several spiritual operations using the chloroform of love, had performed this one
('73', 456, 4, 6, 827883) without that chloroform.
('73', 456, 4, 7, 827908) In resentment I cried :
('73', 456, 5, 8, 827932) To live with the saints in heaven
('73', 456, 6, 9, 827966) Is a bliss and a glory,
('73', 456, 7, 10, 827990) But to live with a saint on earth
('73', 456, 8, 11, 828024) Is a different story.
('73', 456, 9, 12, 828046) May it not be that he had made a mountain of a molehill ?
('73', 456, 10, 13, 828104) But who am I to judge?
('73', 456, 10, 14, 828127) As I write this I feel that I was perhaps too dense to
('73', 456, 11, 15, 828182) probe into the workings of his highy sensitive mind.
('73', 456, 11, 16, 828235) And after all he who had
('73', 456, 12, 17, 828260) devoted half a century of vigilant endeavour to the pursuit of truth and ahimsa should
('73', 456, 13, 18, 828347) be trusted to judge a situation better than I, ever liable to be swayed by passions and
('73', 456, 14, 19, 828435) desires.
('73', 456, 14, 20, 828444) What may appear to me to be trifles may be matters of life and death to him.
('73', 456, 15, 21, 828521) realized that however difficult life with him may appear sometimes, separation would
('73', 456, 16, 22, 828606) be still more unbearable.
('73', 456, 16, 23, 828632) He disclaims saintship.
('73', 456, 16, 24, 828656) He claims to be no better than the
('73', 456, 17, 25, 828691) smallest of us.
('73', 456, 17, 26, 828707) I realized that I had grievously erred in associating even in thought
('73', 456, 18, 27, 828777) those doleful lines with him.
('73', 456, 18, 28, 828807) Whether he is a saint or a mere mortal, like all of us, I
('73', 456, 19, 29, 828865) see that my cry for separation was a fit of frenzy.
('73', 456, 19, 30, 828917) For when I look upon the note that I
('73', 456, 20, 31, 828954) wrote to him, I feel I could not have gone five yards before returning as a penitent.
('73', 456, 21, 32, 829040) And after all is said and done, one thing stands out in bold reliefGandhijis
('73', 456, 22, 33, 829117) uncompromising love of the Harijans and his anxiety to lay down his life for that
('73', 456, 23, 34, 829199) The poignant utterance became a call to greater dedication for the cause.
('73', 456, 24, 35, 829273) incident burnt into every one of those who attended the Sangh meeting this year the
('73', 456, 25, 36, 829357) lesson that no one shall tamper with that most important item of the constructive
('73', 456, 26, 37, 829439) programme and that everyone shall be wide awake.
('73', 456, 26, 38, 829488) The week of retreat in sacred
('73', 456, 27, 39, 829518) Orissa became more sacred with the cleansing effect of the electric shock that
('73', 456, 28, 40, 829597) Gandhiji gave them, and the members went home with a message that they are not
('73', 456, 29, 41, 829676) likely easily to forget.
('73', 456, 29, 42, 829701) M. D. Harijan, 9 4 1938
('73', 457, 0, 1, 829725) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 457, 1, 2, 829767) APPENDIX III LETTER FROM KHWAJA NAZIMUDDIN 1
('73', 457, 2, 3, 829812) May 11, 1938
('73', 457, 3, 4, 829825) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('73', 457, 4, 5, 829842) I write to acquaint you with the conclusions which have been reached by the Government of Bengal in the matter of the premature release of terrorist convicts.
('73', 457, 4, 6, 830001) In formulating these proposals, Government have given the most careful consideration to the suggestions which you were good enough to put forward in your letter of April 12.
('73', 457, 5, 7, 830175) It is necessary to emphasize at the outset that the scheme which is embodied in the succeeding paragraph is to be regarded as a connected plan, the different parts of which form a single and indivisible whole.
('73', 457, 5, 8, 830385) As such, it is communicated not only for securing your own acceptance, but also the acceptance of Mr. Sarat Chandra Bose, President of the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee as well as the leader of the Congress party in the Assembly.
('73', 457, 6, 9, 830622) Government desire to commend the scheme to your most earnest conside ration, because the declared acceptance by you, and by the Congress of Governments policy in this matter is a vital precedent condition to the adoption of the plan.
('73', 457, 6, 10, 830856) In the absence of that acceptance Government will regard these proposals as null and void and will continue to discharge their responsibilities in this matter, according to the policy which has already been announced in the Legislature.
('73', 457, 7, 11, 831093) The scheme is as follows :
('73', 457, 8, 12, 831120) (1) To release forthwith terrorist convicts suffering from serious and con tinued illness.
('73', 457, 9, 13, 831211) (2) To release as soon as possible those convicts who have not been con victed of offences involving the actual commission of murder and serious violence, and have a comparatively short period of their sentences not in excess of 18 months still to serve.
('73', 457, 10, 14, 831466) (3) To place the cases of the remaining convicts before an Advisory Committee which will examine them on individual merits and make such recommen dations in each case to Government as it thinks fit.
('73', 457, 11, 15, 831665) The decision as to the orders to be passed in each case, after consideration of the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, will rest with Government.
('73', 457, 11, 16, 831818) (4) The Advisory Committee will be appointed by Government and will consist of 9 members as follows : (i) The President, a retired judicial officer of high standing; (ii) A member of the Coalition Party;
('73', 457, 12, 17, 832022) 1 Vide Letter to Khwaja Nazimuddin, 15 5 1938
('73', 458, 0, 1, 832068) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 459
('73', 458, 1, 2, 832118) (iii) A member of the Legislative Assembly from the Congress Party; (iv) A member of the Legislative Assembly from amongst the representatives of the Scheduled Castes; (v) A member of the Legislative Assembly from the Liberal Party; (vi) A member of the Legislative Council from the Congress Party; (vii) A European member of the Legislature; (viii) One other Muslim member; and (ix) An official.
('73', 458, 1, 3, 832515) The names of the members constituting the Committee will be announced as early as possible.
('73', 458, 1, 4, 832607) As an integral part of the scheme it shall be agreed and accepted between the Government, yourself and the Congress as follows : (1) That no attempt will be made hereafter by the Congress, or by any other body with the support, tacit or open, of the Congress to secure an advance upon these terms, and the matter shall cease to be a political issue;
('73', 458, 2, 5, 832957) (2) That you and the Congress will actively discourage all forms of agita tion for the accelerated release of prisoners, all attacks in the Press on the policy of Government in the matter of terrorist prisoners, all demonstrations and receptions on the release of such prisoners or thereafter, and all statements,writings and speeches favourable to terrorists or terrorism;
('73', 458, 3, 6, 833331) (3) That you and the Congress will take every step possible to create and maintain public opinion against hunger striking and will publicly condemn such a course if adopted.
('73', 458, 4, 7, 833505) In proposing these terms and conditions, the Government of Bengal have gone to the utmost limit which they consider to be compatible with the discharge of their responsibilities for the eradication of this canker of terrorism, which has for so long been a recurrent factor in the political life of the Province.
('73', 458, 4, 8, 833817) They have done so in the hope of mobilizing public opinion and of contributing to the creation and maintenance of the atmosphere calculated to render a recrudescence of terrorism unlikely.
('73', 458, 4, 9, 834006) Government earnestly desire the active association with themselves of all who genuinely wish for the ordered and non violent political development of the country.
('73', 458, 4, 10, 834169) Your own support I claim with the confidence of one who knows how much you have the same object at heart.
('73', 458, 4, 11, 834275) I should be glad, therefore, if you will be good enough to communicate your views on these proposals as early as possible, and I would suggest that it would be appropriate if you would communicate with Mr. Subhas Chandra Bose and the Leader of the Congress Party in the Legislative Assembly, Bengal, with a view to obtaining their acceptance.
('73', 458, 4, 12, 834618) The Hindustan Times, 4 10 1938
('73', 459, 0, 1, 834649) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('73', 459, 1, 2, 834691) APPENDIX IV
('73', 459, 2, 3, 834703) STATEMENT OF DR.
('73', 459, 2, 4, 834720) N. B. KHARE 1
('73', 459, 3, 5, 834734) July 25, 1938
('73', 459, 4, 6, 834748) I have already admitted an error of judgment committed by me in presenting my resignation to the Governor on the eve of the meeting of the Working Committee.
('73', 459, 4, 7, 834906) I admit that I have been guilty of indiscipline.
('73', 459, 4, 8, 834955) I, as an old Congressman, should have known the value of discipline.
('73', 459, 4, 9, 835024) I realize now 2 the enormity of the error, which has resulted in the dismissal of the Congress Ministers by the Governor under his constitutional powers under the Act 3.
('73', 459, 5, 10, 835194) I am sincerely sorry for what has happened on account of this loss of balance and I think that it is my duty to relinquish all positions of trust in the Congress, whose cause I have put in jeopardy by my action.
('73', 459, 5, 11, 835406) I shall be content if I am permitted to serve as a camp follower.
('73', 459, 5, 12, 835472) I shall do everything in my power to retrieve the prestige which the Congress has lost through my action.
('73', 459, 6, 13, 835578) I hope that all Congressmen will rally round the Working Committee in its endeavour to form a united and stable ministry, for there are rumours of a split in the Province between Maharashtra and Mahakoshal.
('73', 459, 6, 14, 835785) I hope that good counsels will prevail and we shall not think in terms of Maharashtra and Mahakoshal.
('73', 459, 6, 15, 835887) I shall try my best to prevent any such split.
('73', 459, 7, 16, 835934) The Hindu, 3 9 1938
('73', 459, 8, 17, 835954) APPENDIX V
('73', 459, 9, 18, 835965) WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION ON C. P. CRISIS 4
('73', 459, 10, 19, 836012) After having heard the Parliamentary Sub committee and given anxious consideration to the events that have happened since the agreement arrived at in Pachmarhi between the Ministers in the presence of the members of the Parliamentary Sub committee and the Presidents of the three Provincial Congress Committees concerned, and after having had several interviews with Dr. Khare, the Working Committee have reluctantly come to the conclusion that by the series of acts committed by Dr. Khare, culminating in his resignation of his charge and demanding the resignation of his colleagues of their charge, Dr. Khare was guilty of grave errors of judgment, which have exposed the Congress in the C. P. to ridicule and brought down its prestige.
('73', 459, 10, 20, 836751) He was also guilty of gross indiscipline in that he
('73', 459, 11, 21, 836803) 1 Vide Statement to the Press, 30 7 1938 and Statement to the Press, 5 9 1938 2 Now was deleted by Gandhiji.
('73', 459, 11, 22, 836912) 3 Under the Act was deleted by Gandhiji.
('73', 459, 11, 23, 836953) 4 Vide Functions of the Working Committee, 6 8 1938
('73', 460, 0, 1, 837005) VOL. 73 : 21 FEBRUARY, 1938 8 SEPTEMBER, 1938 461
('73', 460, 1, 2, 837055) acted in spite of warnings against any precipitate action.
('73', 460, 2, 3, 837114) His resignation was the direct cause for the exercise, for the first time since
('73', 460, 3, 4, 837194) office acceptance by the Congress, by a Governor of his special powers, whereby Dr.
('73', 460, 4, 5, 837278) Khares three colleagues were dismissed.
('73', 460, 4, 6, 837318) The Working Committee note with
('73', 460, 5, 7, 837350) satisfaction that these three Congress Ministers showed their loyalty to the Congress
('73', 460, 6, 8, 837436) by declining, without instructions from the Parliamentary Sub committee, to tender
('73', 460, 7, 9, 837519) their resignations which were demanded by the Governor.
('73', 460, 8, 10, 837575) Dr. Khare was further guilty of indiscipline in accepting the invitation of the
('73', 460, 9, 11, 837655) Governor to form a new Ministry, and, contrary to the practice of which he was aware,
('73', 460, 10, 12, 837741) in actually forming a new Ministry and taking the oath of allegiance without
('73', 460, 11, 13, 837818) reference to the Parliamentary Sub committee, and the Working Committee, specially
('73', 460, 12, 14, 837901) when he knew that the meetings of these bodies were imminent.
('73', 460, 13, 15, 837963) By all these acts of his Dr. Khare has proved himself unworthy of holding
('73', 460, 14, 16, 838037) positions of responsibility in the Congress organization.
('73', 460, 14, 17, 838095) He should be so considered
('73', 460, 15, 18, 838122) till, by his services as a Congressman, he has shown himself well balanced and
('73', 460, 16, 19, 838201) capable of observing strict discipline and discharging the duties that may be
('73', 460, 17, 20, 838279) undertaken by him.
('73', 460, 18, 21, 838298) The working Committee have also come to the reluctant conclusion that H. E.
('73', 460, 19, 22, 838374) the Governor of the C. P. has shown, by the ugly haste with which he turned night
('73', 460, 20, 23, 838456) into day and forced the crisis that has overtaken the province, that he was eager to
('73', 460, 21, 24, 838541) weaken and discredit the Congress in so far as it lay in him to do so.
('73', 460, 21, 25, 838612) The Working
('73', 460, 22, 26, 838624) Committee hold that, knowing, as he must have, what was going on among members
('73', 460, 23, 27, 838703) of the Cabinet and the instructions of the Parliamentary Sub committee, he ought not
('73', 460, 24, 28, 838788) to have, with unseemly haste, accepted the resignation of the three Ministers and
('73', 460, 25, 29, 838870) demanded the resignation of the other three, dismissed them on their refusal to resign,
('73', 460, 26, 30, 838958) and immediately called upon Dr. Khare to form a new Ministry and sworn in the
('73', 460, 27, 31, 839036) available members of the new Ministry without waiting for the meeting of the
('73', 460, 28, 32, 839113) Working Committee which was imminent.
('73', 460, 29, 33, 839151) Harijan, 30 7 1938
